CD is cut of the line CL which is equal to the line AB.

But now let CD be less then AB, and let it cut AB by his extreme C. The
fourth case
Now then either it cutteth it in the midst or not in the midst. First let
it cut it in the midst: then CD is either the hal^e of AB, and so is AC equal
to CD.

The fifth case.
Or it is less then the half: and then making the center C and the space CD
describe a circle, which shall cut of from the line AB a line equal to the line
CD.

The s^xt case.
Or it is greater then the half. And the^ unto the point A put the line AF
equal to the line CD, by the second. And making the center A and the space AF
describe a circle, which shall cut of from the line AB a line equal to the
line AF, that is, unto the line CD.

But if the line CD do not cut the line AB in the midst: The seventh and eight
cases.
CD shall either be the half of the line AB: or greater then the half, or
less. If CD be the half of AB, or less then the half of AB, the^ making the
center C, and the space CD describe a circle whi^he shall cut of from the line
AB a line equal to the line CD.

But if it be greater then the half, The ninth case.
then again unto the point A put the line AF equal to the line CD (by the
second proposition:) and making the center A, and the space AF describe a
circle which shall cut of from the line AB a line equal to the line AF, that
is, to the line CD.

But if they cut the one the other as the lines CD and AB do. The tenth case.
The^ making the ce^tre B and the space BA describe a circle AF, and draw a
line from the point B to the point C, and produce it to the point F. And
forasmuch as the two right lines BF and CD are unequal, and the line CD
cutteth the line BF by one of his extremes, therefore it is possible to cut of
from CD a line equal to the line BF. For how to do it we have before declared,
wherefore it is possible from the line CD to cut of a line equal to the line
AB: or AB and BF are equal the one to the other.

This is to be noted, that in all these cases, In all these cases the
construction and demo^stration of the first case will serve.
a man may both as touching construction and demonstration, proceed as in the
first case. For it is possible in any position to put to the end of the
greater line a line equal to the less line, and so making the center the said
end, and the space the less line, to describe a circle, which shall cut of
from the greater line a line equal to the line put, namely, to the less line
given, as it is manifest to see in the figures partly here under set, and
partly in the beginning of the other side put.



This Proposi^ion, though also it be most easy to be done mechanically, yet
is no principle.
If a man will mechanically and redily do this proposition, not regardyng
demonstration, he may extend his compass according to the quantity of the
less line given, and so set on foot thereof in one of the ends of the greater
line given, and with the other foot mark a point in the said greater line,
which shall cut of from the greater line a line eq^all to the less. The
easines of doing whereof may cause this proposition also to seem unto some to
be rather a principle, then a proposition. But to that we have before in the
former proposition answered.

The first Theoreme. The 4. Proposition. If there be two triangles, of which
two sides of the one be equal to two sides of the other, each side to his
correspondent side, and having also on angle of the one equal to one angle of
the other, namely, that angle which is contained under the equal right lines:
the base also of the one shall be equal to the base of the other, and the one
triangle shall be equal to the other triangle, and the other angles remaining
shall be equal to the other angles remaining, the one to the other, under which
are subtended equal sides.
SVppose that there be two triangles ABC, and DEF, having two sides of the one,
namely AB, and AC, equal to two sides of the other, namely, to DE and DF, the
one to the other, that is, AB to DE, and AC to DF: having also the angle BAC,
equal to the angle EDF. Then I say that the base also BC is equal to ye base
OF: and yt the triangle ABC, is equal to the triangle DEF: and yt the other
angles remainyng are equal to the other angles remaining, the one to the
other, under which are subtended equal sides: that is, yt the angle ABC is
equal to the angle DEF, and yt the angle ACB is equal to to the angle DFE.
Demonstration lea^ing to an absurdity.
For the triangle ABC exactly agreyng with the triangle DEF, and the point A
being put upon the point D, and the right line AB upon the right line DE, the
point B also shall exactly agree with the point E: for that (by supposition)
the line AB is equal to the line DE. And the line AB exactly agreeyng with the
line DE, the right line also AC exactly agrees with the right line DF, for
that (by supposition) the angle BAC is equal to the angle EDF. And forasmuch
as the right line AC is also (by supposition) equal to the right line DF,
therefore the point C exactly agrees with the point F. Again forasmuch as
the point C exactly agrees with the point F, and the point B exactly agrees
with the point E: therefore the base BC shall exactly agree with the base OF.
For if the point B do exactly agree with the point E, and the point C with the
point F, and the base BC do not exactly agree with the base OF, then two right
lines do include a superficies: which (by the 10. common sentence) is
impossible. Wherefore the base BC exactly agrees with the base OF, and therefore
is equal unto it. Wherefore the whole triangle ABC exactly agrees with the
whole triangle DEF, and therefore (by the 8. common sentence) is equal unto it.
And (by the same) the other angles remaining exactly agree with the other
angles remaining, and are equal the one to the other: that is, the angle ABC
to the angle DEF, and the angle ACB to the angle DFE. If therefore there be two
triangles, of which two sides of the one, be equal to two sides of the other,
each to his correspondent side, and having also one angle of the one equal to
one angle of the other, namely, that angle which is contained under the equal
right lines: the base also of the one shall be equal to the base of the other,
and the one triangle shall be equal to the other triangle, and the other
angles remainyng shall be equal to the other angles remaining, the one to the
other, under which are subtended eqaull sides: which thing was required to be
demonstrated.

This Proposition which is a Theoreme, Two (...)
has two things given: namely, the equality of two sides of the one triangle,
to two sides of the other triangle, and the equality of two angles contained
under the equal sides. In it also are three things required. Three things
required in it.
The equality of base to base: the equality of field to field: and the equality
of the other angles of the one triangle to the other angles of the other
triangle, under which are subtended equal sides.

How one side i^ equal to an other, and so gene^ally how one right line is
equal to an other.
One side of a plain figure is equal to an other, and so generally one right
line is equal to an other, when the one being applied to the other, their
extremes agree together. For otherwise every right line applied to any right
line, agrees therewith: but equal right lines only, agree in the extremes.

How one rectili^ne^ angle is equal to an other
One rectilined angle is equal to an other rectilined angle, when one of the
sides which comprehends the one angle, being set upon one of the sides which
comprehends the other angle, the other side of the one agrees with the other
side of the other. And that angle is the greater, whose side falls without:
and that the less, whose side falls within.

Why this particle (...) to his c^r^espondent side, is put.
Where as in this proposition is put this particle each to his correspondent
side, (instede whereof often times afterward is used this phrase the one to the
other) it is of necessity so put. For otherwise two sides of one triangle added
together, may be equal to two sides of an other triangle added together, and
the angles also contained under the equal sides may be equal: and yet the two
triangles may notwithstanding be unequal. How one triangle is equal to an other
Where note that a triangle is said to be equal to an other triangle, when
the field or area of the one is equal to the area of the other. And the area
of a triangle, What the field or area of a triangle is, and so of any
rectilined (...).
is that space, which is contained within the sides of a triangle. And the
circuit or compass of a triangle is a line composed of all the sides of a
triangle. And so may you think of all other rectilined figures. What (...) of a
triangle is, and ^o also of any (...) figure.
And now to prove that there may be two triangles, two sides of one of which
being added together, may be equal to two sides o^ the other added together,
and the angles contained under the equal sides may be equal, and yet
notwithstanding the two triangles unequal. Suppose that there be two rectangle
triangles: namely, ABC, and DEF, and let their right angles be BAC and EDF. And
in the triangle ABC let the side AB b^ 3. and the side AC 4. which both added
together make 7.

And in the tria^gle DEF, let the side DE be 2. and the side DF be 5. which
added together make also 7. and so the sides of the one triangle added
together, are equal to the sides of the other tria^gle added together. Yet are
both the triangles unequal, and also their bases. For the area of the triangle
ABC is 6 and his base is 5. And the area of the triangle DEF is 5: and his base
^ 29. So that to have the areas of two triangles to be equal, it is requisite
that all the sides of the two triangles be equal, each to his correspondent
side. It happens also sometimes in triangles, that the areas of them being
equal, their sides added together shall be unequal. And contrariwise, their
sides being equal, their areas be unequal. As in these figures here put it is
plain to see. In the first example the areas of the two triangles are equal,
for they are each 12. and the sides in each added together are unequal, for in
the one triangle the sides added together make 18. and in the other they make
16. But in the second example the areas of the two tria^gles are unequal, for
the one is 12. and the other is 15. But the sides added together in each are
equal, for in each they make 18.

That angle is said to subtend a side of a tria^gle, How an angle is said to
subte^d a side: and a side an angle.
which is placed directly opposite, and against that side. That side also is
said to subtend an angle, which is opposite to the angle. For every angle of a
triangle is contained of two sides of the triangle, and is subtended to the
third side.

This is the first Proposition in which is used a demonstration leading to an
absurditi^, o^ an impossib^litie. This proposition proved by a demonstration
leading to an absurdity.
Which is a demonstration that proves not directly the thing intended, by
principles, or by things before proved by these principles: but proves the
contrary thereof to be impossible, and so does indirectly prove the thing
intended.

The 2. Theoreme. The 5. Proposition. An Isosceles, or triangle of two equal
sides, has his angles a^ the base equal the one to the other. And those equal
sides being produced, the angles which are under the base are also equal the
one to the other.
SVppose that ABC be a triangle of two equal sides called Isosceles, having
the side AB equal to the side AC. And (by the second peticio^) produce the
lines AB and AC directly to ye points D and E. The^ I say, that ye angle ABC is
equal to the angle ACB: and ye ye angle CBD is equal to the angle BCE. Take in
the line BD a point at all adventures, Construction.
and let the same be F, and (by the third proposition) from the greater line,
namely, AE, cut of a line equal to AF being the less line, and let the same
be AG: and draw a right line from the point F to the point C, Demonstration.
and an other from the point G to the point B. Now then for as much as AF is
equal to AG, and AB is equal to AC, therefore these two lines FA and AC are
equal to these two lines GA and AB, the one to the other, and they contain a
common angle, namely, that which is contained under FAG: wherefore (by the
fourth proposition) the base FC is equal to the base GB: and the triangle AFC
is equal to the triangle AGB, and the other angles remaining, are equal to
the other angles remaining the one to the other, under which are subtended
equal sides: that is, the angle ACF is equal to the angle ABG, and the angle
AFC is equal to the angle AGB. And forasmuch as the whole line AF is equal to
the whole line AG, of which the line AB is equal to ye line AC, therefore the
residue of the line AF, namely, the line BF, is equal to the residue of the
line AG, namely, to the line CG (by the third common sentence) And it is proved
that CF is equal to BG. Now therefore these two BF and FC are equal to these
two CG and GB the one to the other, and the angle BFC is equal to the angle
CGB, and they have one base, namely, BC, common to them both: wherefore (by the
4. proposition) the triangle BFC is equal to the triangle CGB, and the other
angles remaynyng are equal to the other angles remaining each to other, under
which are subtended equal sides. Wherefore the angle FBC is equal to the
angle GCB, and the angle BCF is equal to the angle CBG. Now forasmuch as the
whole angle ABG is equal to the whole angle ACF (as it has been proved) of
which the angle CBG is equal to the angle BCF. therefore the angle remaining:
namely, ABC is equal to the angle remaining, namely, to ACB (by the third
common sentence) And they are the angles at the base of the triangle ABC. And it
is proved that the angle FBC is equal to the angle GCB, and they are angles
under the base. Wherefore a triangle of two equal sides has his angles at the
base equal the one to ye other. And those equal sides being produced, the
angles which are under the base are also equal the one to the other: which was
required to be proved.

For that this proposition is some what hard to perceue by reason the sides of
the triangles AFC and AGB and also the sides of the tria^gle BFC and CGB run so
one within an other, therefore I have here put the distinctly, namely, the
triangles FAC and BFC on o^e side of the figure of the proposition and the
triangles ACB and CGB on the other side to that ^^de may with less labor see
the demonstration plainly.

That in an Isosceles triangle, the two angles above the base are equal, may
otherwise be (...) on str^red without drawing lines beneath the base somewhat
altering the construction. Namely, drawing the lines within the triangle,
which before were without it after this manner.

Suppose that ABC be an Isosceles triangle and in the line AB take a point at
all adventures, An other demo^stration invented by Proclus.
and let the same be D, And from the line AC out of a line equal to the line
AD. Which let be AE. And draw these right lines BE, DC, and DE. Now forasmuch
as in the triangles, ABE, and ACD, the side AB is equal to the side AC, by
supposition, and the sides AD and AE are also equal by construction, and the
angle at the point A is common to them both, therefore, by the fourth
proposition, the base BE is equal to the base DC. And, by the same, the angles
remaining of the one triangle are equal to the angles remaining of the other
triangle. Wherefore the angle ABE is equal to the angle ACD. Again forasmuch
as in the triangles BDE, and CED the side DB is equal to the side EC, and the
side BE to the side DC, and the angle DBE is equal to the angle ECD and the
base DE being common to both triangles is equal to it self, therefore the
angles remaining of the one triangle, are equal to the angles remaining of the
other triangle. Wherefore the angle ED^ is equal to the angle D EC: and the
angle DEB is equal to the angle EDC. And forasmuch as the angle EDB is equal to
the angle DEC, from which are taken away equal angles DEB, and EDC, therefore
by the common sentence the angles remaining, namely, BDC and CEB are equal,
And as it was before manifest the sides BD and D C are equal to the sides CE
and EB the one to the other, that is, each to his correspondent side: and the
base BC is common to both the triangles: wherefore the angles remaining are
equal to the angles remaining the one to the other, under which are subte^ded
equal sides. Wherefore the angle D BC is equal to the angle ECB. For the line
D C subtendeth the angle D BC, and the line EB subte^deth the angle ECB: which
two lines are as we have before proved equal. Wherefore in an Isosceles
triangle, the angles at the base are equal, though the right lines be not
produced.

To prove this also, there is an other demonstration of Pappus much shorter
which needs no kind of addition of any thing at all: as follows.

Suppose that ABC be an Isosceles triangle, An other demo^stration invented by
Pappus.
and let the side AB be equal to the side AC. Now then understand this one
triangle to be as it were two triangles. And thus reason. Forasmuch as in the
two triangles ABC and ACB, AB is equal to AC and AC to AB, therefore two sides
of the one are equal to two sides of the other, each to his correspondent side,
and the angle BAC is equal to the angle CAB, for it is one and the self same
angle. Wherefore by the 4. proposition the base CB is equal to the base BC, and
the triangle ABC is equal to the triangle ACB: and the angle ABC is equal to
the angle ACB, and the angle ACB to the angle ABC for under them are subtended
equal sides, namely, the lines AB and AC. Wherefore in an Isosceles triangle,
the angels at the base are equal.

Thales Milesius the inuent^r of this proposition.
The old Philosopher Thales Milesius was the first inuenter of this fifth
proposition, as also of many other.

The third Theoreme. The sixth Proposition. If a triangle have two angles equal
the one to the other: the sides also of the same, which subtend the equal
angles, shall be equal the one to the other.
SVppose that ABC be a triangle, having the angle ABC equal to the angle ACB.
Then I say that the side AB is equal to the side AC. For if the side AB be not
equal to the side AC, then one of them is greater. Let AB be the greater. And
by the third proposition, Construction.
from AB being the greater cut of a line equal to the less line, which is AC^
And let the same be D B. And draw a line from the point D to the point C.
Demonstration leading to an impossib^l^ty.
Now forasmuch as the side DB is equal to the side AC, and the line BC is
common to the^ both: therefore these two sides DB and BC are equal to these
two sides AC and CB the one to the other. And the angle DBC is by supposytion
equal to the angle ACB. Wherefore (by the 4 proposytion) the base DC is equal
to the base AB: and (by the same) the triangle DBC is equal to the triangle
ACB: namely, the less triangle unto the greater tria^gle, which is impossible.
VVhe^fore the side AB is not unequal to the side AC. Wherefore it is equal. If
therefore a triangle have two angles equal the one to the other: the sides also
of the same, which subtende the equal angles, shall be equal the one to the
other^ which was required to be demonstrated.

The chiefest and (...) proper kind of conversion.
In Geometry is o^tentimes used conversion of propositions. As this proposition
is the converse of the proposition next before. The chiefest and most proper
kind of conversion is, when that which was the thing supposed in the former
proposition, is the conclusion of the converse and second proposition: and
contrary wise that which was concluded in the first, is the thing supposed in
the second As in the fifth proposition it was supposed the two sides of a
triangle to be equal, the thing concluded is, that the two angles at the base
are equal and in this proposition, which is the converse thereof is supposed
that the angles at the base be equal. Which in the former proposition was the
conclusion. And the conclusion is, that the two sides subtending the two angles
are equal, which in the former proposition was the supposition. This is the
chiefest kind of conversion uniform and certain.

There is an other kind of conversion, An other kind of conversion not so
perfect as the first.
but not so full a conversion nor so perfect as the first is. Which happens
in composed propositions, that is, in such, which have mo suppositions then
one, and pass from these suppositions to one conclusion. In the co^nuerses of
such propositio^s, you pass from the conclusion of the first proposition, with
one or mo of the suppositions of the same: and conclude some other supposition
of the self first proposition: of this kind there are many in Euclide. Thereof
you may have an example in the 8. proposition being the converse of the four^h.
This conversion is not so uniform as the other; but more diverse and uncertain
according to the multitude of the things given, or suppositions in the
proposition.

But because in the fifth proposition there are two conclusions, Two
conclusions in the fifth proposition.
the first, that the two angles at the ba^e be equal: the second, that the
angles under the ba^e are equal: this is to be noted, that this sixth
proposition is the converse of the ^ame fifth as touching the first conclusion
only. The sixth proposition i^ the converse as touching the first conclusion
only. The converse as touching the second conclusion.
You may in like manner make a converse of the same proposition touching the
second conclusion thereof. And that after this manner.

THe two sides of a triangle being produced, if the angles under the base be
equal, the said triangle shall be an Isosceles triangle. In which proposition
the supposition is, that the angles under the base are equal: which in the
fifth proposition was the conclusion^ and the conclusion in this proposition
is, that the two sides of the triangle are equal, which in the fifth proposition
was the supposition. But now for proof of the said proposition:

Suppose that there be a triangle ABC, and let the sides AB^ and AC be produced
to the points D and G, and let the angles under the base be equal, namely,
the angles DBC, and GCB. Then I say that the triangle ABC is an Isosceles
triangle. Construction.
For take in the line AD a point which let be E. And unto the line BE put the
line CF equal (by the 3. proposition). Demonstration^
And draw these lines EC, BF, and OF. Now forasmuch as BE is equal to CF, and
BC is common to the^ both^ therefore these two lines BE and BC, are equal to
these two lines CF and CB the one to the other, and the angle EBC is equal to
the angle FCB by supposition. Wherefore (by the 4. proposition) the base of the
one is equal to the base of the other, and the one triangle is equal to the
other triangle, and the other angles remaining are equal unto the other angles
remaining, the one to the other, under which are subtended equal sides^
Wherefore the base EC is equal to the base FB, and the angle BEC to the angle
CFB, and the angle CBF to the angle BCE. But the whole angle EBC is equal to
the whole angle FCB, of which the angle FBC is equa^l to the angle ECB^
wherefore the angle remaining EBF is equal to the angle remaining FCE. But the
line BE is ^quall to the line CF, and the line BF to the line CE, and they
contain equal angles: wherefore by the same fourth proposition the angle BEF
is equal to the angle CFE. Wherefore by this sixth proposition the side AE is
equal to the side AF^ o^ which B^ is equal to CF, by construction: wherefore
(by the third common sentence) the residue AB is equal to the residue AC
Wherefore the triangle ABC is an Isosceles triangle. If therefore the two sides
of a triangle being produced, the angles under the base be equal, the said
triangle shall be an Isosceles triangle: which was required to be proved.

This moreover is to be noted, that in this proposition there may be an other
case^ for in taking an equal line to AC from AB, An other case in this sixth
proposition.
you may take it from the point A and not from the point B. And yet though
this supposition also be put the self same absurdity will follow.

For suppose that AC be equal to AD: and produce the line CA to the point E:
and put the line AE equal to the line DB (by the third proposition) wherefore
the whole line CE is equal to the whole line AB (by the second common
sentence) Draw a line from the point E to the point B. And forasmuch as the
line AB is equal to the line EC, and the line BC is common to them both, and
the angle ACB is supposed to be equal to the angle ABC: Wherefore (by the
fourth proposition) the triangle EBC is equal to the triangle ABC, namelye,
the whole to the part: which is impossible.

The 4. Theoreme. The 7. Proposition. If from the ends of one line, be drawn
two right lines to any point: there can not from the self same ends on the
same side, be drawn two other lines equal to the two first lines, the one to
the other, unto any other point.
FOr if it be possible: then from the ends of one and the self same right
line, namely, AB, from the points (I say) A and B, let there be drawn two
right lines AC and CB to the point C: and from the same ends of the line AB,
let there be drawn two other right right lines AD and DB equal to the lines
AC and CB the one to the other, is, each to his correspondent line, and on one
and the same side, and to an other point, namely, to D: so that let CA be
equal to DA being both drawn from one end, that is, A: and let CB be equal
to DB, being both also drawn from one end, that is, B. And (by the first
peticion) draw a right line from the point C to the point D. Demonstration
le^^^n^ to an absurdity.
Now forasmuch as AC is equal to AD, the angle ACD also is (by the 5.
proposition) equal to the angle ADC: wherefore the angle ACD is less the^ the
angle BDC. Wherefore the angle BCD is much less then the angle BDC. Again
forasmuch as BC is equal to BD, and therefore also the angle BCD is equal to
the angle BDC. And it is proved that it is much less then it: which is
impossible. If therefore from the ends of one line, be drawn ^wo right lines
to any point: there can not from the self same ends on the same side, be
drawn two other lines equal to the two first lines, the one to the other,
unto any other point: Which was required to be demonstrated.

In this proposition the conclusion is a negation, which very rarely happens
in the mathematical arts. Negative conclu^sions rarely used in the
mathematical arts.
For they ever for the most part use to conclude affirmatively, and not
negatiuely. For a proposition universal affirmative is most agreeable to
sciences, as says Aristotle, and is of it self strong, and needs no negative
to his proof. But an universal proposition negative must of necessity have
to his proof an affirmative, For of only negative propositions there can be
no demonstrations. And therefore sciences using demonstration, conclude
affirmatively, and very seldom use negative conclusions.

An other demonstration after Campanus.
Suppose that there be a line AB, from whose ends A and B, let there be drawn
two lines AC and BC on one side, which let concur in the point C. Then I say
that on the same side there cannot be drawn two other lines, from the ends of
the line AB, which shall concur at any other point, so that that which is
drawn from the point A shall be equal to the line AC, and that which is
drawn from the point B shall be equal to the line BC. For if it be possible,
let there be drawn two other lines on the self same side, which let concur
in the point D, and let the line AD be equal to the line AC, and the line BD
equal to the line BC. Diverse cases in this demonstration.
Wherefore the point D shall fall either within the triangle ABC, or without.
For it cannot fall in one of the sides, for then a part should be equal to
his whole. If therefore it fall without^ then either one of the lines AD and DB
shall cut one of the lines AC and CB, or else neither shall cut neither. First
case.
First let one cut the other and draw a right line from C to D. Now forasmuch
as in the triangle ACD, the two sides AC and AD are equal, therefore the angle
ACD is equal to the angle ADC, by the fifth proposition: likewise forasmuch as
in the tria^gle BCD, the two sides BC and BD are equal, therefore by the same,
the angles BCD and BDC are also equal. And forasmuch as the angle BDC is
greter the^ the angle ADC, it follows that the angle BCD is greater then the
angle ACD, namely, the part greater then the whole: which is impossible.

But if the point D fall without the triangle ABC, Second case.
so that the lines cut not the one the other, draw a line from D to C. And
produce the lines BD and BC beyond the base CD, unto the points E and F. And
forasmuch as the lines AC and AD are equal, the angles ACD and ADC shall also
be equal, by the fifth proposition^ likewise for as much as the lines BC and BD
are equal, the angles under the base, namely, the angles FDC and ECD are
equal, by the second part of the same proposition. And for as much as the
angle ECD is less then the angle ACD: It follows that the angle FDC is less
the^ the angle ADC: which is impossible: for that the angle AD C is a part of
the angle FD C. And the same inconvenience will follow if the point D fall
within the triangle ABC,

The fifth Theoreme. The 8. Proposition. If two triangles have two sides of
the one equal to two sides of the other, each to his correspondent side, and
have also the base of the one equal to the base of the other: they shall have
also the angle contained under the equal right lines of the one, equal to the
angle contained under the equal right lines of the other.
SVppose that there be two triangles ABC and DEF: and let these two sides of
the one AB and AC, be equal to these two sides of the other DE, and DF, each to
his correspondent side, that is, AB to D E, and AC, to DF, and let the base of
the one, namely, BC be equal to the base of the other, namely, to OF. Then I
say, that the angle BAC is equal to the angle EDF. For the triangle ABC
exactly agreing with the triangle DE F, Demonstration leading to an
^mpossibility.
and the point B being put upon the point E, and the right line BC upon the
right line OF: the point C shall exactly agree with the point F (for the line
BC is equal to the line OF) And BC exactly agreeing with OF the lines also BA
and AC shall exactly agree with the lines ED and DF. For if the base BC do
exactly agree with the base FE, but the sides BA and AC do not exactly agree
with the sides ED and DF, but differ as FG and GF do: the^ from ye ends of one
line shall be drawn two right lines to a point, and from the self same ends on
the same side shall be drawn two other lines, equal to the two first lines, ye
one to the other, and unto an other point: but that is impossible, (by the
seventh proposition) Wherefore the base BC exactly agreeing with the base OF,
the sides also BA and AC do exactly agree with the sides ED and DF. Wherefore
also the angle BAC shall exactly agree with the angle EDF, and therefore shall also
be equal to it. If the^fore two triangles have two sides of the one equal to
two sides of the other, each to his correspondent side, and have also the base
of ye one equal to the base of the other: they shall have also the angle
contained under the equal right lines of the one, equal to the angle
contained under the equal right lines of the other: which was required to be
proved.

This proposition is the (...) of the ^ourth, b^t not the che^e^t kind of
conversion.
This Theoreme is the converse of the fourth, but it is not the chiefest and
principal kind o^ conversion. For it turns not the whole supposition into
the conclusion, and the whole conclusion into the supposition. For the fourth
proposition whose converse this is, is a co^pound ^heoreme, having two things
given or s^pposed, which are these: the one, that two sides of the one tria^gle
be equal to two sides of the other tria^gle: the other, that the angle contained
of the two sides of the one is equal to the angle contained of the two sides of
the one: but has amongst other one thing required, which is, that the base of
the one, is equal to the base of the other. Now in this 8. proposition, being
the converse therof^ that the base of the one is equal to the base of the other,
is the supposition, or the thing given: which in the former proposition was the
conclusion. And this, that two sides of the one are equal to two sides of the
other, is in this proposition also a supposition, like as it was in the former
proposition: so that it is a thing given in either proposition. The conclusion
of this proposition is that the angle enclosed of the two equal sides of the
one triangle is equal to the angle enclosed of the two equal sides of the
other triangle: which in the former proposition was one of the things given.

Philo and his scholas demonstrate this proposition without the help of the
former proposition, in this manner.

Suppose that there be two triangles ABC and DEF, having two sides of the one
equal to two sides of the other, namely, AB and AC equal to DE and D F, An
other demo^stration invented by Philo.
the one to the other, and the base BC equal to the base OF. And for that the
base BC is equal to the base E F, therefore the one being applied to the other
they agree. Place the two tria^gles ABC and D OF in one and the self same
plain superficies, and apply the base of the one to the base of the other: But
yet so that the tria^gle ABC be set one the other side of the right line OF,
that the top of the one may be opposite to the top of the other. And in stead
of the triangle ABC put the triangle EFG as in the figure. And let DE be equal
to EG, and DF to FG. After this demonstration three cases in this proposition.
Now then by this means shall happen diverse cases. For the line F G may fall
directly upon the line DF, or it may so fall that it may make with the line DF
an angle within the figure, or with out.

First let it fall directlye. The first case.
And forasmuch as the line DE is equal to the line E G, and DFG, is one
right line: therefore DEGREES is an Isosceles tria^gle: and so, by the fifth
proposition, the angle at the point D is equal to the angle at the point G:
which was required to be proved.

But if it fall not directly, but make with the line D F an angle within the
figure, draw a line from D to G. The second case.
Now forasmuch as ED and EG ^re equal, and the line DG is the base: therefore
by the fifth proposition, the angle EDG is equal to the angle EGD. Again
forasmuch as DF is equal to FG, and DG is the base: therefore by the same, the
angle FDG is equal to the FGD: and it was proved that the angle EDG is equal
to the angle EGD^ wherefore the whole angle EDF is equal to the whole angle FGE:
which was required to be proved.

But if the line FG make with the line DF an angle without the figure: The
third case.
draw a right line without the figure from the point D to the point G. And
forasmuch as DE and EG are equal, and DG is the base, therefore by the fifth
proposition, the angles EDG and DGE are equal. Again forasmuch as DF is
equal to FG, and DG is the base, therefore, by the same, the angle FDG is
equal to the angle FGD. And it was proved that the whole angles EDG and DGE
are equal the one to the other: wherefore the angles remaining EDF and EGF are
equal the one to the other, which was required to be proved.

The 4. Problem. The 9. Proposition. To divide a rectiline angle given, into
two equal parts.
SVppose that the rectiline angle given be BAC. It is required to divide the
angle BAC into two equal parts. Construction.
In the line AB take a point at all adventures, and let the same be D. And (by
the third proposition) from the line AC cut of the line AE equal to AD. And
(by the first peticion) draw a right line from the point D to the point E. And
(by the first proposition) upon the line DE describe an equilater triangle and
let the same be DFE, and (by the first peticion) draw a right line from the
point A to the point F. Then I say that the angle BAC is by ye line AF divided
into two equal parts. Demonstration.
For, forasmuch as AD is equal to AE, and AF is common to them both: therefore
these two DA and AF, are equal to these two EA and AF, the one to the other.
But (by the first proposition) the base DF is equal to the base OF: wherefore
(by the 8. proposition) the angle DAF is equal to the angle FAE. Wherefore the
rectiline angle given, namely, B AC is divided into two equal parts by the
right line AF^ Which was required to be done.

In this proposition is not taught to divide a right lined angle into mo parts
then two: albeit to divide an angle, so it be a right angle, into three parts,
it is not hard. And it is taught of Vi^ellio in his first book of Perspectiue,
It is impossible to divide an acute rectiline angle into three equal parts
without the help of lines which are of a mixed nature.
the 28. Proposition. ^or to divide an acute angle into three equal parts, is
(as says Proclus) impossible: unless it be by the help of other lines which
are of a mixed nature. Which thing Nicomedes did by such lines which are called
Concoide^ linea, who first serched out the invention, nature, and properties of
such lines. And others did it by other means as by the help of quadrant lines
invented by Hippias and Nicomedes. Others by Helices or Spiral lines invented
of Archimedes. But these are things of much difficulty and hardness, and not
here to be entreated of.

Here against this proposition may of the adversary be brought an An instance
is an objection or a doubt, whereby is let or troubled the construction, or
demonstration, and contains an vnruth, and an impossibility: and therefore it
must of necessity be answered unto, and the falsehode thereof made manifest.
instance. For he may cavil that the head of the equilater triangle shall not
fall between the two right lines, but in one of them, or without them both. As
for example.

Suppose that the angle to be divided into two equal parts be BAC, and in the
line BA take the point D, and unto the line DA put the line AE equal (by the
third proposition.) And draw a line from D to E. And upon the line DE describe
(by the first) an equilater triangle, which let be DFE. Now then if it be
possible that the point F do not fall between the lines AB and AC, then it shall
fall either in the line AB or AC, or without them both. Suppose that the point F
be fall upon line AB, so that let DFE be an equilater triangle. Wherefore the
line DF is equal to the line FE: and the angles at the base are equal, namely,
the angles EDF and DEF. Wherefore the whole angle DEC is greater then the angle
EDF. Again forasmuch as AD is equal to AE, therefore ADE is an Isosceles
triangle. Wherefore (by the fifth proposition) the angles under the base are
equal. Wherefore the angle DEC is equal to the angle EDB. But it was also
greater: which is impossible. Wherefore the top of the equilater triangle cannot
be in the right line AB. And in like sort also may we prove that it cannot be
in the right line AC. Wherefore suppose that it be without them both, if it be
possible. And forasmuch as DF is equal to FE, the angles at the base are equal,
namely, the angles DEF and EDF. Wherefore the angle DEF is greater then the
angle EDF. Wherefore the angle DEC is much greater then the angle EDF. But it is
also equal unto it. For they are angles under the base DE of the Isosceles
triangle AD E. Which is impossib^e. Wherefore the point F shall not fall without
the two right lines on that side. And in like sort may we prove that it shall
not fall without them on the other side. Wherefore it shall of necessity fall
between them: which was required to be proved.

There may also in this proposition be diverse cases^ Diverse cases in this
proposition.
^f it so happen that there be no space under the base DE to describe an
equilater triangle, but that of necessity you must describe it on the same
side that the lines AB and AC are. For then the sides of the equilater triangle
either exactly agree with the lines AD and AE, if the said lines AD and AE be
equal with the base DE. Or they fall without them, if the lines AD and AE be
less then the base DE. Or they fall within them, if the said lines be greater
the^ the base DE.

First let them exactly agree^ And let DAE be an equilater triangle. The first
case.
And in the side AD take the point G. And from the side AE cut of a line equal
to the line AG (by the third proposition) which let be AH^ And draw these right
lines GE, HD and GH, and AF. Now forasmuch as AD is equal to AE and AG unto AH^
therefore these two lines DA and AH are equal to these two lines EA and AG: and
they contain one and the self same angle, Wherefore by the fourth proposition,
the angle GDH is equal to the angle HEG. And the base DH is equal to the base
EG. But the line DG is equal to the line EH: wherefore again by the fourth
proposition, the angle EGH is equal to the angle DHG. Wherefore by the sixth
proposition, the base GF is equal to the base HF. And forasmuch as AH is equal
to AG, and AF is common to the^ both, and the base GF is equal to the base HF,
therefore the angle GAF is equal to the angle HAF. Wherefore the angle GAH is
divided into two equal parts: which was required to be done.

The second case.
But if the sides of the equilater triangle fall without the right lines BA and
AC, as do the lines D^ and OF, the^ draw a line from F to A and produce the
line FA to the point G. Now forasmuch as the lines DF and FE are equal, and the
line FA is common to them both, and the bases DA and AE are equal: therefore
(by the eight) the angle DFA is equal to the angle EFA. Again forasmuch as DF
and FE are equal, and FG is common to them both, and they contain equal
angles (as it has been proved) therefore (by the fourth) the base DG is equal
to the base GE. And forasmuch as AD is equal to AE, and AG is common to them
both. Therefore (by the eight) the angle DAG is equal to the angle EAG.
wherefore the angle DAE is divided into two equal parts: Which was required
to be done.

But if the sides of the equilater triangle fall within the right lines BA and
AC, The third case.
as do the lines DF and FE, then again draw a line from A to F. And forasmuch
as DA is equal to AE, and AF is common to them both, and the base DF is equal
to the b^se FE: therefore the angle DAF is (by the eight) equal to the angle
^AF. Wherefore the angle at the point A is divided into two equal parts, how
soever the equilater triangle be placed: which was required to be done.

This is to be noted, that if a man will mechanically or readily, To devide a
(...) angle (...) equal (...).
not regardyng demonstration, divide the foresaid rectiline angle BAC, and so
any other rectiline angle given whatsoeuer^ into two equal parts, he shall
need only with one opening of the compass taken at all adventures to mark
the two points D and E, which cut of equal parts of the lines AB and AC,
howsoever they happen, and so making the centres the two points D and E, to
describe two circles according to the openyng of the compa^^e: and from the
point A to their intersection, which let be the point F to draw a right line:
which shall divide the angle BAC into two equal parts. And here note, that
you shall not need to draw the circles all whole, but one, ly a portion where
they cut the one the other: As in the figure here in the end of the other side
put.

The 5. Problem. The 10. Proposition. To divide a right line given being
finite, into two equal parts.
SVppose that the right line given be AB. It is required to divide the line AB
into two equal parts. Construction.
Describe (by the first proposition) upon the line AB an equilater triangle and
let the same be ABC. And (by the former proposition) divide the angle ACB into
two equal parts by the right line CD. Then I say that the right line AB is
divided into two equal parts in the point D. Demonstration.
For forasmuch as (by the first proposition) AC is equal to CB, and CD is
common to the^ both: therefore these two lines AC and CD are equal to these two
lines BC and CD, ye one to ye other, and the angle ACD is equal to the angle
BCD. Wherefore (by the 4. proposition) the base AD is equal to the base BD.
Wherefore the right line given AB, is divided into two equal parts in the
point D: which was required to be done.

Apollonius ^eacheth to divide a right line being finite into two equal parts
after this manner. An other way to divide a right line being finis^, inverted
by Apollonius.


Suppose that the right line being finite be AB: which it is required to divide
in to two equal parts. Now the^ making the center the point A and the space AB
describe a circle. Again making the center the point B and the space BA
describe an other circle: and from the common sections draw the right line CD,
which let cut the line AB in the point E. Then I say, that the right line CD
deuideth the line AB into two equal parts in the point E. For draw these
right lines D A, DBCA and CB. Which shall be equal the one to the other, for
that they are drawn from the centres to the circumferences of equal circles.
And forasmuch as the lines CA and AD are equal to the lines CB and BD, and the
line CD is common to either of them: therefore, by the eight, the angle ACD is
equal to the angle BCD. Again forasmuch as the line CE is common to the lines
AC and CB, which are equal the one to the other, therefore these two lines AC
and CE are equal to these two lines BC and CE, the one to the other, and they
contain equal angles, as it has been proved. Wherefore by the 4. proposition
the base AE is equal to the base BE. Wherefore the line AB is divided into two
equal parts in the point E: which was required to be done.

By this way of dividing a right line, into two equal parts invented by
Apollonius, it is manifest, that if a man will mechanically, or redely, not
considering the demonstration, divide the said rightline, and so any right line
given whatsoever, into two equal: parts he need only to mark the points of
the intersections of the circles, and to draw a line from the said
intersections, which shall divide the right line given into two equal parts:
as in the figure here put.

The 6. Problem. The 11. Proposition. Upon a right line given, to raise up
from a point given in the same line a perpendicular line.
SVppose that the right line given be AB, and let the point in it given be C.
It is required from the point C to raise up unto the right line AB a
perpendicular line. Take in the line AC a point at all adventures, Construction.
and let the same be D, and (by the 3. proposition) put unto DC an equal line
CE. And by the first proposition) upon the line DE describe an equilater
triangle FDE, and draw a line from F to C. Then I say that unto the right line
given AB, and from the point in it given, namely, C is raised up a
perpendicular line FC. For forasmuch as DC is equal to CE, Demonstration.
and the line CF is common to them both: therefore these two DC and CF, are
equal to these two EC and CF, the one to the other: and (by the first
proposition) the base DF is equal to the base OF: wherefore (by the 8.
proposition) the angle DCF is equal to the angle ECF: and they be side angles.
But when a right line standing upon a right line does make the two side angles
equal the one to the other, either of those equal angles is (by the. 10.
definition) a right angle: and the line standing upon the right line is called
a perpe^dicular line. Wherefore the angle DCF, and thangle FCE are right
angles. Wherefore unto the right line given AB, and from the point in it C, is
raised up a perpendicular line CF: which was required to be done.

Although the point given should be set in one of the ends of the right line
given, it is easy so do it as it was before. For producing the line in length
from the point by the second peticion, you may work as you did before. But if
one require to erect a right line perpendicularly from the point at the end of
the line, without producing the rightlyne, that also may well be done after
this manner.

Suppose that the right line given be AB, and let the point in it given be in
one of the ends thereof, An other case in this proposition.
namely, in A. And take in the line AB a point at all adventures, Construction.
and let the same be C. And from the said point raise up (by the foresaid
proposition) unto AB a perpendiculer line, which let ^e OE. And (by the 3.
proposition) from the line CE cut of the line CD equal to the line CA, And (by
the 9. Proposition) divide the angle ACD into two equal parts by the line CF.
And from the point D raise up unto the line CE a perpe^diculer line, DF, which
let concur with the line CF in the point F. And draw a right line from F to
A. Then I say that the angle at the point A is a right angle. For, forasmuch as
DC is equal to CA, Demonstration.
and CF is common to them both, and they contain ^quall angles (for the angle
at the point C is divided into two equal parts) therefore (by the 4.
Proposition) the line DF is equal to the line FA, and so the angle at the
point A is equal to the angle at the point D. But the angle at the point D is a
right angle. Wherefore also the angle at the point A is a right angle. Wherefore
from the point A unto the line AB, is raised up a perpendiculer line AF,
without producing the line AB. Which was required to be done.

Appollonius teaches to raise up unto a line given, from a point in it given,
a perpendiculer line, after this manner. An other way to erect a perpe^dicular
line invented by Appolonius.

Construction^.




Suppose that the right line given be AB. And let the point in it given, be C.
And in the line AC, take a point at all adue^tures, and let the same be D. And
from the line CB, cut of a line equal to the line CD, which let be CE^ and
making the center D, and the space DE, describe a circle. And again making the
center C, and the space ED, describe an other circle, and let the point of
their intersection be F. And draw a right line from F to C. Then I say that the
line FC is erected perpendiculerly unto the line AB. For draw these lin^s ED
and FE: which shall by the definition of a circl^ be either of them equal to the
line DE. Demonstration.
and therefore (by the first common sentence) are equal the one to the other.
But the lines DC and CE are by construction equal, and the line FC is common
to them both. Wherefore the angles also at the point C are equal (by the 8.
proposition:) wherefore they are right angles. Wherefore the (...) CE is erected
perpendiculerly unto the line AB from the point C^ which was required to be
done.

By this way of erecting a perpendiculer line invented by Appollonius, How to
erect a perpendicular line mechanically.
it is also manifest, that if a man will mechanically, without d^monstration,
erect unto a line given from a point given in it a perpendiculer line: he need
only on either side of the point given, to cut of equal lines: and so making
either of the ends of the said lines (either of th'endes I say, which have not
one point common to them both) the centres, and the space both the lines added
together, or wider then both, or at the lest wider the^ one of them, to
describe those portions of the circles where they cut the one the other, and
from the point of the intersection to the point given, to draw a line, which
shall be perpendicular unto the line given: as in the figure here put it is
manifest to see.

The 7. Problem. The 12. Proposition. Unto a right line given being infinite,
and from a point given not being in the same line, to draw a perpendicular line.
LEt the right line given being infinite be AB, and let ye point given not
being in the said line AB, be C. It is required from the point given, namely,
C, to draw unto the right line given AB, a perpendiculer line. Construction.
Take on the other side of the line AB (namely, on that side wherein is not the
point C) a point at all adventures, and let the same be D. And making the
center C, and the space CD, describe (by the third peticion) a circle, and let
the same be EFG, which let cut the line AB in the points E and G. And (by
the x. proposition) divide the line EG into two equal parts in the point H.
And (by the first peticion) draw these right lines, CG, CH, and CE. Then I say,
that unto the right line given AB, and from the point given not being in it,
namely, C, is drawn a perpendiculer line CHAPTER Demonstration.
For forasmuch as GH is equal to HE, and HC is common to them both; therefore
these two sides GH and HC, are equal to these two sides EH and HC, the one to
the other^ and (by the 15 definition) the base CG is equal to the base CE:
wherefore (by the 8. proposition) the angle CHG is equal to the angle CHE: and
they are side angles: but when a right line standing upon a right line makes
the two side angles equal the one to the other, either of those equal angles
is (by the 10. definition) a right angle, and the line standing upon the said
right line is called a perpendiculer line. Wherefore unto the right line given
AB, and from the point given C, which is not in the line AB, is drawn a
perpendiculer line CH: which was required to be done.

This Problem did Oen^pides first find out, Oenopides the first inuenter of
this problem.
considering the necessary use thereof to the study of Astronomy.

There ar^ two kinds of perpendiculer lines: Two kinds of perpendiculer
lines, namely, a plain perpendiculer line and a solid.
whereof one is a plain perpendiculer line, the other is a solid. A plain
perpendiculer line is, when the point from whence the perpendi^uler line i^
dra^en, is in the same plain superficies with the line whereunto it is a
perpendicular. A solid perpendiculer line is, when the point, from whence the
perpendiculer is drawn, is on high, and without the plain superficies. So
that a plain perpendiculer line is drawn to a right line: and a solid
perpendiculer line is drawn to a superficies. A plain^ perpendiculer line
causes right angles with one only line, namely, with that upon whom it
falls. But a solid perpendiculer line causes right an^le^, not only with
one line, but with as many lines as may be drawn in that superficies, by the
touch thereof. This proposition teaches to draw a plain perpendiculer line.
This proposition teaches to draw a plain perpendiculer line, for it is drawn
to one line, and supposed to be in the self same plain superficies.

There may be in this proposition an other case. An other case in this
proposition.
For if it be so, that on the other side of the line AB, there be no space to
take a point in but only on that side wherein is the point C. Construction^
Then take some certain point in the line AB, which let be D. And making the
center the point C, and the space CD, describe a part of the circumference of a
circle, which let be DEF: which let cut the line AB in the two points D and F.
And divide the line DF into two equal parts in the point H. And draw these
lines CD, CH and CF. And forasmuch as DH is equal to HF, Demonstration.
and CH is common to them both, and CD is equal to CF (by the 15. definition:)
therefore the angles at the point H are equal the one to the other (by the 8.
proposition:) and they are side angles, wherefore they are right angles.
Wherefore the line CH is a perpendiculer to the line DF. But if it happen so
that the circle which is described do not cut the line, but touch it, then
taking a point without the point E, namely, the point G, and making the center
the point C, and the space CG, describe a part of the circumference of a
circle: which shall of necessity cut the line AB: and so may you proceed as
you did before. As you see in the second figure.

The 6. Theoreme. The 13. Proposition. When a right line standing upon a right
line makes any angles: those angles shall be either two right angles, or
equal to two right angles.
SVppose that the right line AB standing upon the right line CD do make these
angles CBA and ABD. Then I say, that the angles CBA and ABD are either two
right angles, or its ^quall to two right angles. If the angle CBA be equal to
the angle ABD: then are they two right angles (by the tenth difinition.
Construction,
) But if not, raise up (by the 11. proposition) unto the right line CD, and
from the point given in it, namely^ Demonstration
B, a perpendiculer line BE^ Wherefore (by the x. definition) the angle CBE and
EBD ar^ right angles. Now forasmuch as the angle CBE, is equal to these two
angles CBA and ABE, put the angle EBD common to them both^ wherefore the angles
CBE and EBD, are equal to these three angles CBA, ABE, and EBD. Again
forasmuch as the angle DBA is equal unto these two angles DBE and EBA, put the
angle ABC common to them both: wherefore the angles DBA and ABC, are equal to
these three angles, DBE, EBA, and ABC. And it is proved that the angles CBE and
EBD are equal to the self same three angles: but things equal to one and the
self same things are also (by the first common sentence) equal the o^e to the
oath. Wherefore the angles CBE and EBD are equal to the angles DBA and ABC.
But the angles CBE and EBD are two right angles: wherefore also the angles DBA
and ABC are equal to two right angles. Wherefore when a right line standing
upon a right line makes any angles: those angles shall be either two right
angles, or equal to two right angles: which was required to be demonstrated.

An other demonstration after Pelitarius.
Suppose that the right line AB do stand upon the right line CD. Then I say,
that the two angles ABC and ABD, An other demonstration after Peli^^riu^.
are either two right angles, or equal to two right angles. For if AB be
perpe^diculer unto CD: the^ is it manifest, that they are right angles (by the
conversion of the definition) But if it incline toward the end C, then (by
the 11. proposition) from the point B, erect unto the line CD a perpendicul^r
line BE. By which construction the proposition is very manifest. For forasmuch
as the angle ABD is gre^ter then the right angle DBE by the angle ABE^ and the
other angle ABC is less then the right angle CBE by the self same angle ABE:
if from the great^r b^e taken away the excess, and the same be added to the
less, they shall be made two right angles. That is, if from the obtuse angle
ABD be taken away the angl^ ABE, there shall remain the right angle DBE. And
then if the same angle ABE be added to the ^cute angle CBA, there shall be
made the right angle CBE. Wherefore it is manifest, that the two angles,
namely, the obtuse angle ABD, and the acute angle ABC, are equal to the two
right angles CBE and DBE: which was requ^red to be proved.

The 7. Theoreme. The 14. Proposition. If unto a right line, and to a point in
the same line, be drawn two right lines, no^ both on one and the same side,
making the side angles equal to two right angles: those two right lines shall
make directly one right line.
Unto the right line AB, and to y^ point in it B^ let ther^ be drawn two right
lines BC, and BD, unto contrary sides, making the side angles, namely, ABC and
ABD, equal to two right angles. Then I say, that ye right lines BD and BC make
both one right line. Demonstration leading to an absurdit^e.
For if CB and BD do not make both one right line, let the right line BE be so
drawn to BC, that they both make one right line. Now forasmuch as the right
line AB stands upon the right line CBE, therefore the angles ABC and ABE are
equal to two right angles (by the 13. proposition) But (by supposition) the
angles ABC and ABD are equal to two right angles: wherefore the angles CBA, and
ABE, are equal to the angles CBA, and ABD: take away the angle ABC, which is
common to them both. Wherefore the angle remaining ABE, is equal to the angle
remaining ABD, namely, the less to the greater, which is impossible.
Wherefore the line BE is not so directly drawn to BC, that they both make one
right line. In like sort may we prove, that no other line, besides BD, can so
be drawne^ Wherefore the lines CB and BD, make both one right line. If therefore
unto a right line, and to a point in the same line, be drawn two right lines,
not both on one and the same side, making the side angles equal to two right
angles: those two lines shall make directly one right line: which was required
to be proved.

An other demonstration after Pelitarius.
Suppose that there be a right line AB, unto whose poi^te ^, An other
demonstration after Pelitarius.
let there be drawn two right lines CB and BD, unto contrary sides: and let
the two angles CBA, and DBA, be either two right angles, or equal to two right
angles. Then I say, that the two lines CB and BD, do make directly one right
line, namely, CD. For if they do not, the^ let ^E b^ ^o d^awn unto CB, that
they both make directly one right line C^^: which shall pass ^ither above the
line BD, or under it. First let it pass above it. And for a^ much as the two
angles CBA and ABE, are (by the former proposition) equal to two right angles,
and are a part of the two angles, CBA and ABD: but the angles CBA and AND a^e
by (supposition) equal also to two right angles^ therefore the par^^ is equal
to the whole which is im^ossible. And the like absurdity will follow if CB E
pass under the line BD: namely, that the whole shall be equal to the part^
which is also impossible. Wherefore CD is one right line: which was required to
be proved.

The 8. Theoreme. The 15. Proposition. If two right lines cut the one the
other: the head angles shall be equal the one to the other.
SVppose that these two right lines AB and CD, do cut the one the other in the
point E. Then I say, that the angle AEC, is equal to the angle DEB.
Demonstration.
For forasmuch as the right line AE, stands upon the right line DC, making
these angles CEA, and AED: therefore (by the 13. proposition) the angles CEA,
and AED, are equal to two right angles. Again forasmuch as the right line DE,
stands upon the right line AB, making these angles AED, and DEB: therefore (by
the same proposition) the angles AED, and DEB, are equal to two right angles:
and it is proved, that the angles CEA, and AED, are also equal to two right
angles. Wherefore the angles CEA, and AED, are equal to the angles AED, and
DEB. Take away the angle AED, which is common to them both. Wherefore the
angle remaining CEA, is equal to the angle remaining DEB. And in like sort may
it be proved, that the angles CEB, and DEA, are equal the one to the other. If
therefore two right lines cut the one the other, the head angles shall be equal
the one to the other: which was required to be demonstrated.

Thales Milesius the first inuent^r of this proposition.
Thales Milesius the Philosopher was the first inuenter of this Proposition, as
witnesses Eudemius, but yet it was first demonstrated by Euclide. And in it
there is no construction at all. No construction in this proposition.
For the exposition of the thing given, is sufficient enough for the
demonstration.

Head Angles, What head angles are.
are apposite angles, caused of the intersection of two right lines: and are so
called, because the heddes of the two angles are joined together in one point.

The converse of this proposition after Pelitarius.
The converse of this propositio after Pelitarius.
If four right lines being drawn from one point, do make four angles, of
which the two opposite angles are equal: the two opposite lines shall be drawn
directly, and make one right line.

Suppose that there be four right lines AB, AC, AD, and AE, drawn from the
point A, making four angles at the point A: of which let the angle BAC be
equal to the angle DAE, and the angle BAD to the angle CAE. Then I say, that
BE and CD are only two right lines: that is, the two right lines BA and AE are
drawn directly, and do make one right line, and likewise the two right lines
CA and AD are drawn directly, and do make one right line. For otherwise if it
be possible, Demonstration leading to an absurdity.
let OF be one right line, and likewise let CG be one right line. And forasmuch
as the right line EA stands upon the right line CG, therefore the two angles
EAC and EAG, are (by the 13 proposition) equal to two right angles. And
forasmuch as the right line B A stands upon the right line OF: therefore (by
the self same) the two angles EAG and FAG are also equal to two right angles.
Wherefore taking away the angle EAG, which is common to them both, the angle
EAC, shall (by the third common sentence) be equal to the angle FAG: but the
angle EAC is supposed to be equal to the angle BAD. Wherefore the angle BAD is
equal to the angle FAG, namely a part to the whole: which is impossible. And
the self same absurdity will follow, on what side soever the lines be drawn.
Wherefore BE is one line, and CD also is oue line: which was required to be
proved.

The same converse after Proclus.
If unto a right line, and to a point thereof be drawn two right lines, not on
one and the same side, in such sort that they make the angles at the top
equal: The same converse after Pelitarius, which is demonstrated directly.
those right lines shall be drawn directly one to the other, and shall make one
right line.

Suppose that there be a right line AB, and take a point in in C. And unto the
point in it C, draw these two right lines CD and CE unto contrary sides, making
the angles at the head equal, namely, the angles ACD and BCE. Then I say, that
the lines CD and CE are drawn directly, and do make one right line. For
forasmuch as the right line CD standing upon the right line AB, does make the
angles DCA and DCB equal to two right angles (by the 13 proposition:) and the
angle DCA is equal to the angle BCE: therefore the angles DCB and BCE are
equal to two right angles. And forasmuch as unto a certain right line BC, and
to a point thereof C, are drawn two right lines not both on one and the same
side, making the side angles equal to two right angles, therefore (by the 14
proposition) the lines CD and CE are drawn directly, and do make one right
line, which was required to be proved.

The same may also be demonstrated by an argument leading to an absurdity. The
same converse after Proclus demonstrated indirectly.
For if CE be not drawn directly to CD, so that they both make one right line,
then (if it be possible) let CF be drawn directly unto it. So that let DCF
be one right line. And forasmuch as the tw^ right lines AB and DF do cut the
one the other, they make the head angles equal (by the 15. proposition)
Wher^fore the angles ACD and BCF are equal: but (by supposition) the angles
ACD and BCE are also equal. Wherefore (by the first common sentence) the angle
BCE is equal to the angle BCF: namely, the greater to the less: which is
impossible. Wherefore no other right line besides CE is drawn directly to CD.
Wherefore the lines, CD and CE are (...), and make one right line: which was
required to be proved.

What a Corrollary is.
Of this fiuetenth Proposition follows a Corrollary. Where note that a
Corollary is a Proposition, whose demonstration depends of the demonstration
of an other Proposition, and it appears suddenly, as it were by chance
offering it self unto us: and therefore is reckoned as lucre or gain. The
Corollary which follows of this proposition, is thus.

A Corollary following of this proposition.
If four right lines cut the one the other: they make four angles equal to
four right angles.

This Corollary gave great occasion to find out that wonderful proposition
invented of Pithagoras, which is thus.

A wonderful proposition invented by P^^hagoras.
Only three kinds of figures of many angles, namely, an equilater triangle, a
right angled figure of four sides, and a figure of six sides, having equal
sides and equal angles, can fill the whole space about a point, their angles
touching the same point.

Every angle o^ an equilater triangle i^ equal ^o ^wo ^hird par^^^ of a right
angle
Every angle of an equilater triangle contains two third parts of a right
angle: six times two thirdes of a right angle make four right angles.
Wherefore six equilater triangles fill the whole space about a point which is
equal to four right angles, as in the 1. figure. Also every angle of a
rectangle quadrilater figure is a right angle: wherefore four of them fill the
whole space as in the 2. figure. Every angle of a six angled figure is equal
to a right angle, Every angle of a si^e angled figu^e i^ equal to a right
angle, and to a third part of a right angle.
and moreover to a third part of a right angle. But a right angle, and a third
part of a right angle, taken three times, make 4. right angles: wherefore three
equilater six angled figures fill the whole space about a point: which space
(by this Corrollary) is equal to four right angles: as in the third figure.
Any other figure of many sid^, howsoever you join the^ together at the angles,
shall either want of four angles, or exceed them. By this Corrollary also it
is mani^est that if mo then two lines, that is, three, or four, or how many
soever do cut the one the other in one point, all the angles by them made at
the point shall be equal to four right angles. For they fill the place of four
right angles. And it is also many sest, that the angles by those right lines
made are double in number to the right lines which cut the one the other. So
that if there b^ two lines which cut the one the other, the^ are there made
four angles equal to four right angles: but if three, then are there made
six angles: if four, eight angles, and so infinitely. Forever the mul^itude,
or number of of the angles is dubled to the multitude of the ^igh^ lines which
cut the one the other. And as the angles increase in multitude, so diminish
they in magnitude. For that that which is divided is always one and the self
same thing, namely, four right angles.

The 9. Theoreme. The 16. Proposition. Whenever in any triangle, the line of
one side is drawn forth in length: the outward angle shall be greater then
any one of the two inward and opposite angles.
SVppose that ABC be a triangle: and let one of ye sides thereof, namely, BC be
produced unto the point D. Then I say, that the outward angle ACD, is greater
then any one of ye two inward and opposite angles, that is, then the angle CBA,
Cons^ru^^ion.
or then the angle BAC. Divide the line AC (by the 10. proposition) into two
equal parts, in the point E. And draw a line from the point B to the point E.
And (by the 2. peticion) extend BE to the point F. And (by the 2. proposition)
unto the line BE put an equal line OF. And (by the first peticion) draw a line
from F to C: and (by the 2. peticion) extend the line AC to the point G.
Demonstration.
Now forasmuch as the line AE, is equal to the line EC, and BE is equal to
OF. therefore these two sides AE and EB, are equal to these two sides CE and
OF, the one to the other: and the angle AEB, is (by the 15. proposition) equal
to the angle FEC, for they are head angles: wherefore (by the 4. proposition)
the base AB is equal to the base FC: And the triangle ABE is equal to the
triangle FEC: and the other angles remaining are equal to the other angles
remaining, the one to the other, under which are subtended equal sides.
Wherefore the angle BAE is equal to the angle ECF. But the angle ECD is
greater then the angle ECF. Wherefore the angle ACD, is greater then the angle
BAC. In like sort also if the line BC be divided into two equal parts, may it
be pro^ed, that the angle BCG, that is, the angle ACD, is greater then the
angle ABC. Whensoever therefore in any triangle, the line of one side is drawn
forth in length: the ou^ward angle shall be greater then any one of the two
inward and opposite angles: which was required to be demonstrated.

An other demonstration after Pelitarius.
Suppose that the triangle given be ABC. An other Demonstration after
Pelitarius.
Whose side AB let be produced unto the point D. Then I say, that the angle DBC
is greater then either of the angles BAC and ACB. For forasmuch as the two
lines AC and BC do concur in the point C, and upon them falls the line AB:
therefore (by the converse of the first peticion) the two inward angles on one
and the self same side, are less then two right angles. Wherefore the angles
ABC and CAB are less then two right angles: but the angles ABC and DBC are (by
the 13 proposition) equal to two right angles. Wherefore the two angles ABC and
DBC are greater then the two angles ABC and BAC. Wherefore taking away the
angle ABC, which is common to them both, there shall be left the angle DBC
greater then the angle BAC. And by the same reason, forasmuch as the two lines
BA and CA concur in the point A, and upon them falls the right line CB,
the two inward angles ABC and ACB are less then two right angles. But the
angles ABC and DBC are equal to two right angles. Wherefore the two angles ABC
and DBC, are greater then the two angles ABC and ACB. Wherefore taking away the
angle ABC, which is common to them both, there shall remain the angle DBC
greater then the angle ACB: which was required to be proved.

Here is to be noted, that when the side of a triangle is drawn forth, the
angle of the triangle which is next the outwa^d angle, is called an angle in
order unto it: and the other two angles of the triangle are called opposite
angles unto it.

A Corrollary following of this proposition.
Of this Proposition follows this Corrollary, that it is not possible that
from one and the self same point should be drawn to one and the self same
right line, three equal right lines. For from one point, namely, A, if it be
possible, let there be drawn unto the right line BD, these three equal right
lines AB, AC, and AD. And forasmuch as AB is equal to AC, the angles at the
base are (by the fifth proposition) equal. Wherefore the angle ABC is equal to
the angle ACB. Again forasmuch as AB is equal to AD, the angle ABD is (by the
same) equal to the angle ADB: but the angle ABC was equal to the angle ACB.
Wherefore the angle ACB is equal to the angle ADB: namely, the outward angle
to the inward and opposite angle: which is impossible. Wherefore from one and
the self same point, can not be drawn to one and the self same right line
three equal right lines: which was required to be proved.

An other Corrollary ^ollowing also of the same.
By this Proposition also may this be demonstrated, that if a right line falling
upon two right lines, do make the outward angle equal to the inward and
opposite angle, those right lines shall not make a triangle, neither shall they
concur. For otherwis^ one and the self same angle should be both greater,
and also equal: which is impossible. As for example.

Suppose that there be two right lines AB and CD, and upon them let the right
line BE fall, making the angles ABD and CDE equal. Then I say, that the right
lines AB and CD shall not concur. For if they concur, the foresaid angles
abidyng equal, namely, the angles CDE and ABD: Then forasmuch as the angle CDE
is the outward angle it is of necessity greater then the inward and opposite
angle, and it is also equal unto it: which is impossible. Wherefore if the said
lines co^curre, the^ shall not the angles remain equal, but the angle at the
point D shall be increased. For whether AB abiding fixed you suppose the line
CD to be moved unto it, so that they concur, the space and distance in the
angle will be greater: for how much more CD approaches to AB, so much farther
of goes it from DE. Or whether CD abiding fixed, you imagine the line AB to be
moved unto i^, so that they concur, the angle ABD will be less, for
therewith all it comm^th nere unto the lines CD and BD. Or whether you imagine
either of them to be moved the one to the other, you shall find that the line
AB coming near to CD, makes the angle ABE less, and CD going farther from
DE by reason of his motion to the line BD^ makes the angle CDE to increase.
Wherefore it follows of necessity, that if it be a triangle, and that the
right lines AB and CD do conc^rre, the outward angle also shall be greater^
then the inward and opposite angle. For either the inward and opposite angle
abiding fixed, the outward i^ increased: or the outward abiding fixed, the
inward and opposi^^ is diminished^ or else both of them being moved till they
concur, the inward is diminished, and the outward is more increased. And
the caus^ hereof is the motion of the right lines the one tending to that part
where it diminishes the inward angle, the other tending to that part where it
increases the outward angle.

The 10. Theoreme. The 17. Proposition. In every triangle, two angles, which
two soever be taken, are less then two right angles.
SVppose that ABC be a triangle. Then I say that two angles of the said
triangle ABC, which two angles soever be taken, are less the^ two right angles
Extend (by the 2. peticio^) the line BC, Construction.
to the point D. Demonstration.
And forasmuch as (by the proposition going before) the outward angle of the
triangle ABC, namely, the angle ACD is greater then the inward and opposite
angle ABC: put the angle ACB common to them both: wherefore the angles ACD and
ACB are greater then the angles ABC and BCA. But (by the 13 proposition) the
angles ACD and ACB are equal to two right angles. Wherefore the angles ABC
and BCA are less then two right angles. In like sort also may we prove, that
the angles BAC and ACB are less then two right angles^ and also that the
angles CAB and ABC are less then two right angles. Wherefore in every
triangle, two angles, which two soever be taken, are less then two right
angles: which was required to be proved.

This may also be demonstrated without the help of the former propo^ition, by
the converse of the fifth petition, and by the 13. proposition as you saw was
done in the former after Politarius.

It may also be demonstrated without producing any of the sides of the
triangle, after this manner.

An other demo^stration inuen^ed by Proclus.
Suppose that there a be triangle ABC. And in the side BC take a point at all
adventures, and let the same be D, and draw the line AD. And forasmuch as in
the triangle ABD, the side BD is produced, therefore (by the former
proposition) the outward angle ADC, is greater then the inward and opposite
angle ABD. Again forasmuch as in the triangle ADC, the side CD is produced,
therefore (by the same) the outward angle ADB, is greater then the inward and
opposite angle ACD: but the angles at the point D are equal to two right
angles (by the 13. proposition:) wherefore the angles ABC and ACB are less then
two right angles. And by the same reason may we prove that the angles BAC and
BCA are less then two right angles, if we take a point in the line AC, and
draw a right line from it to the point B: and so also may it be proved that the
angles CAB and ABC are less the two right angles, if there be taken in the
line AB a point, and from it be a line drawn to the point C.

A Corrollary fo^l^wi^g this Proposition.
By this proposition also may be proved this Corrollary, that from one and the
self same point to one and the self same right line, can not be drawn two
perpendicular lines.

For if it be possible, from the point A, let there be drawn unto the right
line BC, two perpendicular lines AB, and AC: wherefore the angles ABC and ACB
are right angles. But forasmuch as ABC is a triangle. therefore any two angles
thereof are (by this proposition) less then two right angles. Wherefore the
angles ABC and ACB are less then two right angles: but they are also equal to
two right angles, by reason AB and AC are perpendicular lines upon BC^ which is
