impossible. Wherefore from one and the self same point cannot be drawn to one
and the self same line two perpendicular lines: which was required to be
proved.

The 11. Theoreme. The 18. Proposition. In every triangle, to the greater side
is subtended the greater angle.
SVppose that ABC be a triangle, having the side AC greater then the side AB.
Then I say that the angle ABC is greater then the angle BCA. Construction.
For forasmuch as AC is greater the^ AB, put (by the 3. proposition) unto AB an
equal line AD. And (by the first peticion) draw a line from the point B to the
point D. Demonstration^
And forasmuch as the outward angle of the triangle DBC, namely, the angle ADB
is greater then the inward and opposite angle DCB (by the 16. proposition,) but
(by the 5. proposition) the angle ADB is equal to the angle ABD, for the side
AB is equal to the side AD: therefore the angle ABD is greater then the angle
AC^. Wherefore the angle ABC is much greater then the angle ACB. Wherefore in
every triangle, to the greater side is subtended the greater angle: which was
required to be proved.

You may also prove the angle at the point B greater then the angle at the
point C (the side AC being greater then the side AB) if from the line AC you
cut of a line equal to the line AB, An other demonstration after Prophyrius.
beginning at the point C, as before you begaune at the point A: and that after
this manner. Let the line DC be equal to the line AB and draw the line BD: and
produce AB to the point E: and put the line BE equal to the line AD. Wherefore
the whole line AE is equal to the whole line AC: draw a line from E to C. And
forasmuch as AE is equal to AC, therefore the angle AEC is also equal to the
angle ACE (by the 5. proposition:) but the angle ABC is greater then the angle
AEC. For one of the sides of the triangle CBE, namely, the side BE is produced,
and so the outward angle ABC is greater then the inward and opposite BEC (by
the 16 proposition^) wherefore the angle ABC is much greater then the angle
ACB^ which was required to be proved.

Note that that which is here spoken in this propositi^on, That which is spoken
in this Proposition is to be understood in one and the self same triangle.
is to be understood in one and the self same triangle. For it is possible
that one and the self same angle may be subtended of a greater line, and of a
less line: and one and the self same right line may subtend a greater angle,
and a less angle. As for example.

Suppose that there be an Isosceles triangle ABC and, in the side AB take the
point D at all adventures: and from the line AC cut of (by the 3. proposition)
the line AE equal to the line AD. And draw a right line from D to E. Wherefore
the right lines DE and BC do subtend the angle at the point A, and of them the
one is greater, and the other less. And after the self same manner a man may
put infinite right lines greater and less, subtending the angle at the point A.

Again suppose that ABC be an Isosceles triangle. And let BC be less then
either of the lines BA and AC. And upon BC describe (by the first) an equilater
triangle BCD. And draw a line from A to D, and produce it to the point E. And
forasmuch as in the triangle ABD, the outward angle BDE, is greater ^hen the
inward and opposite angle BAD (by the 16. proposition) And by the same in the
tria^gle ACD, the outward angle CDE, is greater then the inward and opposite
angle CAD^ therefore the whole angle BDC is greater the^ the whole angle BAC.
And one and the self same right line subtendeth both these angles, namely, the
greater angle and the less. And it is also proved, that greater right lines
and less subtende one and the self same angle. But in one and the self same
triangle one right line subtendeth one angle, and the great right line ever
subtendeth the great angle, and the less the less, as it was proved in the
proposition.

The 12. Theoreme. The 19. Proposition. In every triangle, under the greater
angle is subtended the greater side.
SVppose that ABC be a triangle, ^auyng the angle ABC greater then the angle
BCA. Then I say that the side AC is greater then ye side AB. For if no^,
Demonstration lea^in^ to an i^possibilitie.
the the side AC is either equal to ye side AB, or else it is less the^ it^ The
side AC is not equal to ye side AB, for then (by the 5^ proposition) ye angle
ABC should be equal to the angle ACB: but (by suppositio^) it is not.
Wherefore the side AC is not equal to the side AB. And the side AC can not be
less then the side AB, for then the angle ABC should be less then the angle
ACB (by the proposition next going before). But (by supposition it is not)
Wherefore the side AC is not less then the side AB. Wherefore the side AC is
greater then the side AB. Wherefore in every triangle, under the greater angle
is subtended the greater side: which was required to be demonstrated.

This proposition (...) the converse the former.
This proposition is the converse of the proposition next going before.
Wherefore as you see, that which was the conclusion in the former, is in this
the supposition, or thing given: and that which was there the thing given, is
here the thing required or conclusion. And it is proved by an argument leading
to an impossibility, as commonly all conuerses are.

P^oclus demonstrateth this proposition after an other way: but first he
puts this An Assumpt is (...) of necessity in the help of a demonstration,
the certainty whereof is not so pl^i^e, and the^fore ^e^e^h is self first to
be demonstrated. An assumpt put by Pr^i^s^er the demonstration of this
Propo^i^ion.
Assumpt following.

If an angle of a triangle be divided into two equal parts, and if the line
which deuideth it being drawn to the base, do divide the same into two
unequal parts: the sides which contain that angle shall be unequal, and that
shall be the greater side, which falls on the grater side of the base, and that
the less which falls on the less side of the base.

Suppose ABC to be a triangle, and (by the 9. proposition) divide the angle at
the point A, into two equal parts, by the right line AD. And let the line AD
divide the base BC, into two unequal parts, and let the part CD be greater
then the part BD. Then I say, that the side AC is greater then the side AB.
Produce the line AD to the point E, and (by the third) put the line DE equal
to the line DA. And forasmuch a^ DC is by supposition greater then DB, put (by
the 3. proposition) DF equal to BD, and draw a line from E to F, and produce it
to the point G. Now forasmuch as AD is equal to ED and DB is equal to DF,
therefore in the two triangles ABD, and EFD, two sides of the one are equal to
two sides of the other, each to his correspondent side. and (by the 15.
proposition) they contain equal angles, namely, the head angles: wherefore (by
the fourth proposition) the base BA is equal to the base BF: and the angle DEF
is equal to the angle DAB. But the angle DAG is by construction equal to the
same angle DAB: wherefore (by the first common sentence) the angles EAG and AEG
are equal. Wherefore (by the ^^ proposion) the side AG is equal to the side
EG. Wherefore the side AC is greater then the side EG. Wherefore it is much
greater then the side OF. But the side OF is equal to the side AB, as it has
been proved. Wherefore the side AC is greater then the side AB: which was
required to be proved.

This assumpt being put, this Proposition is of Proclus thus demonstrated.

Suppose ABC to be a triangle, having his angle at the point B greater then the
angle at the point C. An other demonstration after Proclu^.
Then I say that the side AC is greater then the side AB. Divide the line BC
into two equal parts in the point D, and draw a line from A to D. And produce
the line AD to the point E: and put the line DE equal to the line AD, and draw
a line from B to E. Now forasmuch as BD is equal to DC, and AD is equal to DE
therefore in the two triangles ADC and BDE, two sides of the one are equal to
two sides of the other, each to his correspondent side, and they contain equal
angles (by the 15. proposition): wherefore (by the fourth proposition) the base
BE is equal to the base AC, and the angle DBE is equal to the angle at the
point C. Divide also th'angle ABE into two equal parts by the line BF: wherefore
the line OF is greater then the line FA. And forasmuch as in the triangle A^E,
the angle at the point B is divided into two equal parts by the right line
BF, and the line OF is greater then the line AF^ therefore by the former
Assumps the side RE is greater then the side BA: but the line BE is equal to
the line AC. Wherefore the side AC is greater then the side AB: which was
required to be proved.

The 13. Theoreme. The 20. Proposition. In every triangle two sides, which two
sides soever be taken, are greater then the side remaining.
SVuppose that ABC be a triangle. Then I say that two sides of the triangle
ABC, which two sides soever be taken, are greater^ then the side remaining that
is, the sides BA and AC are greater then the side BC: and the sides AB and BC
then the side AC: and the sides AC and BC then the side BA. Construction.
Produce (by the 2. peticion) the line BA to the point D. And (by the third
proposition) unto the line AC put an equal line AD. and draw^ a line from the
point D to the point C. Demonstration.
And forasmuch as the line DA is equal to the line AC, therefore (by the 5.
proposition) the angle ADC, is equal to the angle ACD. But the angle BCD is
greater then the angle ACD, therefore the angle BCD is greater then the angle
ADC. And forasmuch as DCB is a triangle, having the angle BCD greater then the
angle ADC, but (by the 18. proposi^ion) under the greater angle is subtended
the greater side: wherefore DB is greater then BC. But the line DB is equal to
the lines AB and AC (for the line AD is equal to the line AC) wherefore the
sides BA and AC, are greater then the side BC. And in like ^orte may we prove,
that the sides AB and BC are greater then the side AC: and that the sides BC
and CA are greater then the side AB. Wherefore in every triangle two sides,
which two sides soever be taken, are greater then the side remayning^ which was
required to be demonstrated.

This Proposition may also be demonstrated without producing any of the sides,
after this manner.

An other demo^stra^ion without producing one of the sides.
Suppose ABC to be triangle. Then I say, that the two sides AB and AC are
greater then the side BC: divide the angle at the point A (by the 9.
proposition) into two equal parts by the right line AE. And forasmuch as in
the triangl ABE, the outward angle AEC is greater then the angle BAE (by the 16
proposition), and the angle BAE is put to be equal to the angle EAC, therefore
the side AC is greater then the side CE. And by the same reason the side AB is
greater the the side BE. For in the triangle A^C the outward angle AEB, is
greater then the angle CAE, that is then the angle EAB^ Wherefore also the side
AB is greater then the side BE. Wherefore the sides AB and AC are greater then
the whole side BC. And after the same manner may you prove touching the other
sides also.

The same may yet also be demonstrated an other way.

An other Demonstration.
Suppose ABC to be a triangle. Now if ABC be an equilater triangle, then without
doubt any, two sides thereof are greater then the third. For the three sides
being equal any two sides of them are double to the third. But if it be an
Isosceles triangle, either the base is less then either of the equal sides or
it is greater. If the base be less, then again two of them are greater then
the third, but if the base be greater^ let BC being the base of the Isosceles
triangle ABC be greater the^ either of the sides AB and AC and from it ^ut of
(by the 3. proposition) a line equal to any one of the other sides, which let
be BE, and draw a line from A to E. And forasmuch as in the triangle AEB, the
angle AEC is an outward angle: therefore it is greater then the angle BAE (by
the 16. proposition). And by the same reason, the angle AEB is greater then the
angle CAE. Wherefore the angles at the point E are greater then the whole angle
at the point A. But the angle BEA is equal to the angle BAE (by the 5.
proposition) for AB is put to be equal to BE. Wherefore the angle remaining
AEC is greater then the angle CAE. Wherefore also the side AC is greater then
the side EC. But the side AB is equal to the side BE. Wherefore the sides AB
and AC are greater then the side BC.

But if the triangle ABC be a S^^lenum, let the side AB be the greatest, and
let AC be the mean, and BC the least. Wherefore the greatest side being added
to any one of the two sides must ^edes be greater then the third. For of it
self it is greater then any of them. But if AB being the greatest^ you would
prove the sides AC and CB to be greater then it. Then as you did in the
Isoceles triangle, cut of from the greatest a line equal to one of them, and
from the point C to the point of the intersection draw a right line, and reason
as you did before by the outward angles of the triangle, and you shall have your
purpose.

This proposition may yet moreover be demonstrated by an argument leading to an
absurdity, and that after this manner.

Suppose ABC to be a triangle. An other demo^stration leading to an absurditi^
Then I say that the sides AB and AC, are greater then the side BC. For if they
be not greater, they are either equal or less. First let them be equal, and
from the line BC cut of the line BE equal to the line AB (by the 3.
proposition) wherefore the residue EC is equal to AC. Now forasmuch as AB is
equal to BE they subtend equal angles. Likewise forasmuch as AC is equal to
CE they subtend equal angles. Wherefore the angles which are at the point E are
equal to the angles which are at the point A, which is impossible (by the
16. proposition).

But now let the sides AB and AC be less then the side BC, and from the line
BC cut of (by the 3. proposition) the line BD equal to the line AB, and
likewise from the same line BC cut of the line CE equal to the line AC. And
forasmuch as AB is equal to BD, the angle BDA also is equal to the angle BAD
(by the fifth proposition). Again forasmuch as AC is equal to CE, therefore
(by the same) the angle CEA is equal to the angle EAC. Wherefore these two
angles BDA and CEA are equal to these two angles BAD and EAC. Again forasmuch
as the angle BDA is the outward angle of the triangle ADC, therefore it is
greater then the angle EAC. For it is greater then the angle DAC (by the 16.
proposition). And by the same reason, forasmuch as CEA is the the outward angle
of the triangl^ ABE, therefore it is greater then the angle BAD (for it is
greater then the angle BAE). Wherefore the angles BDA and CEA are greater then
the two angles BAD and EAC. But they were also proved equal unto them: which
is impossible. Wherefore the sides AB and AC are neither equal to the side BC,
nor less then it, but greater. And so also may it be proved of the rest.

A brief demonstration by the definition of a right line.
A man may also more briefly demonstrate this proposition by Campanus
definition of a right line, which as we have before declared is thus: A right
line is the shortest extension or drawght that is or may be from one point to
another. Wherefore any one side of a triangle, for that it is a right line
drawn from some one point to some other one point, is of necessity shorter
then the other two sides drawn from and to the same points.

Not all things manifest to the sese, are straight way manifest to reason and
understanding.
Epicurus and such as followed him derided this proposition, not counting it
worthy to be added in the number of propositions of Geometry for the easines
thereof, for that it is manifest even to the sense. But not all things
manifest to sense, are straight ways manifest to reason and understanding. It
pertayneth to one that is a teacher of sciences, by proof and demonstration to
render a certain and undoubted reason, why it so appears to the sense^ and
in that only consists science.

The 14. Theoreme. The 21. Proposition. If from the ends of one of the sides
of a triangle, be drawn to any point within the said triangle two right
lines. those right lines so drawn, shall be less then the two other sides of
the triangle, but shall contain the greater angle.
SVppose that ABC be a triangle: and from the ends of the side BC, namely,
from the points B and C, let there be drawn within ye triangle two right
lines BD and CD to ye point D. Then I say, that the lines BD and CD are less
then the other sides of the triangle, namely, then the sides BA and AC: and
that the angle which they contain, namely, BDC, is greater then the angle BAC.
Extend (by the second peticion) the line BD to the point E. Demonstration.
And forasmuch as (by the 20. proposition) in every triangle the two sides are
greater then the side remaining, therefore the two sides of the triangle ABE,
namely, the sides AB and AE, are greater then the side EB. Put the line EC
common to them both. Wherefore the lines BA and AC, are greater then the lines
BE and EC^ Again forasmuch as (by the same) in the triangle CED, the two sides
CE and ED, are greater then ye side DC, put ye line DB common to them both^
wherefore ye lines CE and ED, are greater then the lines CD and DB. But it is
proved that the lines BA and AC, are greater then the lines BE and EC.
Wherefore the lines BA and AC, are much greater then the lines BD and DC.
Again forasmuch as (by the 16. proposition) in every triangle, the outward
angle is greater then the inward and opposite angle, therefore the outward
angle of the triangle CDE, namely, BDC, is greater then the angle CED.
Wherefore also (by the same) the outward angle of the triangle ABE, namely,
the angle CEB is greater then the angle BAC. But it is proved, that the angle
BDC is greater then the angle CEB. Wherefore the angle BDC is much greater then
the angle BAC. Wherefore if from the ends of one of the sides of a triangle,
be drawn to any point within the said triangle two right lines: those right
lines so drawn shall be less then the two other sides of the triangle, but shall
contain the greater angle: which was required to be demonstrated.

In this proposition is expressed, that the two right lines drawn within the
triangle, have their beginning at the extremes of the side of the triangle. For
from the one extreme of the side of the triangle, and from some one point of
the same side, may be drawn two right lines within the triangle, which shall
be longer the^ the two outward lines: which is wonderful and seems strange,
that two right lines drawn upon a part of a line, should be greater then two
right lines drawn upon the whole line. And again it is possible from the one
extreme of the side of a triangle, and from some one point of the same side to
draw two right lines within the triangle which shall contain an angle less
then the angle contained under the two outward lines.

As touching the first part.

Suppose ABC to be a rectangle triangle, whose right angle let be at the point
B. And in the side BC take a point at al adventures, which let be D: and draw a
right line from A to D Wherefore the line AD is greater then the line AE (by the
19. proposition) From the line AD cut of (by the third) a lin^ equal to the
line AB, which let be DE. And divide the line EA into two equal parts in the
point F (by the 10. proposition) And draw a line from F to C. Now forasmuch as
AFC is a triangle, therefore the lines AF and FC are greater the^ the line AC
(by the former proposition): but AF is equal to FE^ wherefore the right lines FE
and FC are greater then the line AC. And the line DE is equal to the line AB.
Wherefore the right lines FC and FD are greater then the right lines AB and AC^
and they are drawn within the triangle ABC, the one from one extreme of the
side BC, and the other from a point in the same side BC: which was required to
be proved.

As touching the second part. Suppose ABC to be an Isosceles triangle, and
let the base thereof namelye, BC be greater then either of the equal sides,
and from the line AC ^utte of a line equal to the line AB (by the third
proposition) which let be BD: and draw a line from A to D: and in the line
AD take a point at al adventures, which let be E, and draw a line from C to E.
Now forasmuch as the line AB, is equal to the line BD, therefore (by the fifth
proposition) the angle BAD is equal to the angle BDA. And forasmuch as in the
triangle EDC the angle EDB is an outward angle, therefore (by the 16.
proposition) it is greater then the inward and opposite angle DEC. Wherefore
the angle BAD is greater then the angle DEC. Wherefore the angle BAC is much
greater then the angle DEC: and the angle BAC is contained of the outward right
lines BA and AC, and the angle DEC is contained of the inward right lines DE
and EC: which was required to be proved.

By means of this proposition also is described that kind of triangles, which
contains fouresides. As for example, this figure ABC. For it is contained of
four sides BA, AC, CE, and EB. But it has only three angles, one at the
point B, an other at the point A, and the third at the point C. Wherefore this
present figure ABC is a quadrilater triangle: which of old philosophers has
ever been counted wonderful. And here is to be noted, that there is difference
between a three sided figure, and a three angled figure. For not every figure
having three angles has also only three sides as it is plain to see in this
figure. Likewise it is not all on, a figure to have lower sides, and four
angles. For a four sided figure may have only three angles, as in the former
figure: and a four angled figure may have five sides, as in this figure
following. And so of all other figures.

The 8. Problem. The 22. Proposition. Of three right lines, which are equal to
three right lines given, to make a triangle. But it behooves two of those lines,
which two soever be taken, to be greater then the third. For that in every
triangle two sides, which two sides soever be taken, are greater then the side
remaining.
SVppose that the three right lines given be A, B, C: of which let two of them,
which two soever be taken, be greater then the third, that is, let the lines A,
B, be greater then the line C, and the lines A, C, then the line B, and the
lines B, C, then the line A. It is required of three right lines equal to the
right lines A, B, C, to make a triangle. Construction.
Take a right line having an appointed end on the side D, and being infinite
on the side E. And (by the 3. proposition) put unto the line A, an equal line
DF, and put unto the line B, an equal line FG, and unto ye line C, an equal
line GH. And making the center F, and the space DF, describe (by the 3.
peticio^) a circle DKL. Again making the center G, and the space G H, describe
(by the same) a circle HKL; and let the point of the intersection of the said
circles be K, and (by the first peticion) draw a right line from the point K to
ye point F, and an other from the point K to the point G. Then I say, that of
three right lines equal to the lines A, B, C, is made a triangle KFG.
Demonstration.
For forasmuch as the point F is the center of the circle DKL. therefore (by
the 15. definition) the line FD is equal to the line FK. But the line A is
equal to the line FD Wherefore (by the first common sentence) the line FK is
equal to the line A. Again forasmuch as the point G, is the center of the
circle LKH, therefore (by the same definition) the line GK is equal to the
line GH^ But the line C is equal to the line GH: wherefore (by the first
common sentence) the line KG is equal to the line C. But the line FG is by
supposition equal to the line B wherefore these three right lines GF, FK, and
KG, are equal to these three right lines A, B, C. Wherefore of three right
lines, that is, KF, FG, and GK, which are equal to the three right lines given,
that is to A, B, C, is made a triangle KFG: which was required to be done.

An other construction, and demonstration after Flussates.
Suppose that the three right lines be A, B, C. And unto some one of them,
namely, An other construction and demonstration after Flussates.
to C, put an equal line DE, and (by the second proposition) from the point E,
draw the line EG, equal to the line B: and (by the same) unto the point D put
the line DH equal to the line A. And making the center the point E, and the
space EG, describe a circle FG: likewise making the center the point D, and the
space DH, describe an other circle HF: which circles let cut the one the
other in the point F. And draw these lines DF and OF. Then I say that DFE is a
triangle described of 3. right lines equal^ to the right lines A, B, C. For
forasmuch as the line DH is equal to the right line A, the line DF, shall also
be equal to the same right line A. (For that the lines DH and DF, are drawn
from the center to the circumference). Likewise forasmuch as EG is equal to OF
(by the 15. definition) and the right line B is equal to the same right line
EG: therefore the right line OF is equal to the right line B: but the right
line DE, was put to be equal to the right line C. Wherefore of three right
lines ED, DF, and FE, which are equal to three right lines given, A, B, C, is
described a triangle: which was ^equired to be done.

Instances in this Problem.
In this proposition the adversary paraduenture will cavil, that the circles
shall not cut the one the other (which thing Euclide puts them to do) But
now if they cut not the one the other, either they touch the one the other,
or they are dista^nte the one from the other. First if it be pos^ible let them
tooche the one the other: as in the figure here put (the construction whereof
answers to the construc^ion of Euclide).

First instance.
And forasmuch as F is the center of the circle DK, therefore the line DF is
equal to the line FN. And forasmuch as the point G, is the center of the circle
HL, therefore the line HG, is equal to the line GM. Wherefore these two lines
DF, and GH, are equal to one line, namely, to FG. But they were put to be
greater then it: for the lines DF, FG, and GH, were put to be equal to the
lines A, B, C, every two of which are supposed to be greater then the third:
wherefore they are both greater, and also equal, which is impossible. Second
instance
Again if it be possible, let the circles be distant the one from the other,
as are the circles DK and HL. And forasmuch as F is the center of the circle
DK, therefore the line DF is equal to the line FN. And forasmuch as G is the
center of the circle LH, therefore the line HG is equal to the line GM:
wherefore the whole line FG is greater then the two lines DF, and GH, (for the
line FG, excedeth the lines DF, and GH, by the line NM) but it was supposed
that the (...) ^ DF and HG (...) the^ the (...) FG: a^ also i^ (...) suppos^d
that the lines A and C, were (...) line B (for the (...) D^ is put to be ^qu^ll
to the line A, and the line F^ to the line B^ and the line HG to the line G^)
Wh^^^fo^^ they are both greater and also equal: which is impossible. Wherefore
the circles neither tooch the one the other, nor are distant the one from the
other. Wherefore of necessity they cut the one the other: which was required
to be proved.

The 9. Problem. The 23. Proposition. Upon a right line given, and to a point
in it given: to make a rectiline angle equal to a rectiline angle given.
SVppose yt the right line given be AB, and let ye point in it given be A. And
let also the rectiline angle given be DCH. It is required upon the right line
given AB, and to the point in it given A, to make a rectil^ne angle equal to
the rectiline angle given DCH. Construction.
Take in either of the lines CD and CH a point at all adventures, and let the
same be D and E. And (by the first peticion) draw a right line from D to E. And
of three right lines, AF, FG and GA, which let be equal to the three right
lines given, that is, to CD, DE, and EC, make (by ye proposition going before)
a triangle, and let the same be AFG^ so that let the line CD be equal to the
line AF, and the line CE to the line AG, and moreover the line DE to the line
FG. Demonstration.
And forasmuch as these two lines DC and CE are equal to these two lines FA
and AG, the one to the other, and the base DE is equal to the base FG:
therefore (by the 8. proposition) the angle DCE is equal to the angle FAG.
Wherefore upon the right line given AB, and to the poi^^ i^ i^ given namely A,
is made a rectiline angle FAG, equal to the rectiline angle given DCH: which
was required to be done.

An other construction and demons^^ation after Proclus.
Suppose that the right line given be AB: An other construction and
demonstration after Proclus.
and let the point in it given be A, and let the rectiline angle given be CDE.
It is required upon the right line given AB, and to the point in it given A, to
make a rectiline angle equal to the rectiline angle given CDE. Draw a line
from C to E. And produce the line AB on either side to the points F and G. And
unto the line CD, put the line FA equal, and unto the line DE let the line AB
be equal, and unto the line EC put the line BG equal. And making the ce^tre the
point A, and the space AF, describe a circle KF. And again making the center
the point B and the space BG describe an other circle ^L: which shall of
necessity cut the one the other, as we have before proved. Let them cut the
one the other in the points M and N. And draw these right lin^s AN, AM, BN,
and BM. And forasmuch as FA is equal to AM^ and also to AN (by the definition
of a circle) but CD is equal to FA, wherefore the lines AM and AN are ech^
equal to the line DC. Ag^yne forasmuch as BG, is equal to BM, and to BN, and
BG is equal to CE: therefore either of these lines BM and BN is equal to the
line CE. But the line BA is equal to the line DE. Wherefore these two lines BA
and AM, are equal to these two lines D E and DC, the one to the other, and the
base BM is equal to the base CE. Wherefore (by the 8. proposition) the angle
MAB, is equal to the angle at the point D. And by the same reason the angle
NAB, is equal to the same angle at the point D. Wherefore upon the right line
given AB, and to the point in it given A, is described a rectiline angle on
either side of the line AB: namely, on one side the rectiline angle NAB, and on
the other side the rectiline angle MAB, either of which is equal to the
rectiline angle given CDE: which was required to be done.

An other construction also, and demonstration after Pelitar^us.
A^ other D^mons^ra^ion after ^eli^arius.
Suppose that the right line given be AB: and let the point in it given be C,
and let the rectiline angle given be DEF. It is required upon the line given
AB, and to the point in it given C, to describe a rectiline angle equal to the
rectiline angle given DEF. Produce the line FE to the point G: and from the
point E erect (by the 11. proposition) unto the line GF a perpendiculer line
EH, which if it exactly agree with the line ED, then was the angle given a
right angle. Wherefore if from the point C you erecte a perpendiculer line unto
the line AB, that shall be done which was req^ired to be done But if it do not,
then from the point H, ere^t unto the line HE, a perpendiculer line HD, which
being produced shall (by the fift^ peticion) concur with the line FD being
also produced: for the angle DEH is less then a right angle (when as GEH is a
right angle). Where^ore let them concur in the point D, and so is made the
triangle DEH. After the same manner from the point given C, erect unto the line
AB a perpendiculer line CK: which let be equal to the perpendicular line EH
(by the 3. proposition): and from the point K erect unto the line K C, a
perpendiculer line KL, which let be equal to the perpendiculer line HD. And
draw a line from C to L. Then I s^y that the angle LCB, is equal to the angle
given DEF. For the two triangles HEAD and KCL, are (by the fourth proposition)
equal, and equilater the one to the other: and the two angles LCK and DEH are
equal. And the two angles BCK and FEH are equal, for either of them is a right
angle. Wherefore (by the 2. common sentence) the whole angle LCB, is equal to
the whole angle DEF. Which was required to be done.

And if the perpendiculer line chance to fall without the angle given, namely,
if the angle given be an acute angle, the self same manner of demonstration
will serve: but only that instead of the second common sentence, must be used
the 3. common sentence.

Appollonius puts another construction and demonstration of this
proposition: which (though the demonstration thereof depend of propositions
put in the third book, yet for that the construction is very good for him that
will redely, and mechanically, without demonstration, describe upon a line
given, and to a point in it given, a rectiline angle equal to a rectiline
angle given) I thought not amiss here to place it. And it is thus.

Suppose that the rectiline angle given be CDE, An other construction and
d^^monstration after Appollonius.
and let the right line given be AB, and let the point in it given be A. Take
in the line CD, a po^^^ at all adventures, which let be F. And making the
ce^tre the point D, and the space DF, describe a circle FG, cutting the line
DE, in the point G, and draw a right line from F to G. Likewise from the line
AB, cut of a line equal to the line DF, which let be AH. And making the ce^tre
the point A, and the space AH describe a circle HK, and from the point H^
subtend unto the circumference of the circle a right line equal to the right
line FG, which let be HK: and draw a right line from A to K. Then I say that
the angle HAK, is equal to the angle CDE. The proof whereof I now omit for
that it depends of the ^8 and 27 propositions of the third book.

But now, as I said, by this you may very redily, and mechanically, How to do
this pr^position redily and mechanically.
without demonstration, upon a line given, and to a point in it given describe
a rectiline angle equal to a rectiline angle given. For in the rectiline angle
given, you need only to mark the two points, where the circumference of the
circle cutteth the lines containing the angle geuen^ as the points F and G^ and
likewise to mark in the line given as in AB, the point H, and so making the
center the point A, according to the space AH (which is put to be equal to FD)
describe a pe^^e of a circumference on that side that you will have the angle to
be, as for example the circumference HK, and opening your compass to the
wideth from the point F, to the point G, set one foot thereof fixed in the
point H, and mark the point where the other foot cutteth the said
circumference, which point let be K. And from that point to the point. A, draw
a right line: and so shall you have described at the point A, an angle equal to
the angle at the point D. As in the figures in the end of the other side put.

Oenopides the first inuenter of this proposition.
Oenopides was the first inuenter of this proposition as witnesses Eudemius.

The 15. Theoreme The 24. Proposition. If two triangles have two sides of the
one equal to two sides of the other, each to his correspondent side, and if the
angle contained under the equal sides of the one, be greater then the angle
contained under the equal sides of the other: the base also of the same,
shall be greater then the base of the other.
SVppose that there be two triangles ABC, and DEF, having two sides of the one,
that is, AB, and AC, equal to two sides of the other, that is, to DE, and DF,
each to his correspondent side: that is, the side AB, to the side DE, and the
side AC to the side DF: and suppose that the angle BAC be greater then the
angle EDF. Then I say that the base BC, is greater then the base OF. For
forasmuch as the angle BAC is greater then the angle EDF, Construction.
make (by the 23. proposition) upon the right line DE, and to the point in it
given D, an angle EDG equal to the angle given BAC. And to one of these lines,
that is, either to AC, or DF, put an equal line DG. And (by the first
peticio^) draw a right line from the point G, to the point E, and an other from
the point F, Demonstration.
to the point G. And forasmuch as the line AB is equal to the line DE, and the
line AC to the line DG, the one to ye other, and the angle BAC is (by
construction) equal to the angle EDG, therefore (by the 4. proposition) the
base BC, is equal to the base EG. Again for as much as the line DG is equal
to the line DF, ther^ (by the 5. proposition) the angle DGF, is equal to the
angle DFG. Wherefore the angle DFG is greater then the angle EGF. Wherefore
the angle EFG is much greater then the angle EGF. And forasmuch as EFG is a
triangle, having the angle EFG greater then the angle EGF, and (by the 18.
pr^position) under the greater angle is subtended the greater side, therefore
the side EG is greater then the side OF. But the side EG is equal to the side
BC: wherefore the side BC is greater then the side OF. If therefore two
triangles have two sides of the one equal to two sides of the other, each to
his correspondent side, and if the angle contained under the equal sides of
the one, be greater then the angle contained under the equal sides of the
other: the base also of the same shall be greater then the base of the other:
which was required to be proved.

In this Theoreme may be three cases. Three cases in this pr^position.
For the angle EDG, being put equal to the angle BAC, and the line DG, being
put equal to the line AC, and a line being drawn from E to G, the line EG
shall either fall above the line GF, or upon it, or under it. Euclides
demonstration serves, The first cas^. 2.
when the line GE falls above the line GF, as we have, before manifestly
seen.

But if it fall upon it, Second case.
as in this figure here put. Then forasmuch as the two lines AB and AC, are
equal to the two lines DE and DG, the one to the other, and they contain
equal angles by construction: therefore (by the 4. proposition) the base BC,
is equal to the base EG, but the base EG, is greater then the base OF:
wherefore also the base BC, is greater then the base OF: which was required to
be proved.

But now let the line EG, Third case.
fall under the line E F, as in the figure here put. And forasmuch as these two
lines AB, and AC, are equal to these two lines DE and DG, the one to the
other, and they contain equal angles, therefore (by the 4. proposition) the
base BC, is equal to the base EG. And forasmuch as within the triangle DEGREES, the
two linnes DF and FE, are set upon the side DE: therefore (by the 21.
proposition) the lines DF and F^ are less then the outward lines DG and GE:
but the line DG is equal to the line DF. Wherefore the line GE is greater then
the line FE. But GE is equal to BC. Wherefore the line BC is greater the the
line OF. Which was required to be proved.

This third case may also another way be demonstrated. An other demonstration
of the third case.
Produce the lines DF and DG, which are equal, unto the points K and H: and
draw a line from F to G: wherefore (by the second part of the fifth
proposition) the angles KFG and FGH, which are under the base FG^ are equal:
therefore the angle EFG is greater then the angle FG^. Wherefore (by the 18
proposition) the sid^ EG is greater then the side OF: but the base BC is equal
unto the base EG: Wherefore the base BC, is greater then the base EF^ Which was
required to be proved.

It may peradventure seme^ that Euclide should here in this proposition have
proved, that not only the bases of the triangles are unequal, but also that
the areas of the same are unequal: for so in the fourth proposition, after he
had proved the base to be equal, he proved also the areas to be equal. But
hereto may be answered, Why Euclide etc.
that in equal angles and bases, and unequal angles and bases, the
consideration is not like. For the angles and bases being equal, the triangles
also shall of necessity be equal, but the angles and bases being unequal,
the areas shall not of necessity be equal. For the triangles may both be
equal and unequal: and that may be the greater, which has the greater
angle, and the greater base, and it may also be the less. And for that cause
Euclide made no mention of the comparison of the triangles. Whereof this also
might be a cause, for that to the demonstration thereof are required certain
Propositions concerning parallel lines, which we are not as yet come unto.
After the ^^ etc.
Howbeit after the 37^ proposition of his book you shall find the comparison of
the areas of triangles, which have their sides equal, and their bases and
angles at the top unequal.

The 16. Theoreme. The 25. Proposition. If two triangles have two sides of the
one equal to two sides of the other, each to his correspondent side, and if
the base of the one be greater then the base of the other: the angle also of
the same contained under the equal right lines^ shall be greater then the
angle of the other.
SVppose that there be two triangles, A, B, C, and DEF, having two sides of
tb'one, that is, AB, and AC, equal to two sides of the other, that is to DE,
and DF, each to his correspondent side, namely, the side AB to the side DF, and
the side AC to the side DF. But let the base BC be greater then the base OF.
The^ I say, they the angle BAC is greater then the angle EDF. For if not,
Demonstration leading to an absurdi^y.
then is it either equal unto it, or less then it. But the angle BAC is not
equal to the angle EDF: for if it were equal, the base also BC should (by the
4. proposition) be equal to the base OF: but by supposition it is not.
Wherefore the angle BAC is not equal to the angle EDF. Neither also is the
angle BAC less then the angle EDF: for then should the base BC be less the^
the base OF (by the former proposition) But by supposition it is not. Wherefore
y^ angle BAC is not less the^ ye angle EDF. And it is already proved, that it
is not equal unto it: wherefore ye a^gle BAC is greater then the angle EDF. If
therefore two triangles have two sides of the one equal to two sides of the
other, each to his correspondent side, and if the base of the one be greater
then the base of the other, the angle also of the same contained under ye equal
right lines shall be greater the^ the angle of the other: which was required to
be proved.

This proposition is plain opposite to the eight, and is the co^uerse of the
four and twenty which went before. All converses are commonly indirectly
demonstrated.
And it is proved (as commonly all conuerses are) by a reason leading to an
absurdity. But it may after Menelaus Alexandrinus be demonstrated directly, An
other demo^stration after Menelaus Alexandrinus.
after this manner.

Suppose that there be two triangles ABC and DEF: having the two sides AB and
AC equal to the two sides DE and DF, the one to the other: and le^ the base BC
be greater then the base OF. Then ^ say that the angle at the point A, is
greater the^ the angle at the point D. For from the base BC (...) of (by the
third) a line eqnall to the base OF, and let the same be BG. And upon the line
GB and to the point B put (by the 23, proposition) an angle equal to the angle
DEF: which let be GBH: and let the line ^H be equal to the line DE. And draw
a line from H to G, and produce it beyond the point G: which being produce
shall fall either upon the angle A, Diverse cases in this demonstration.
or upon the line AB, or upon the line AC. First let it fall upon the angle A.
First case.
And forasmuch as these two lines BG and BH are equal to these two lines OF
and ED, the one to the other, and they contain equal angles (by construction)
namely, the angles GBH and DEF: therefore (by the 4. proposition) the base GH is
equal to the DF, and the angle BHG to the angle EDF. Again forasmuch as the
line BH is equal to the line BA (for the line AB is supposed to be equal to
the line DE, unto which line the line BH is put equal) therefore (by the 5.
proposition) the angle BHA is equal to the angle BAH: wherefore also the angle
EDF is equal to the angle BAH. But the angle BAC is greater then the angle BAH:
wherefore also the angle BAC is greater then the angle EDF. Second case.


But now let it fall upon the line AB in the point K, and draw a line from A
to H. And forasmuch as these two lines BG and BH are equal to these two lines
OF and ED, the one to the other, and they contain equal angles (by
constuction) namely, the angles GBH and DEF: therefore (by the 4. proposition)
the base GH is equal to the base DF, and the angle BHG to the angle EDF.
Again forasmuch as in the triangle BAH, the side BA is equal to the side BH,
therefore (by the 5. proposition) the angle BAH is equal to the angle BHA. But
the angle BHA is greater then the angle BHG. wherefore also the angle BAH is
greater then the angle BHG. Wherefore the angle BAC is much greater then the
angle BHG. But it is proved that the angle BHG is equal to the angle at the
point D. Wherefore the angle BAC is greater then the angle at the point^ D:
Which was required to be proved.

But now suppose that the line HG being produced do fall upon the line AC,
Third case.
namely, in the point K. And again draw also a line from A to H. And forasmuch
as BG is equal to OF, and BH, to ED, therefore these two lines BG and BH are
equal to these two lines OF, and ED, the one to the other, and (by
construction) they contain equal angles, namely, the angles GBH and FED.
Wherefore (by the fourth proposition) the base GH is equal to the base DF: and
th'angle BHG is equal to th'angle EDF. And forasmuch as GH is equal to DF,
and DF is equal to AC: therefore GH also is equal to AC. Wherefore HK is
greater then AC, wherefore HK is much greater then AK. Wherefore (by the 18.
proposition) the angle KAH is greater then the angle KHA. Again forasmuch as
BH is equal to AB (for BH is put equal to DE, which is by supposition equal to
AB) therefore (by the 5. proposition) the angle BHA is equal to the angle BAH.
Wherefore the whole angle BHK is less then the whole angle BAK. But it has
been pro^ed, that the angle BHK is equal to the angle at the point D, wherefore
the angle BAC is greater then the angle at the point D, which was required to
be proved.

Hero Mechanicus also demonstrateth it an other way, and that by a direct
demonstration.

An other demonstration after Hero Mechanicus.
Suppose that there be two triangles ABC and DEF, having the two sides AB, and
AC, ^quall to the two sides DE, and DF, the one to the other, and let the base
BC, be greater then the base OF. Then I say, that the angle at the point A, is
greater then the angle at the point D. For forasmuch as BC, is greater the^ OF,
produce OF to the point G, and put the line EG, equal to the line BC. Likewise
produce the line DE to the point H, and put the line DH, equal to the line DF.
Wherefore making the center the point D, and the space DF, describe a circle,
and it shall pass also by the point H. Let the same circle be FKH. And
forasmuch as AC and AB are greater the BC (by the 20. proposition) and the
lines AB and AC, ar equal to the line EH, and the line BC is equal to the line
EG. Therefore the line EH is greater then the line EG. Wherefore making the
center the point E and the space EG describe a circle and it shall cut the line
EH. Let the same circle be GK: and from the common sectio^ of the circles,
which let be the point K, draw these right lines KD and KE. And forasmuch as
the point D is the center of the circle HKF, therefore (by the 15. def^nition)
the line DK, is equal to the line DH, that is unto the line AC. Again
forasmuch as E is the center of the circle GK, therefore the line E K is equal
to the line EG, that is, to the line BC. And forasmuch as these two lines AB
and AC, are equal to these two lines DE and DK, and the base BC is equal to
the base E K (for E K is equal to E G (by the 15. definition) and E G is put
to be equal to BC). Wherefore (by the 4. proposition) the angle BAC is equal to
the angle ED K. But the angle E DK is greater then the angle E DF: wherefore
also the angle BAC, i^ greater then the angle EDF: which was required to be
proved.

The 17. Theoreme. The 26. Proposition. If two triangles have two angles of the
one equal to two angles of the other, each to his correspondent angle, and have
also one side of the one equal to one side of the other, either that side
which lies between the equal angles, or that which is subtended under one of
the equal angles: the other sides also of the one, shall be equal to the other
sides of the other, each to his correspondent side, and the other angle of the
one shall be equal to the other angle of the other.
SVppose that there be two triangles AB C, and DEF, having two angles of the
one, that is, the angles ABC, and BCA, equal to two angles of the other, that
is, to the angles DEF, and EFD, each to his correspo^dent angle, that is, the
angle ABC, to the angle DEF, and the angle BCA to the angle EFD, and one side
of the one equal to one side of ye other, first that side which lies between
the equal angles, that is, the side BC, to the OF. The^ I say that the other
sides also of the one shall be equal to the other sides of the other, each to his
correspondent side, that is, that side AB, to the side DE, and the side AC, to
the side DF, and the other angle of the one, to the other angle of the other,
that is, the angle BAC to the angle EDF. For if the side AB be not equal to
the side DE, the one of them is greater. Let the side AB be greater: and (by
the 3. proposition) unto the line DE, put an equal line GB, and draw a right
line from the point G, to the point C. Now forasmuch as the line GB,
Demonstration leading to an absurditis.
is equal to the line DE, and the line BC to the line OF, therefore these two
lines GB and BC, are equal to these two lines DE and OF, the one to the other,
and the angle GBC is (by supposition) equal to the angle DEF. Wherefore (by
the 4. proposytion) the base GC is equal to the base DF, and the triangle GCB
is equal to the triangle DEF, and the angles remay^ing are equal to the
angles remaining under which are subtended equal sides. Wherefore the angle
GCB is equal to the angle DFE. But the angle DFE is supposed to be equal to
the angle BCA. Wherefore (by the first common sentence) the angle BCG is equal
to the angle BCA, the less angle to the greater: which is impossible.
Wherefore the line AB is not unequal to the line DE. Wherefore it is equal
And the the line BC is equal to the line OF: now therefore there are two sides
AB and BC equal to two sides DE and OF, the one to the other, and the angle
ABC, is equal to the angle DEF. Wherefore (by the 4. proposition) the base AC
is equal to the base DF, and the angle remaining BAC is equal to the angle
remaining EDF.

Again suppose that the sides subtending the equal angles be equal the one
to the other, let the side I say AB be equal to the side DE. Then again I
say, that the other sides of the one are equal to the other sides of the
other, each to his correspondent side, that is the side AC to the side DF, and
the side BC to the side OF: and moreover the angle remaining, namely, BAC, is
equal to the angle remaining, that is, to the angle EDF. For if the side BC be
not equal to the side OF, the one of them is greater: let the side BC, if it
be possible, be greater. And (by the third proposytion) unto the line OF, put
an equal line BH, and draw a right line from the point A to the point H. And
forasmuch as the line BH is equal to the line OF, and the line AB to the line
DE, therefore these two sides AB and BH, are equal to these two sides DE and
OF, the one to the other, and they contain equal angles. Wherefore (by the
4. proposition) the base AH is equal to the base DF, and the triangle ABH, is
equal to the triangle DEF, and the angles remaining are equal to the angle^
remaining, under which are subte^ded equal sides. Wherefore the angle BHA is
equal to the angle EFD. But the angle EFD is equal to the angle BCA.
Wherefore the angle BHA is equal to the angle BCA. Wherefore the outward
angle of ye triangle AHC, namely, the angle BHA, is equal to the inward and
opposite angle, namely, to the angle HCA, which (by the 16 proposition) is
impossible. Wherefore the side OF is not unequal to the side BC, wherefore it
is equal. And the side AB is equal to ye side DE: wherefore these two sides
AB and BC, are equal to these two sides DE and OF, the one to the other, and
they contain equal angles: Wherefore (by the 4. proposition) the base AC is
equal to the base DF: and the triangle ABC, is equal to the triangle DEF, and
the angle remaining, namely, the angle BAC is equal to the angle remaining,
that is, to the angle EDF. If therefore two triangles have two angles of the
one equal to two angles of the other, each to his correspondent angle, and have
also one side of the one equal to o^e side of the other, either that side
which lies between the equal angles, or that which is subtended under one of
the equal angles: the other sides also of the one shall be equal to the other
sides of the other, each to his correspondent side, and the other angle of the
one shall be equal to the other angle of the other: which was required to be
proved.

Whereas in this proposition it is said, that triangles are equal, which
having two angles of the one equal to two angles of the other, the one to the
other, have also one side of the one equal to one side of the other, either
that side which lies between the equal angles, or that side which subtendeth
one of the equal angles: this is to be noted that without that caution
touching the equal side, the proposition shall not always be true. As for
example.

Suppose that there be a rectangle triangle ABC, whose right angle let be at
the point B, and let the side BC be greater the^ the side BA: and produce the
line AB, from the point B to the point D. And upon the right line BC and to the
point in it C, make unto the angle BAC an equal angle (by the 23. proposition),
which let be BCD, and let the lines BD and CD, being produced co^curre in the
point D. Now the^ there are two triangles ABC, and BCD, which have two angles
of the one equal to two angles of the other, the one to the other, namely, the
angle ABC to the angle DBC (for they are both right angles), and the angle BAC,
to the angle BCD (by construction) and have also one side of the one equal to
one side of the other, namely, the side BC, which is common to them both. And
yet notwithstanding the triangles are not equal: for the triangle BDC, is
greater then the triangle ABC. For upon the right line BC, and to the point in
it C, describe an angle equal to the angle ACB: which let be FCB (by the 23.
proposition). And forasmuch as the side BC was supposed to be greater then the
side. AB, therefore (by the 18. proposition) the angle BAC is greater then the
angle BCA, wherefore also the angle BCD is greater then the angle BCF.
Wherefore the triangle BCD is greater then the triangle BCF. Again forasmuch
as there are two triangles ABC and BCF; having two angles of the one equal to
two angles of the other^ the one to the other, namely, the angle ABC to the
angle FBC (for they are both right angles) and the angle ACB to the angle FCB
(by construction), and one side of the one is equal to one side of the other,
namely, that side which lies between the equal angles, that is, the side BC
which is common to both triangles. Wherefore (by this proposition) the
triangles ABC and F BC are equal. But the triangle DBC is greater the^ the
triangle F BC. Wherefore also the triangle DBC is greater then the triangle
ABC. Wherefore the triangles ABC and DBC, are not equal: notwithstanding they
have two angles of the one equal to two angles of the other, the one to the
other, and one side of the one equal to one side of the other.

The reason whereof is, for that the equal side in one triangle, subte^deth one
of the equal angles, and in the other lies between the equal angles. So that
you see that it is of necessity that the equal side do in both triangles,
either subtend one of the equal angles, or lie between the equal angles.

Of this proposition was Thales Milesius the inuentor, Thales Milesius the
inuent^r of this proposition.
as witnesses Eudemus in his book of Geometrical enarrations.

The 18. Theoreme. The 27. Proposition. If a right line falling upon two right
lines, do make the alternate angles equal the one to the other: those two
right lines are parallels the one to the other.
SVppose that the right line OF falling upon these two right lines AB and CD,
do make the alternate angles, namely, the angles AEF and EFD equal the one to
the other. Then I say that AB is a parallel line to CD. For if not, then these
lines produced shall mete together, either on the side of B and D, or on the
side of A and C. Demo^stration ^eading to an absurdity.
Let them be produced therefore, and let them mete if it be possible on the side
of B and D, in the point G. Wherefore in the triangle GEF, the outward angle
AEF is equal to the inward and opposite angle EFG, which (by the 16.
proposition) is impossible. Wherefore the lines AB and CD being produced on the
side of B and D, shall not meet. In like sort also may it be proved that they
shall not mete on the side of A and C. But lines which being produced on no
side meet together, are parrallell lines (by the last definition:) wherefore AB
is a parrallel line to CD. If therefore a right line falling upon two right
lines, do make the alternate angles equal the one to the other: those two
right lines are parrallels the one to the other: which was required to be
demonstrated.

^
This word alternate is of Euclide in diverse places diversely taken: sometimes
for a kind of situation in place, and sometime for an order in proportion, in
which signification he uses it in the v. book, and in his books of numbers.
And in the first signification he uses it here in this place, and generally in
all his other books, ^
h^uing to do with lines and figures. And those two angles he calls
alternate, which being both contained within two parallel or equidistant lines
are neither angles in order, nor are on the one and self same side, but are
separated the one from the other by the line which falls on the two lines:
the one angle being above, and the other beneath.

The 19. Theoreme. The 28. Proposition. If a right line falling upon two right
lines, make the outward angle equal to the inward and opposite angle on one
and the same side, or the inward angles on one and the same side, equal to
two right angles: those two right lines shall be parallels the one to the other.
SVppose that the right line OF, falling upon these two right lines AB and CD,
do make the outward angle EGB equal to the inward and opposite angle GHD, or
do make the inward angles on one and the same side, that is, the angles BGH and
GHD equal to two right angles. Then I say that the line AB is a parallel line
to the line CD For forasmuch as the angle EGB is (by supposition) equal to the
angle GHD, Demonstration
and the angle EGB is (by the 15. proposition) equal to the angle AGH:
therefore the angle AGH is equal to the angle GHD: and they are alternate
angles. Wherefore (by the 27. proposition) AB is a parallel line to CD.

Again forasmuch as the angles BGH and GHD are (by supposition) equal to two
right angles, and (by the 13. proposition) the angles AGH and BGH, are also
equal to two right angles, wherefore the angles AGH and BGH, are equal to the
angles BGH and GHD: take away the angle BGH which is common to them both
Wherefore the angle remainyng, namely, AGH is equal to the angle remaining,
namely, to GHD. And they are alternate angles. Wherefore (by the former
proposition) AB is a parallel line to CD. If therefore a right line falling
upon two right lines, do make the outward angle equal to the inward and
opposite angle on one and the same side, or the inward angles on one and the
same side, equal to two right angles, those two right lines shall be parallels
the one to the other: which was required to be proved.

Ptolomeus demonstrateth the second part of this proposition, namely, that the
two inward angles on one and the same side being equal, the right lines are
parellels, after this manner. An other demo^stration of the second part of this
proposition after Ptolome^^


Suppose that there be two right lines AB and CD, and let a certain right line
EFGH cut them in such sort, that it make the angles BFG and FGD equal to
two right angles. Then I say, that these right lines AB and CD are parallel
lines, that is, they shall not concur. For if it be possible, let the lines
BF and GD being produced concur in the point K. Now forasmuch as the right
line OF stands upon the right line AB, therefore (by the 13. proposition) it
makes the angles AFE, and BFE equal to two right angles: likewise forasmuch
as the line FG stands upon the line CD, therefore (by the same proposition) it
makes the angles CGF and DGF equal to two right angles. Wherefore the four
angles BFE, AFE, CGF, and DGF are equal to four right angles: of which the two
angles BFG and FGD are (by supposition) equal to two right angles, wherefore
the angles remaining, namely, AFG and CGF are also equal to two right angles.
If therefore the right lines FB and GD being produced (the inward angles being
equal to two right angles) do concur, then shall the lines FA and GC being
produced concur. For the angles AF G and CGF are equal to two right angles.
For either the right lines shall concur on either side, or else on neither
side. For that on either side the angles are equal to two right angles.
Wherefore let the right lines F A and GC concur in the point L. Wherefore the
two right lines LAFK and LCGK do comprehend a space, which (by the 6. peticion)
is impossible. Wherefore it is not possible that the inward angles being equal
to two right angles, the right lines should concur. Wherefore they are
parallels: which was required to be proved.

The 20. Theoreme. The 29. Proposition. A right line line falling upon two
parallel right lines: makes the alternate angles equal the one to the other:
and also the outward angle equal to the inward and opposite angle on one and
the same side: and moreover the inward angles on one and the same side equal
to two right angles.
SVppose that upon these parallel lines AB and CD do fall the right line OF.
Then I say that the alternate angles which it makes, namely, the angles AGH
and GHD, are equal the one to the other and yt the outward angle EGB is equal
to the inward and opposite angle on the same side, namely, to ye angle GHD:
and yt the inward angles on one and the self same side, that is, the angles
BGH and GHD, are equal to two right angles. For if the angle AGH be not equal
to the angle GHD, Demonstration (...)
the one of them is greater. Let the angle AGH be greater. And forasmuch as the
angle AGH is greater then the angle GHD, put the angle BGH common to the^ both.
Wherefore ye angles AGH and BGH, are greater the^ ye angles BGH and GHD. But by
ye 13. proposition ye angles AGH and BGH are equal to two right angles,
wherefore ye angles BGH and GHD are less the^ two right angles. But (by ye 5.
peticion) if upon two right lines do fall a right line, making ye inward angles
on one and ye same side, less the^ two right angles, those right lines being
infinitely produced must needs at ye length meet on the side wherein are the
angles less the^ two right angles. Wherefore the right lines AB and CD being
infinitely produced will at ye length meet. But they cannot meet, because
they are parallels (by supposition): wherefore the angle AGH is not unequal to
the angle GHD: wherefore it is equal.

And the angle AGH is (by the 15. proposition) equal to the angle EGB. Second
part.
Wherefore (by the first common sentence) the angle EGB is equal to the angle
GHD.

Put the angle BGH common to them both: wherefore the angles EGB and BGH, Third
part.
are equal to the angles BGH and GHD. But the angles EGB and BGH are (by the
13. proposition) equal to two right angles. Wherefore the angles BGH and GHD
are also equal to two right angles. If a line therefore do fall upon two
parallel right lines: it makes the alternate angles equal the one to the
other: and also the outward angle equal to the inward and opposite angle on
one and the same side: and moreover the inward angles on one and the same side
equal to two right angles: which was required to be demonstrated.

This proposition is the converse of the two propositions next going before.
This proposition is the converse of the two former propositio^s.
For, that which in either of them is the thing sought, or conclusion, is in
this the thing given, or supposition. And contrariwise the things which in
them were given or suppositions, are in this proved, and are conclusions.

Pelitarius after this proposition adds this witty conclusion.
If two right lines which cut two parallel lines, An addition of Pelitarius.
do between the said parallel lines concur in a point, and make the
alternate angles equal, or the outward angle equal to the inward and opposite
angle on the same side, or finally the two inward angles on one and the self
same side equal to two right angles: those two right lines are drawn directly
and make one right line.

Suppose that there be two right lines AB and CB, which let cut two parallel
lines DE and FG: and let AB cut the line DE in the point H: and let CB cut the
line FG in the point K: and let the lines AB and CB, concur between the two
parallel lines DE and FG in the point B: and let the angle DHB be equal to the
angle BKG: or let the angle AHD be equal to the angle BKF: or finally let the
angles BHD and BKF be equal to two right angles. The^ I say that the two lines
AB and BC are drawn directly, and do make one right line. For if they be not,
then produce AB until it cut FG in the point L, and let AL be one right line,
Demonstration leading to an absurdity.
and so shall be made the triangle BLK. Now then (by the first part of this 29.
proposition) the angle DHB shall be equal to the alternate angle GLB: First part.
but (by supposition) the angle DHB is equal to the angle BKG. Wherefore the
angle BLG is equal to the angle BKL, namely, the outward angle to the inward
and opposite angle: which (by the 16. proposition) is impossible.

Moreover (by the second part of this 29. proposition) the angle AHD shall be
equal to the angle BLK, Second part.
namely, the outward angle to the inward and opposite angle on one and the same
side. But the same angle AHD is supposed to be equal to the angle BKF:
wherefore the angle BKF is equal to the angle BLK. Which (by the self same
16. proposition) is impossible.

Lastly forasmuch as the angles BHD and BKF are supposed to be equal to two
right angles, Third part.
and the angles BHD and BLK are also by the last part of this 29 proposition
equal to two right angles, therefore the angle BKF shall be equal to the angle
BLK: which again by the self same 16. proposition is impossible.

The 21. Theoreme The 30. Proposition. Right lines which are parallels to one
and the self same right line: are also parrallel lines the one to the other.
SVppose that these right lines AB and CD, be parallel lines to the right line
OF. Then I say, that the line AB is a parallel line to CD. Demonstration.
Let there fall upon these three lines a right line GHK. And forasmuch as the
right line GHK falls upon these parallel right lines AB and OF, therefore
(by the proposition going before) the angle AGH is equal to the angle GHF.
Again forasmuch as the right line GK falls upon these parallel right lines
OF and CD, therefore (by the same) the angle GHF is equal to the angle GKD.
Now then it proved that the angle AGH is equal to ye angle GHF, and yt the
angle GKD is equal to the angle GHF. Wherefore the angle AGK is equal to the
angle GKD. And they are alternate angles: wherefore AB is a parallel line to CD.
Right lines therefore which are parallels to one and the self same right line,
are also parallel lines the one to the other: which was required to be proved.

Euclide in the demonstration of this proposition, sets the two parallel
lines which are compared to one, in the extremes, and the parallel to whom
they are compared, he places in the middle, for the easier demonstration. It
may also be proved even by a principle only. For if they should concur on
any one side, they should concur also with the middle line, and so should
they not be parallels unto it, which yet they are supposed to be.

An other case in (...) Problem^.
But if you will alter their position and placing, and set that line to which
you will compare the other two lines, above, or beneath: you may use the same
demonstration which you had before. As for example.

Suppose that the lines AB and CD be parallels to the line OF: and let both the
lines AB and CD, be above, and let the line OF be beneath, and not in the
midst. Upon which let the right line GHK fall. And forasmuch as either of the
angles KHD and HGB is equal to the angle HKE, (for they are alternate angles)
therefore they are (by the first common sentence) equal the one to the other.
Wherefore (by the 28 proposition) the right lines AB and EF^ are paralles.

An objection.
But here if a man will object that the lines EK and KF, are parallels unto the
line CD, Answer.
and therefore are parallels the one to the other. We will answer that the
lines EK and KF are parts of one parallel line, and are not two parallel
lines. Parallel lines are understood to be produced infinitely.
For parallel lines ar understood to be produced infinitely But EK being
produced falls upon KF. Wherefor^ it is one and the self same with it, and
not an other. Wherefore all the parts of a parrallel line are parallels, both
to the right line unto which the whole parallel line is a parallel, and also to
all the parts of the same right line. As the line EK is a parallel unto HD, and
the line KE to the line CHAPTER For if they be produced infinitely, they will never
concur.

Howbeit there are some which like not, that two distinct parellel lines,
should be taken and counted for one parallel line: for that the continual
quantity, namely, the line is cut asonder, and cesseth to be one. Wherefore
they say, that there ought to be two distinct parallel lines compared to one.
And therefore they add to the proposition a correction, in this manner. Two
lines being parallels to one line: are either parallels the one the other, or
else the one is set directly against the other, so that if they be produced
they should make one right line. As for example.

Suppose that the lines CD and OF be parallels to one and the self same line
AB, and let them not be parallels the one to the other. Then I say, that the
two lines CD and OF, are directly set the one to the other. For for as much as
they are not parallel lines, let them concur in the point G, And from the
point G draw a line cutting the line AB in the point H. Now by the former
proposition the angles AHG and HGC are equal to two right angles, but by the
same proposition, the angle AHG, is equal to the alternate angle HGE.
Wherefore the angles HGC and HGF are equal to two right angles. Wherefore (by
the 14 proposition) the lines CG and FG are drawn directly and make one right
line. Wherefore also the lines CD and OF are set directly the one to the other:
and being produced they will make one right line.

The 10. Problem. The 31. Proposition. By a point given, to draw unto a right
line given, a parallel line.
SVppose that the point given be A, and let the right line given be BC. It is
required by the point given, namely A, to draw vuto the right line BC, a
parallel line. Construction.
Take in the line BC a point at all adventures, and let the same be D. and (by
the first peticio^) draw a right line from the point A, to the point D. And (by
the 23. proposition) upon the right line given AD, and to the point in it given
A, make an angle DAE, equal to the angle given ADC. And (by the 14.
proposition) put unto the line AE the line AF directly, in such sort that they
both make one right line. And forasmuch as the right line AD falling upon the
right lines BC and OF, does make the alternate angles, namely, EAD, and ADC
equal ye one to the other, therefore (by the 27. proposition) OF is a parallel
line to BC. Wherefore by the point given, namely A, is drawn to the right line
given BC a parallel line EAF: which was required to be done.

This proposition is to be understood of a point given without the line
given, and in such sort also, that the same line given being produced, do not
fall upon the point given.

The 22. Theoreme. The 32, Proposition. If one of the sides of any triangle be
produced: the outward angle that it makes, is equal to the two inward and
opposite angles. And the three inward angles of a triangle are equal to two
right angles.
SVppose y^ ABC be a triangle, and produce one of ye sides thereof namely, CB to
the point D. Then I say, that the outward angle ACD is equal to the two
inward and opposite angles CAB and ABC: and yt the three inward angles of the
triangle, that is, the angles ABC, BCA, and CAB are equal to two right angles.
Construction.
For (by the proposition going before) raise up from the point C, a parallel to
the right line AB, and let the same be CE. Demonstration.
And forasmuch as AB is a parallel to CE, and upon them falls the right line
AC: therefore the alternate angles BAC and ACE are equal the one to the other.
Again forasmuch as AB is a parallel unto CE, and upon them falls the right
line BD, therefore the outward angle ECD is (by the 29. proposition) equal to
the inward and opposite angle ABC. And it is proved that the angle ACE is equal
to the angle BAC: wherefore the whole outward angle ACD is equal to the two
inward and opposite angles, that is, to the angles BAC and ABC. Put the angle
ACB common to them both. Wherefore the angles ACD and ACB, are equal to these
three angles ABC, BCA, and BAC. But the angles ACD and ACB are equal to two
right angles (by the 13. proposition): wherefore the angles ACB, CBA, and CAB
are equal to two right angles. If therefore one of the sides of any triangle be
produced, the outward angle that it makes, is equal to the two inward and
opposite angles. And the three inward angles of a triangle are equal to two
right angles: which was required to be demonstrated.

Euclide demonstrateth either part of this composed Theoreme, by drawyng from
one angle of the triangle a parrallel line to one of the sides of the same
triangle, without the triangle. Either part thereof may also be proved without
drawyng of a parallel line without the triangle, only changing the order of
the things required or conclusions. For Euclide first proves that the
outward angle of a triangle (one of his sides being produced) is equal to the
two inward and opposite angles: and by that he proves the second part:
namely, that the 3. inward angles of a triangle are equal to two right angles.
But here it is contrariwise. For first is proved that the three inward angles
of a triangle are equal to two right angles, and by that is proved the other
part of the Theoreme, namely, that one side of a tria^gle being produced, the
outward angle is equal to the two inward and opposite angles. And that after
this manner.

Suppose that there be a triangle ABC^ An other demonstration.
and produce the side BC to the point E. And take in the line BC a point at al
auentures which let be F: and draw a line from A to F. And by the point F draw
unto the line AB a parallel line (by the former proposition) which let be FD.
Now forasmuch as FD is a parallel unto AB, and upon them falls the right
line AF, and also the right line BC, therefore the alternate angles are equal,
and also the outward angle is equal to the inward angle. Wherefore the whole
angle AFC is equal to the angles FAB and ABF. And by the same reason (if by
the point F we draw a parallel line to the line AC) may we prove that the angle
AFB is equal to the angles FAC, and ACF. Wherefore the two angles AFB and AFC
are equal to the three angles of the triangle ABC. But the two angles AFB and
AFC are (by the 13. proposition) equal to two right angles. Wherefore also the
three angles of the triangle ABC are equal to two right angles.

But the angles ACF and ACE are also (by the 13. proposition) equal to two
right angles. Take away the angle ACF which is common, wherefore the angle
remaining, namely, the outward angle ACE is equal to the two angles remaining,
namely, to the two inward and opposite angles ABC and CAB: which was required
to be proved.

Eudemus affirms, that the latter part of this Theoreme, The three angles of
a triangle are equal to two right angles, was first found out by Pithagoras,
The latter part of this Theoreme first ^ound out by Pithagoras.

The demon^tration thereof after him.


whose demonstration thereof is thus.

Suppose that there be a triangle ABC: and by point A, draw (by the former
proposition) unto the line BC, a parallel line, which let be DE. And forasmuch
as the right lines BC and DE are parallels, and upon them falls the right
lines AB and AC, therefore (by the 29. proposition) the alternate angles are
equal. Wherefore the angle DAB is equal to the angle ABC, and the angle EAC
to the angle ACB. Add the angle BAC common. Wherefore the angles DAB, BAC,
CAE, that is, the angles DAB and BAE, namely, two angles equal to two right
angles, are equal to the three angles of the triangle ABC. Wherefore the three
angles of a triangle are equal to two right angles: which was required to be
proved.

The converse of this proposition is thus.
If the outward angle of a triangle be equal to the two inward angles opposit^
against it: one of the sides of the triangles is produced, The converse of this
proposition.
and the line without the triangle, is drawn directly to the side of the
triangle, and makes one right line with it. And if the three inward angles of a
rectiline figure be equal to two right angles, the same rectiline figure is a
triangle.

Demonstration of the first part of the converse.
Suppose that there be a triangle ABC: and let the outward angle ACD be equal to
the two inward and opposite angles ABC and CAB. Then I say that the side BC is
produced to the point D. And that BCD is one right line. For forasmuch as the
angle ACD is equal to the two inward and opposite angles, add the angle ACB
common. Wherefore the angles ACD and ACB are equal to the three angles of the
triangle ABC. But the three angles of the triangle ABC are equal to two right
angles Wherefore also the two angles ACD and ACB are equal to two right
angles. But if unto a right line, and to a point in the same line be drawn two
right lines, not both on one and the same side, making the side angles equal to
two right angles: those two right lines shall be drawn directly, and make one
right line (by the 14. proposition.) Wherefore the right line BC is drawn
directly to the line CD, and so is BCD one right line: which was required to be
proved.

Demonstration of the second part of the converse.
Again suppose that there be a certain rectiline figure ABC, having only
three ang^es, namely, at the points A, B, C: which angles let be equal to two
right angles Then I say that ABC is a triangle. First AC is one right line. For
draw the line BD. And forasmuch as in either of the triangles ABD and DBC, the
three angles are equal to two right angles, of which the angles at the points
A, B, C, are equal to two right angles. Wherefore the angles remaining, namely,
ADB and CDB are equal to two right angles. Wherefore (by the 14. proposition)
the line DC is set directly to the line DA. Wherefore the side AC is one right
