line. And in like sort may we prove that the side AB is one right line, and
also that the side BC is one right line. Wherefore the figure ABC is a
triangle: which was required to be proved.

A Corrollary.
By the second part of this 29. proposition, namely, three angles of a triangle
are equal to two right angles, may easily be known, to how many right angles,
the angles within any figure having right lines and many angles are equal. As
are figures of four angles, of five angles, of six angles, and so
consequently: and infinitely, And this is to be noted, that every right lined
figure is resolved into triangle, For that a triangle is the first of all
figures. Every right lined figure is resolved in triangles.

A triangle is the first of all figures.

Into how many triangles a figure may be resolved.


For two lines accomplish no figures VVher^ore how many sides the figure has,
into so many triangles may it be resolved, saving two. As if the figure have
four sides, it is resolved into two triangles, if it have five sides, into 3.
triangles: if 6 sides into 4. triangles, and so consequently, and infinitely.
And it is proved that the three angles of every triangle are equal to two
right angles. Wherefore if you multiply the number of the triangles, into
which the figure is resolved, by two, you shall have the number of right
angles, to which the angles of the figure are equal. So the angles of every
qua^rangled figure are equal to 4. right angles. For it is composed of two
triangles. And the angles of a five angled figure are equal to 6. right angles,
for it is composed of three triangles, and so forth in like order.

The rediest and aptest manner to reduce any rectiline figure into triangles, is
thus. From any one angle of the figure to every other angle (of the same) being
opposite unto it, draw a right line, so shall you have all the triangles of
that figure described. In a quadra^gle, from one angle you can draw but one
line to the opposite angle, by which it is divided into two triangles only. In
a pentagon figure, from one angle you may draw lines to two opposite angles,
and so you shall have three triangles. In an Hexagon, you may from one angle
draw lines to three opposite angles, and so shall you have 4. triangles. In an
heptagon, from one angle may be drawn lines to four opposite angles, and so
shall there be five triangle. And so consequently of the rest. As you see in the
figures here set.

This thing may also be thus expressed. In any figure of many sides, An other
way to know the number of right angles unto which the angles of any figure are
^quall.
the number of the angles of the figure doubled, is the number of the right
angles to which the angles of the figure are equal, saving four, As for
example.

Let there be an hexagon figure ABCDEF, and within it take a point at all
auentures, namely, G. And draw from the same point to every one of the angles a
right line, and so shall there be comprehended in the figure so many triangles,
as there are angles in the same. Wherefore by this 32. proposition all the
angles of these triangles taken together, are equal to double so many right
angles, as there be angles in the figure. Wherefore forasmuch as there are
six triangles, there are twelve right angles. But all the angles at the point
G are equal to 4. right angles by the 13. proposition. Wherefore take away
four out of twelve, and there rest eight. Wherefore the six angles in the
Hexagon figure are equal to eight right angles.

By that which has now been declared, Another expression of the former
Corollary.
it follows that all the angles of any figure having many sides, taken
together, are equal to twice so many right angles, as the figure is in the reaw
or order of figures. A tria^gle is the first figure in order, A triangle the
first figure in order.
and^ his angles are equal to two right angles, which are twice one. A
quadrangle is the second figure in order. A quadrangle the second, and so
consequently. How the order of figures is gathered.
Wherefore his angles are equal to four right angles, which are twice two. The
order of figures is gathered of the sides. For if you take two from the number
of the sides of a figure, the number of the sides remaining, is the number of
the order of the figure. As if you will know, how many in order is a figure of
six sides: from six (which is the number of this sides) take a way two, and
there will remain four. Wherefore a figure of six sides is the fourth figure
in the order of figures. Then double four, so shall you have eight. Wherefore
the angles thereof are equal to eight right angles. And so of all other figures.

An other Corrollary.
Hereby also it is manifest, that the outward angles of any figure of many sides
taken together, are equal to four right angles. For the inward angles
together with the outward angles, are equal to twice so many right angles, as
there be angles in the figure (by the 13. proposition) But the inward angles
are equal to twice so many right angles, as there be angles in the figure,
saving foure^ as it was before declared. Wherefore the outward angles are
always equal to four right angles. As for example.

Suppose that there be a pentagon, ABCDE. And produce the five sides thereof to
the points F, G, H, K, L. Now (by the 13. proposition) the two angles at the
point A shall be equal to two rightangles. And (by the same) the two angles at
the point B shall be also equal to two right angles. And so taking every two
angles, they shall be in all equal to ten right angles. Wherefore taking
away the inward angles, which (as has before been proved) are equal to six
right angles, the outward angles shall be equal to four right angles. And so
of all other figures^

An other Corrollary.
It is also manifest, that every pentago^, which is so described, that each side
thereof deuideth two of the other sides, has his five angles equal to two
right angles.

For suppose that ABCDE: be such a pentagon as is there required so that let
the side AC cut the side BE in the point G: and let the side AD, cut the same
side BE in the point F. Now the^ by this proposition the angle AFG shall be
equal to the two angles at the point B and D: namely, the outward angle to the
two inward and opposite angles. And by the same reason the angle FGA is equal
to the angles at the points C and E which are in the triangle CEG. But the two
angles AFG and FGA, together with the angle at the point A, are equal to two
right angles (by this proposition). Wherefore the four angles at the points,
B, C, D, E, together with the angle at the point A, are equal to two right
angles: which was required to be proved.

An other Corrollary.
By this proposition also it is manifest, that every angle of an equilate
triangle is two third parts of a right angle. And that in a triangle of two
equal sides having a right angle at the top, either of the the two angles at
the base is the half of a right angle. And in a triangle called Sealenum, such
a Scalenu^ (I say) which is made by the drawght of a perpendicular line from
any one of the angles of an equilater tria^gle to the opposite side thereof, one
angle is a right angle, an other is two third parts of a right angle, namely,
that angle which was also an angle of the equilater triangle, wherefore of
necessity the angle remaining is one third part of a right angle. For the three
angles of a tria^gle must be equal to two right angles.

An other Corrallory.
Moreover by this proposition it is manifest, that if there be two triangles,
and if two angles of the one be equal to two angles of the other: the angle
remaining shall also be equal to the angle remaining. For forasmuch as three
angles of any triangle are equal to three angles of any other triangle (for
that in each the three angles are equal to two right angles)^ If from each
triangle be taken away the two equal angles, the angle remaining shall (by the
3. common sentence) be equal to the angle remaining.

And here I think it good to show how to divide a right angle into three
equal parts, for that the demonstration thereof depends of this proposition.

Suppose that there be a right angle ABC, contained of the right lines AB and
BC: How to divide ^ right angle into three equal parts.
and in the line BC, take a point at all adventures, which let be D. An^ upon
the line BD describe (by the first) an equilater triangle BDE. And (by the 9.
proposition) divide the angle DBE into two equal parts by the right line BF.
Then I say that the right angle ABC is divided into three equal parts by the
right lines BE and BF. For forasmuch as EBD is an equilater triangle, therefore
as hath^ before been declared, the angle EBD is two third parts of a right
angle. But the whole angle ABC, is a right angle. Wherefore the angle remaining,
namely, ABE is one third part of a right angle. Again forasmuch as the angle
EBD, is two third parts of a right angle, and it is divided into two equal
parts by the right line BF, therefore either of these two angles EBF and FBD is
one third part of a right angle. Wherefore the three angles ABE, EBF and FBD
are equal the one to the other. Wherefore the right angle ABC is divided into
three equal parts by the right lines BE and BF: which was required to be done.

The 23. Theoreme. The 33. Proposition. Two right lines joining together on one
and the same side, two equal parallel lines: are also them selves equal the
one to the other, and also parallels.
SVppose that AB and CD be right lines equal, and parallels: and let these two
right lines AC and BD join the^ together, the one on the one side, and the
other on ye other side. Then I say that the lines AC and BD are both equal,
and also parallels. Draw (by the first peticion) a right line from the point B
to the point C. D^^on^^ratio^.
And forasmuch as AB is a parallel to CD, and upon them falls the right line
BC, therefore the alternate angles ABC and BCD, are equal the one to the other
(by the 29. proposition). And forasmuch as the line AB is equal to the line
CD, and the line BC is common to them both, therefore these two lines AB and
BC, are equal to these two lines BC and CD, and the angle ABC is equal to the
angle BCD. Wherefore (by the 4. proproposition) the base BD is equal to the
base AC, and the triangle ABC, is equal to the triangle BCD, and the angles
remaining are equal to the angles remaining the one to the other, under which
are subtended equal sides, wherefore the angle ACB is equal to the angle CBD,
and the angle BAC to the angle BDC. And forasmuch as upon these right lines AC
and BD falls the right line BC making the alternate angles, that is the
angles ACB and CBD, equal the one to the other, therefore (by the 27.
proposition) the line AC is a parallel to the line BD. And it is proved that it
is equal unto it. Wherefore two right lines joining together on one and the
same side two equal lines which are parallels, are also themselves equal the
one to the other, and also parallels: which was required to be proved.

The 24. Theoreme. The 34 Proposition. In parallelogrammes, the sides and
angles which are opposite the one to the other, are equal the one to the
other, and their diameter deuideth them into two equal parts.
SVppose that ABCD be a parallelogramme and let the diameter ther^ of be BC.
Then I say that the opposite sides and angles of the parallelogramme ACDB are
equal the one to the other, and yt the diameter BC deuideth it into two equal
parts. Demonstration
For forasmuch as AB is a parallel line unto CD, and upon them falls a right
line BC: therefore (by the 29. proposition) the alternate angles ABC and BCD are
equal the one to the other. Again forasmuch as AC is a parallel line to BD,
and upon them falls the right line BC: therefore (by the same) the alternate
angles, that is, the angles ACB and CBD are equal the one to the other. Now
therefore there are two triangles ABC and BCD, having two angles of the one,
namely, the angles ABC and ACB equal to two angles of the other, that is, to
the angles BCD and CBD, the one to the other, and one side of the one equal to
one side of the other, namely, that side that lies between the equal angles,
which side is common to them both, namely, the side BC. Wherefore (by the 26.
proposition) the other sides remaining are equal to the other sides remaining,
the one to the other, and the angle remaining is equal to the angle remaining.
Wherefore the side AB is equal to the side CD, and the side AC to the side BD,
and the angle BAC is equal to the angle BDC. And for as much as the angle ABC is
equal to the angle BCD, and the angle CBD to the angle ACB: therefore (by the
second common sentence) the whole angle ABD is equal to the whole angle ACD.
And it is proved that the angle BAC is equal to the angle CDB. Wherefore in
parallelogrammes, the sides and angles which are opposite are equal the one to
the other. I say also that the diameter thereof deuideth it into two equal
parts. For forasmuch as AB is equal to CD, and BC is common to them both,
therefore these two AB and BC are equal to these two BC and CD, and the angle
ABC is equal to the angle BCD. Wherefore (by the 4. proposition) the base AC is
equal to the base BD, and the triangle ABC is equal to the triangle BCD.
Wherefore the diameter BC deuideth the parallelogramme ABCD into two equal
parts: which is all that was required to be proved.

In this Theoreme^ are demonstrated three passions or properties of
parallelogrammes. Three passions of parallolegrames demo^strated in this Thoreme.
Namely, that their opposite sides are equal: that their opposite angles are
equal: and that the diameter deuideth the parallelogramme into two equal
parts. Which is true in all kinds of parallelogrammes. There are four
kinds of parallelogrammes, Four kinds of parallelogrammes.
a square, a ^igure of one side longer then the other, a Rhombus, or diamond
figure, and a Rhom^oides or diamondlike figure. And here is to be noted, that
in those parallelogrammes, all whose angles ar right angles (as is a square,
and a figure on the one side longer) the diameters do not only divide the
figure into two equal parts, but also they are equal the one to the other. As
for example.

Suppose that ABCD be a square, or a figure on the one side longer, and draw in
it these diametres AD and BC. And forasmuch as the line AB is equal to the
line CD (by the definition of a square, and of a figure on the also one side
longer) and the line AC is common to the both: therefore two sides of the
triangle ABC are equal to two sides of the triangle ACD, the one to the other,
and the angles which they contain are equal, namely, the angles BAC and ACD,
for they are rightangles. Wherefore the bases namely, the diameters AD and BC,
are (by the 4. proposition) equal.

But in those parallelogrames whose angles are not right angles, as is a
Rhombus, and a ^homboides, the diameters be ever unequal. As for example.

Suppose that ABCD he a Rhombus, or a Rhombaides and draw in it these
diameters AC and BD. And forasmuch as AB is equal to CD and BC is common to
them both, and the angle ABC is not equal to the angle BCD (by the definition
of a Rhombus and also of a Rhombaides) therefore (by the 24. proposition) the
bases also are unequal, namely, the diameters AC and BD.

Again. In parallelogrammes of equal sides, as are a square, and a Rhombus,
the diameters do not only divide the figures into two equal parts, but also
they divide the angles into two equal parts.

For suppose that there be a square or Rhombus ABCD, and draw the diameter AD.
And forasmuch as the sides AB and BD are equal to the sides AC and CD (for the
figures are equilater) and the angles ABD and ACD are equal (for they are
opposite angles) and the base AD is common to both triangles. Therefore (by the
fourth proposition) the angles BAD and CAD are equal, and so also are the
angles BDA and CDA equal. Wh^^fore the angles BAC and CDB are divided into two
equal parts.

But in parallogrammes whose sides are not equal, such as are a figure on the
one side longer, and a Rhomboides it is not so.

For suppose ABCD to be a figure on the one side longer or a Romboides. And
draw the diameter AD. And now if the angles BAC and CDB, be divided into two
equal parts by the diameter AD, then forasmuch as the angle. CAD is (by the
29. proposition) equal to the angle ADB, the angle also BAD shall be equal to
the angle ADB (by the first common sentence). Wherefore also the side AB is
equal to the side BD (by the 6. proposition). But the said sides are unequal:
which is impo^^ible. Wherefore the angles BAC and CDB are not divided into two
equal parts.

The converse of th^^ proposition after Pr^^lus.
The converse of the first and second part of this proposition after Proclus. Is
(...) figure whatsoever have his opposite sides and angles equal: then is a
parallelograms.

For suppose that ABCD be such a figure, namely, which has his opposite sides
and angles equal. And let the diameter thereof be AD. Now forasmuch as the
sides AB and BD are equal to to the sides DC and AC, and the angles which they
co^tayne are equal, and the base AD is common to each triangle, therefore (by
the 4. proposition) the angles remaining are equal to the angles remaining,
under which are subtended equal sides. Wherefore the angle BAD is equal to the
angle ADC, and the angle ADB to the angle CAD. Wherefore (by the 27.
proposition) the line AB is a parallel to the line CD, and the line AC to the
line BD. Wherefore the figure ABCD is a parallogramme: which was required to be
proved.

A Corollary taken out of Flussates.
A Corrollary taken out of Flussates.
A right line cutting a parallelogramme which way soever into two equal
parts, shall also divide the diameter thereof into two equal parts.

For if it be possible let the right line GC divide the parallelogramme AEBD
into two equal parts, but let it divide the diameter DE into two unequal
parts in the point I. And let the part IE be greater then the part ID. And
unto the line ID put the line IO equal (by th3. proposition). Demonstration
leading to (...) absurdi^^e.
And by the point O, draw unto the lines AD and BE a parallel line OF (by the
31. proposition.) Wherefore in the triangles FOI and CDI, two angles of the one
are equal to two angles of the other, namely, the angles IOF and IDC (by the
29. proposition), and the angles FIO and CID (by the 15. proposition), and the
side ID is equal to the side IO. Wherefore (by the 26. proposition) the
triangles are equal. Wherefore the whole triangle EIG is greater then the
triangle DIC. And forasmuch as the trapesium GBDC is supposed to be the half
of the parrallelograme, and the half of the same parallelograme is the
triangle EBD (by this proposition). From the trapesium GBDC and the triangle
EBD which are equal, take away the trapesium GBDI which is common to them
both, and the residue namely, the triangle DIC shall be equal to the residue,
namely, to the tria^gle EIG: but it is also less (as has before ben proved):
which is impossible. Wherefore a right line dividing a parallelogramme into two
equal parts, shall not divide the diameter thereof unequally. Wherefore it
shall divide it equally: which was required to be proved.

An addition of Pelitarius.
Between two right lines being infinite and making an angle given: An addition
o^ Pelitarius.
to place a line equal to a line given, in such sort, that it shall make with
one of those lines an angle equal to an other angle given. Now it behooves
that the two angles given be less then two right angles.

Suppose that there be two lines AB and AC, making an angle given BAC: and let
them be infinite on that side where they open one from the other. And let the
line given be D, and let the other angle given be E. And let the two angles A
and E be less then two right angles (otherwise there could not be made a
triangle, as it is manifest by the 17 proposition). It is required between the
lines AB and AC to place a line equal to the line given D, which with one of
them as for example with the line AC, Construction.
may make an angle equal to the angle given E. Now then upon the line AC and to
the point in it A, make an angle equal to the angle given E (by the 23.
proposition), which let be CAF. And produce the line FA on the other side of
the point A to the point G: and let AG be equal to the line given D (by the 3.
proposition). And by the point G, draw (by the 31. proposition) a parallel line
to the line AC, which let be GH, and produce it until it concur with the line
AB: which concurse let be in the point H. And again by the point H draw the
line HK parallel unto the line GF: which let cut the line AC in the point K.
Then I say that the line HK is placed between the lines AB and AC and is equal
to the line D. And that the angle at the point K is equal to the angle given
E. Demonstration
For forasmuch as (by construction) AGHK is a parallelogramme the line KH is
equal to the line AG (by this proposition). Wherefore also it is equal to the
line D. And forasmuch as the line AK fall^th upon the two parallel lines, FG
and KH, therefore the angle AKH is equal to the angle FAK (by the 29.
proposition) for that they are alternate angles. Wherefore also the same angle
at the point K is equal to the angle given E. Wherefore the line HK being
placed between the two lines AB and AC and being equal to the line D^ makes
the angle at the point K equal to the angle given E: which was required to be
done.

Though this addition of Pelitarius be not so much pertaining to the
proposition: yet because it is witty and seems somewhat difficult, I thought
it good here to anexe it.

The 25. Theoreme. The 35. Proposition. Parallelogrammes consisting upon one
and the same base, and in the self same parallel lines, are equal the one to
the other.
SVppose that these parallelogrammes ABCD and EB CF do consist upon one and the
same base, that is, upon BC, and in the self same parallel lines, that is AF,
and BC. Then I say, that the parallelograme ABCD is equal to the parallelograme
EBCF. Demonstration.
For forasmuch as ABCD is a parallelogramme, therefore (by the 34. proposition)
the side AD, is equal to the side BC, and by the same reason also the side OF
is equal to the side BC, wherefore AD is equal to OF: and DE is common to them
both. Wherefore the whole line AE is equal to the whole line DF. And the side
AB is equal to ye side DC: wherefore these two EA and AB are equal to these
two FD and DC, the one to the other: and ye angle FDC is equal to the angle
EAB, namely, the outward angle to ye inward angle (by ye ^9. proposition):
wherefore (by ye 4 proposition) the base EB is equal to the base FC, and the
triangle EAB is equal to the triangle FDC. Take away the triangle DGE, which
is common to them both. Wherefore the residue, namely, the trapesium ABGD is
equal to the residue, that is, to the trapesium EGCF. Put the triangle GBC
common to them both. Wherefore the whole parallelogramme ABCD is equal to the
whole parallelogramme EBCF. Wherefore parallelogrammes consisting upon one and
the same base, and in the self same parallel lines, are equal the one to the
other: which was required to be demonstrated.

Parallelogrammes are said to be in the self same parallel lines, when their
bases, and the opposite sides unto them, are one and the self same lines with
the parallels.

Three cases in this proposition.

The first case.


In this proposition are three cases. For the line BE may cut the line AF,
either beyond the point D, or in the point D, or on this side the point D. When
it cutteth the line AF beyond the point D the demonstration before put serves.

But if the line BE do cut the line AF in the point D, The second case.
then forasmuch as (by the former proposition) the triangle BCD or BCE is the
half of either of these para^lelogrammes ABCD and EBCF (for in the
parallelogramme ABCD the diameter BD makes the triangle BD C the half of the
same parallelogramme, and in the parallelogramme EBCF the diameter EC or DC
makes the self same triangle BDC the half of the parallelograme EBCF)
therefore (by the 7. common sentence) the parallelogrammes ABCD and EBCF are
equal.

But if the live BE do cut the line AF on this side the point D, The third
case.
then forasmuch as either of the lines AD and OF is equal to the line BC,
therefore by the first common sentence they are equal the one to the other.
Wherefore taking away ED, which is common to both, the residue AE shall be equal
to the residue DF. Again forasmuch as (by the 34. proposition) the line AB is
equal to the line CD, and (by the ^7. proposition) the angle EAB is equal to
the angle FDC: therefore (by the 4. proposition) the triangles EBA and FCD are
equal. Add the trapesium CDEB common to them both: and so (by the second
common sentence) the two parallelogrammes ABCD and EBCF shall be equal: which
was required to be proved.

The 26. Theoreme. The 36. Proposition. Parallelogrammes consisting upon equal
bases, and in the self same parallel lines, are equal the one to the other.
SVppose that these parallelogrammes ABCD and EFGH do consist upon equal
bases, that is, upon BC and FG, and in the self same parallel lines, that is,
AH and BG. Then I say, that the parallelogramme ABCD is equal to the
parallelogramme EFGH. Construction.
Draw a right line from the point B to the point E, and an other from the point
C to the point H. Demonstration
And forasmuch as BC is equal to FG, but FG is equal to EH, therefore BC also
is equal to EH, and they are parallel lines, and the lines BE and CH join
them together: but two right lines ioynyng together two equal right lines
being parallels, are themselves also (by the 33 proposition) equal the one to
the other, and parallels. Wherefore EBCH is a parallelogramme, and is equal to
the parallelograme ABCD for they have both one and ye same base, that is, BC.
And are in ye self same parallel lines, that is, BC and EH. And by ye same
reason also the parallelograme EFGH is equal to the parallelograme EBCH.
Wherefore the parallelograme ABCD is equal to the parallelograme EFGH.
Wherefore parallelogrames consisting upon equal bases, and in the self same
parrallel lines, are equal the one to the other: which was required to be
proved.

Three cases in this proposition.
In this proposition also are three cases. For the equal bases may either be
utterly separated a sonder: or they may touch a^ one of the ends: or they may
have one part common to them both.

The first case.
Euclides demonstration serves when the bases be utterly separated a sonder.
Which yet may happen seven diverse ways. Every case may happen seven diverse
ways.
For the bases being separated a so^der, their opposite sides also may be
utterly separated a sonder beyond the point D, as the sides AD and EH in the
first figure.



both, as in the third figure, the sides AD and EH have the part ED common to
them both.

Or they may justly agree the one with the other, that is, the points A and D

Or the side AD being produced on this side the point A, part of the opposite

Or one end of the side EH may light upon the point A, and the whole side

Or the said side EH may utterly be separated a sonder on this side the point

And the two other cases also may in like manner have seven variet^es: The like
variety in each of the other two cases.
as in the figures here underneath and on the other side of this leaf set it is
manifest. And here is to be noted, that in these three cases and in all their
varieties also, Euclides construction and demostration serves in all these
cases, and in their varities also.
the construction and demonstration put by Euclide (namely, the drawing of
lines from the point B to the point E and from the point C to the point H, and
so proving it by the former proposition) will serve only in the fourth
variety of each case, there needs no farther construction: for that the
conclusion straight way follows by the former proposition.



The 27. Theoreme. The 37. Proposition. Triangles consisting upon one and the
self same base, and in the self same paralles: are equal the one to the
other.
SVppose that these triangles ABC and DBC do consist upon one and the same
base, namely, BC, and in the self same parallel lines, that is, AD and BC.
Then I say, that the triangle ABC is equal to the triangle BDC. Construction.
Produce (by the 2. peticion) the line AD on each side to the points E and F.
And (by the 31. proposition) by the point B, draw unto the line CA a parallel
line BE and (by ye same) by the point C, draw unto the line BD a parallel line
CF. Demonstration.
Wherefore EBCA. and DBCF are parallelogrammes. And the parallelogramme EBCA,
is (by the 35. proposition) equal to the parallelogramme DBCF. For they
consist upon one and the self same base, namely, BC, and are in the self
same parallel lines, that is, BC and OF. But the triangle ABC is (by the 34.
proposition) the half of the parallelogramme EBCA, for the diameter AB
deuideth it into two equal parts: and (by the same) the triangle DBC is the
half of the parallelogramme DBCF, for the diameter DC deuideth it into two
equal parts: but the halues of things equal are also equal the one to the
other (by the 7. common sentence), wherefore ehe triangle ABC is equal to the
triangle DBC Wherefore triangles consisting upon one and the self same base,
and in the self same parallels: are equal the one to the other: which was
required to be demonstrated.

Those triangles are said to be contained within the self same parallel
lines, How triangles are said to be in the self same parallel lines.
which having their bases in one of the parallel lines, have their ^oppes in
the other.

Here as I promised will I show out of Proclus the comparison of two triangles,
which having their sides equal, have the bases and angles at the top
v^equall. Comparison of two triangles whose sides being equal, their bases and
angles at the top are unequal.
And first I say that the unequal angles at the top being equal to two
right angles, the triangles shall be equal. As for example.

Suppose that these two triangles ABC and DEF have two sides of the one,
namely, AB and AC, equal to two sides of the other, namely, to DE and DF, each
to his correspondent side, When the two angles at the tops are equal to two
right angles.
that is, AB to DE, and AC to DF, and let the base BC be greater then the base
OF: and let the angle at the point A be greater then the angle at the point D.
But let the said angles at the points A and D, be equal to two right angles.
Then I say that the triangles ABC and D OF are equal. For forasmuch as the
angle BAC is greater then the angle ED F, upon the line ED, and to the point D
describe (by the 23. proposition) an angle equal to the angle BAC, which let
be EDG: and put the line DG equal to the line AC: and draw a line from E to G,
and an other from F to G: and produce the lines ED and FD beyond the point D to
the points H and K. Now forasmuch as the angle BAC is equal to the angle EDG,
and the angles BAC and EDF are equal to two right angles, therefore the angles
EDG and EDF are equal to two right angles. But the angles EDG and KDG, are
also equal to two right angles: take away the angle FDG common to them both:
wherefore the angle remaining EDF is equal to the angle remaining GDK. But the
angle EDF is equal to the angle HDK (by the 15. proposition) for they are head
angles. Wherefore the angle GDK is equal to the angle HDK. And forasmuch as in
the triangle GDF the outward angle GDH is (by the 32. proposition) equal to the
two inward and opposite angles at the points G and F: which two angles also are
(by the 5. proposition) equal the one to the other: for the line DG is by
construction equal to the line AC, namely, to the line DF. Wherefore the angle
GDH is double both to the angle at the point G, and to the angle at the point
F. But the angle GDH is also double to the angle GDK (for the angle GDK is
proved to be equal to the angle KDH) wherefore the angle at DGF is equal to
the angle GDK: and they are alternate angles. Wherefore (by the 27.
proposition) the line D^ is a parallel to the line FG. Wherefore the triangles
GDE and FDE are upon one and the self same base, namely, DE, and in the self
same parallel lines: DE and GF. Wherefore by this proposition they are equal.
But the triangle GDE is by construction equal to the triangle ABC. Wherefore
also the triangle DEF is equal to the triangle ABC: which was required to be
proved.

But now let the angles BAC and EDF be greater then two right angles: When they
are greater the^ two right angles.
and let the angle at the point A be greater then the angle at the point D, as
it was before. The^ I say that the triangle ABC is le^se then the triangle DEF.
Let the same construction be here that was in the former. And forasmuch as the
angles BAC and EDF, that is, the angles EDG and EDF are greater then two right
angles, but the angles EDG and GDK are equal to two right angles: take away
the angle FDG which is common to them both. Wherefore the angle remaining,
namely, EDF is greater the^ the angle remaining, namely, then GDK: that is, the
angle KDH (which by the 15. proposition is equal to the angle EDF) is greater
then the angle GDK, wherefore the angle GDH is more then double to the angle
GDK: but the angle GDH is double to the angle DGF, as was before proved.
Wherefore the angle GDK is less then the angle DGF. Unto the angle GDK put (by
the 23. proposition) the angle DGL equal: and produce the line GL till it
concur with the line OF in the point L. And draw a line from D to L.
Wherefore (by the 27. proposition) GL is a parallel line to DE, for that the
alternate angles DGL and GDK are equal. Wherefore the triangles GDE and LDE are
(by this proposition) equal (for they consist upon one and the self same base,
namely, DE, and are in the self same parallel lines, namely, ED and GL) But
the triangle LDE is less then the triangle FDE, Wherefore also the triangle GDE
is less the^ the triangle FDE. But the triangle GDE is equal to the triangle
ABC. Wherefore the triangle ABC is less then the triangle DEF: which was
required to be proved.

When they are less then two right angles.
But now let the angles BAC and EDF be less then two right angles: and again
let the angle at the point A be greater then the angle at the point D. Then I
say that the tria^gle ABC is greater then the triangle DEF. Let the same
constructio^ be also here that was in the two former. And forasmuch as the
angles BAC and EDF, that is, the angles EDG and EDF, are less then two right
angles, but the angles EDG and GDK are equal to two right angles, take away the
angle FDG which is common to them both, wherefore the angle remaining, namely,
EDF is less then the angle remaining, namely, then GDK: that is, the angle HDK
(which by the 1^. proposition is equal to the angle ED F) is less then the
angle GDK. Wherefore the whole angle GD H is less then double to the angle GD
K. But it is double to the angle DGF (as before it was proved): wherefore the
angle GD K is greater then the angle DGF. Put the angle DGL equal to the angle
GD K (by the 23. proposition) and produce the line GL till it concur with the
line OF also produced^ and let the concurse be in the point L. And draw a line
from D to L. And for as much as the angle D GL is equal to the angle GD K, and
they are alternate angles, therefore the line GL is a parallel to D E (by the
27. proposition). Wherefore (by this proposition) the triangles GD E and LD E
are equal: but the triangle LDE is greater then the triangle FD E, and the
triangle GD E is equal to the triangle ABC. Wherefore the triangle ABC is
greater then the triangle D OF: which was required to be proved.

The 28. Theoreme. The 38. Proposition. Triangles which consist upon equal
bases, and in the self same parallel lines, are equal the one to the other.
SVppose that these triangles ABC and DEF do consist upon equal bases, that is,
upon BC and OF, and in the self same parallel lines, that is BF and AD. Then I
say that the triangle ABC is equal to the triangle ABC is equal to the
triangle DEF. Construction.
Produce (by the second peticion) the line AD on each side to the points G and
H. And (by the 31. proposition) by the point B draw unto CA a parallel line
BG, and (by the same) by the point F draw unto DE a parallel line FH.
Demonstration.
Wherefore GBCA and DEFH are parallelogrammes. But the parallelograme GBCA is
(by the 36 proposition) equal to the parallelogramme DEFH, for they consist
upon equal bases, that is, BC and OF, and are in the self same parallel
lines, that is, BF and GH. But (by the 34. proposition) the triangle ABC is the
half of the parallelogramme GBCA, for the diameter AB deuideth it into two
equal parts: and the triangle DEF is (by the same) the half of the
parallelogramme DEFH, for the diameter FD deuideth it into two equal parts.
But the halues of things equal are (by the 7. common sentence) equal ^he one
to the other. Wherefore the triangle ABC is equal to the triangle DEF.
Wherefore triangles which consist upon equal bases, and in the self same
parallel lines, are equal the one to the other: which was required to be
proved.

In this proposition are three cases. Three cases in this proposition.
For the bases of the triangles either have one part common to them both or the
base of the one touches the base of the other only in a point: or their bases
are utterly severed a sunder. And each of these cases may also be diversely, Each
of these cases also may be diversely.
as we before have seen in parallelogrammes consisting on equal bases, and
being in the self same parallel lines. So that he which diligently notes the
variety that was there put touching them, may also easily frame the same
variety to each case in this proposition. Wherefore I think it nedeles here
to repeat the same again: for how soever the bases be put, or the tops, the
manner of construction and demonstration here put by Euclide will serve:
namely, to draw parallel lines to the sides.

An addition of Pelitarius.
To divide a triangle given into two equal parts.

Suppose that the triangle given to be divided in to two equal parts be ABC.
An addition of Pelitarius, to divide a triangle into two equal parts.
Divide one of the sides thereof, namely, BC into two equal parts (by the 10.
proposition) in the point D. And draw a line from the point D to the point A.
The^ I say that the two triangles ABD and ACD, are equal, which is easy to
prove (by the 38. proposition) if by the point A we draw unto the line BC a
paral^el line (by the 31. proposition), which let by HK: for so the triangles
AB D and ADC, consisting upon equal bases BD and DC, and being in the self
same parallel lines HK and BC are of necessity equal. The self same thing
also will happen if the side BA be divided into two equal parts in the point E,
and so be drawn a right line from the point E, to the point C. Or if the side
AC be divided into two equal parts in the point F, and so be drawn a right
line from the point F to the point B: which is in like manner proved by drawing
parallel lines by the points B, and C, to the lines BA and AC,

Note.
And so by this you may divide any triangle into so many parts as are signified
by any number that is euenly even: as into 14.16.32.64. etc.

An other addition of Pelitarius. An other addition of Pelitarius.

From any point given in one of the sides of a triangle, to draw a line which
shall divide the triangle into two equal parts.

Let the triangle given be BCD: and let the point given in the side BC be A. It
is required from the point A to draw a line which shall divide the triangle BCD
into two equal parts. Construction.
Divide the side BC into two equal parts in the point E. And draw a right
line from the point A to the point D. And (by the 31. proposition) by the point
E draw unto the line AD a parallel line OF: which let cut the side DC in the
point F. And draw a line from the point A to the point F. Then I say that the
line AF deuideth the triangle BCD into two equal parts: namely, the trapesium
ABDF is equal to the triangle ACF. For draw a line from E to D, Demonstration
cutting the line AF in the point G. Now then it is manifest (by the 38.
proposition) that the two triangles BED and CED are equal (if we understand a
line to be drawn by the point D parallel to the line BC, for the bases BE and
EC are equal). The two triangles also D OF and AEF are (by the 37. proposition)
equal: for they consist upon one and the self same base OF, and are in the
self same parallel lines AD and OF. Wherefore taking away the triangle EFG
which is common to the^ both, the triangle AEG shall be equal to the triangle D
FG: wherefore unto either of the^ add the trapesiu^ CFGE, and the triangle ACF
shall be equal to the triangle DEC. But the triangle DEC is the half part of the
whole triangle BCD wherefore the triangle ACF is the half part of the same
triangle BCD. Wherefore the residue, namely, the trapesium ABFD is the other
half of the same triangle. Wherefore the line AF deuideth the whole triangle
BCD into two equal parts: which was required to be done.

The 29. Theoreme. The 39. Proposition. Equal triangles consisting upon one
and the same base, and on one and the same side: are also in the self same
parallel lines.
SVppose that these two equal triangles ABC and DBC do consist upon one and
the same base, namely, BC and on one and the same side. The^ I say that they
are in the self same parallel lines. Draw a right line from the point A to
the point D. Now I say that AD is a parallel line to BC. For if not, then (by
the 31. proposition) by the point A draw unto the right line BC a parallel
line AE, and draw a right line from the point E to the point C. Wherefore ye
triangle EBC is (by ye 37. proposition) equal to the triangle ABC, for they
consist upon one and the self same base, namely, BC, and are in ye self same
parallels, that is, AE and BC. But the triangle DBC is (by supposition) equal
to the triangle ABC^ Wherefore the triangle DBC is equal to the triangle EBC,
the greater unto the less: which is impossible. Wherefore the line AE, is not
a parallel to the line BC. And in like sort may it be proved that no other
line besides AD is a parallel line to BC, wherefore AD is a parallel line to
BC. Wherefore equal triangles consisting upon one and the same base, and on
one and the same side, are also in the self same parallel lines: which was
required to be proved.

This proposition is the converse of the 37. proposition. This Theoreme the
converse of the 37. proposition.
And here is to be noted that if by the point A, you draw unto the line BC a
parallel line, the same shall of necessity either light upon the point D, or
under it, or above it. If it light upon it, then is that manifest which is
required: but if it light under it, then follows that absurdity which Euclide
puts, namely, that the greater triangle is equal to the less: which self
same absurdity also will follow, if it fall above the point D. As for example.

Suppose that these equal triangles ABC and D BC do consist upon one and the
self same base BC, and on one and the same side. Then I say, that they are in
the self same parallel lines, and that a right line joining together their
tops is a parallel to the base BC. Draw a right line from A to D. Now if this
be not a parallel to the base BC, let AE be a parallel unto it, and let AE fall
without the line AD. And produce the line BD till it concur with the line AE
in the point E and draw a line from E to C. Wherefore the triangle ABC is equal
to the triangle EBC: but the triangle ABC is equal to the triangle DBC:
Wherefore the triangle EBC is equal to the triangle D BC. Namely, the whole to
the part: which is impossible. Wherefore the parallel line falls not without
the line AD. And Euclide has proved that it falls not within. Wherefore the
line AD is a parallel unto the line BC. Wherefore equal triangles which are on
the self same side, and on one and the self same base, are also in the self
same parallel lines: which was required to be proved.

An addition of Flussates.
The self same also follows in parallelogrames. An addition of Fl^ssases.
For if upon the base AB be set on one and the same side these equal
parallelogrames ABCD and ABGE, they shall of necessity be in the self same
parallel lines. For if not, but one of them is set either within or without,
let the parallelograme B^ being equal to the parallelograme ABCD be set within
the same parallel lines: wherefore the same parallelograme BF being equal to
the parallelograme ABCD (by the 35. proposition) shall also be equal to the
other parallelograme ABGE (by the first common sentence) For the parallelograme
ABGE is by supposition equal to the parallelogramme ABCD: whe^fore the
parallelograme BF being equal to the parallelograme ABGE, the part shall be
equal to the whole, which is absurd. The same inconvenience also will follow,
if it fall without. Wherefore it can neither fall within nor without.
Wherefore equal parallelogrames being upon one and the self same base and on
one and the same side, are also in the self same parallel lines.

An addition of Campanus.
An addition of Campanus.
If a right line divide two sides of a triangle into two equal parts: it
shall be equidistant unto the third side.

Suppose that there be a triangle ABC: and let there be a right line DE, which
let divide the two sides AB and BC into two equal parts in the points D and
E Then I say, that the line DE is a parallel to the line A C. Draw these two
lines AE and DC. Now then imagining a line to be drawn by the point E parallel
to the line AB, the triangle BDE shall (by the 38. proposition) be equal to
the triangle DAE (for their two bases AD and DB are put to be equal) And by
the same reason the triangle BDE is equal to the triangle CED. Wherefore (by
the first common sentence) the triangles EAD and ECD are equal, and they are
erected on one and the self same base, namely, DE, and on one and the same
side. Wherefore (by the 39. proposition) they are in the self same parallel
lines, and the line which joins together their tops is a parallel to their
base. Wherefore the lines DE and AC are paralles: which was required to be
proved.

The 30. Theoreme. The 40. Proposition. Equal triangles consisting upon equal
bases, and in one and the same side: are also in the self same parallel lines.
SVppose that these equal triangles ABC and CDE do consist upon equal bases,
that is, upon BC and CE, and on one and the same side, namely, on the side of
A. Then I say that they are in the self same parallel lines. Construction.
Draw by the first peticion a right line from the point A to the point D. Now
I say that AD is a parallel line to BE. For if not, then (by the 31.
proposition) by the point A draw unto the line BE a parallel line AF. And draw
a right line from the point F to the point E. Demonstration leading to an
absurdity.
Wherefore (by the 38. proposition) the triangle BAC is equal to the triangle
CFE^ for they consist upon equal bases, that is BC and CE, and are in the self
same parallel lines, namely, BE and AF. But by supposition the triangle ABC is
equal to the triangle CDE. Wherefore the triangle DCE is equal to the triangle
FCE, namely, the greater unto the less, which is impossible. Wherefore AF is
not a parallel line to BE. And in like sort may we prove that no other line
besides AD is a parallel line to BE. Wherefore AD is a parallel line to BE
Equal triangles therefore consisting upon equal bases, and in one and the
same side: are also in the self same parallel lines: which was required to be
proved.

This proposition is the converse of the 38. proposition. This proposition is
the converse of the 38. propositio^s.
And in this as in the former proposition, if the parallel line drawn by the
point A, should not pass by the point D, it must pass either beneath it, or
above it. Euclide sets forth only the absurdity which should follow if it
pass beneath it: but the self same absurdity also will follow if it should
pass above it: as it is not hard to see by the gathering thereof in the former
proposition. And therefore here I omit it.

The 31. Theoreme. The 41. Proposition. If a parallelograme and a triangle have
one and the self same base, and be in the self same parallel lines: the
parallelograme shall be double to the triangle.
SVppose that the parallelograme ABCD and the triangle EBC have one and the
same base, namely, BC, and let the^ be in the self same parallel lines,
namely, BC and AE. The^ I say, that the parallelograme ABCD is double to the
triangle BEC. Draw (by the first peticion) a right line from the point A to ye
point C. Demonstration.
Wherefore (by the 37. proposition) the triangle ABC is equal to the triangle
EBC^ for they are upon one and the self same base BC, and in the self same
parallel lines BC and EA: but the parallelograme ABCD is double to the
triangle ABC (by the 34. proposition) for the diameter thereof AC deuideth it
into two equal parts: wherefore the parallelogramme ABCD is double to the
triangle EBC. If therefore a parallelogramme and a triangle have one and the
self same base, and be in the self same parallels, the parallelograme shall
be double to the triangle: which was required to be proved.

Two cases in this proposition.
This proposition has two cases. For the base being one, the triangle may have
his top without the parallelograme, or within. The first case is demonstrated
of the author. The second case is thus.

Suppose that there be a parallelograme ABCD, and let the triangle be ECD,
either of which let have one and the self same base, namely, CD, and let them
be in the self same parallel lines CD and AB, and let the top of the
triangle ECD, namely, the point E, be within the parallelograme ABCD. Then I
say that the parallelograme ABCD is double to the triangle ECD. Draw a right
line from the point A to the point D. Now forasmuch as the parallelograme ABCD
is double to the triangle AD (by the 34. proposition): and the triangle ADC is
equal to the triangle EDC (by the 37. proposition). Therefore the
parallelogramme ABCD is double to the triangle ECD: which was required to be
proved.

A corollary.
By this proposition it is manifest that if the base be doubled, the triangle
erected upon it shall be equal to the parallelogramme.

The self same demonstration will serve if the triangle and the
parallelogramme be upon equal bases.
And if the bases of the triangle and of the parallelogramme be equal, the
self same demonstration will serve if you draw the diameter of the
parallelograme. For the triangles being equal, the parallelogramme which is
double to the one, shall also be double to the other. And the triangles must
needs be equal (by the 38. proposition) for that their bases are equal, and
for that they are in the self same parallel lines.

The converse of this proposition is thus.
If a parallelogramme and a triangle have one and the self same base, or
equal bases the one to the other, and be described on one and the same side of
the base: ^f the parallelogramme be double to the triangle, they shall be in the
self same parallel lines.

The converse of this proposition.
For if they be not, the whole shall be equal to his part. For then the top of
the triangle must needs fall either within the parallel lines or without. And
whether of both soever it do, one and the self same impossibility will
follow, if by the top of the triangle be drawn unto the base a parallel line.

An other converse of the same proposition.
If a parallelogramme be the double of a triangle, being both within the self
same parallel lines: An other converse of the same proposition.
then are they upon one and the self same base, or upon equal bases. For if
in that case their bases should be unequal, then might straight way be proved,
that the whole is equal to his part: which is impossible.

A trapesium having two sides only parallel lines, Comparison of a triangle
and a trapesium being upon one and the self same base, and in the self same
parallel lines.
is either more then double, or less then double to a triangle contained
within the self same parallel lines, and having one and the self same base
with the trapesium, or table. ^ust the double it cannot be, for then it should
be a parallelogramme. A trapesium having two sides parallels has of necessity
the one of them longer then the other: for if they were equal then should the
other two sides enclosing them be also equal (by the 33. proposition.) If the
greater side of the trapesium be the base of the triangle, then shall the
trapesium be less then the double of the triangle And if the less side of the
trapesium be the base of the triangle then shall the trapesium be greater then
the triangle.

For suppose that ABCD be a trapesium, When the greater side of the trapesium
is the base of the triangle.
and let two sides thereof, namely, AB and CD be parallel lines, and let the
side AB be less then the side CD, and produce the side AB infinitlye on the
side B to the point F. And let the triangle ECD have one and the self same
base with the trapesium, namely, the line CD. Then I say that the trapesium
ABCD is less the^ the double of the triangle ECD. For put the line AF equal
to the line CD (by the 3. proposition) and draw a line from D to F. Wherefore
ACD F is a parallelogramme (by the 33. proposition). Wherefore (by the 34
proposition) it is double to the triangle ECD. But the trapesium ABCD is a part
of the parallelogramme ACD F. Wherefore the trapesium ABCD is less then the
double of the triangle ECD: which was requi^ed to be proved.

Again let the triangle have to his base the side AB. When the less side is
the base.
Then I say that the trapesium ABCD is greater then the double of the triangle
AEB. For from the side CD cut of the line CF equal to the line AB (by the ^.
proposition). And draw a line from B to F. Wherefore (by the 33. proposition)
ABCF is a parallelogramme: and therefore is (by the 34. proposition) double to
the triangle AEB. Wherefore the trapesium ABCD is more then the double of the
triangle AEB^ which was required to be proved.

The 11. Problem. The 42. proposition. Unto a triangle given, to make a
parallelograme equal, whose angle shall be equal to a rectiline angle given.
SVppose that the triangle given be ABC, and let the rectiline angle given be
D. It is required that unto the triangle ABC there be made a parallelograme
equal, whose angle shall be equal to the rectiline angle given, namely,
Construction.
to the angle D. Divide (by the 10. proposition) the line BC into two equal
parts in the point E. And (by the first peticion) draw a right line from the
point A to the point E. And (by the 23. proposition) upon the right line given
EC, and to the point in it given E, make the angle CEF equal to the angle D.
And (by the 31. proposition) by the point A draw unto the line EC a parallel
line AH: and let the line OF cut the line AH in the point F. and (by the same)
by the point C, draw unto the line OF a parallel line CG. Wherefore FECG is a
parallelograme. Demonstration
And forasmuch as BE is equal to EC, therefore (by the 38. proposition) the
triangle ABE is equal to the triangle AEC, for they consist upon equal bases
that is BE and EC, and are in the self same parallel lines, namely, BC and AH.
Wherefore the triangle ABC is double to the triangle AEC. And the
parallelograme CEFG is also double to the triangle AEC: for they have one and
the self same base, namely, EC: and are in the self same parallel lines, that
is, EC and AH. Wherefore the parallelograme FECG is equal to the triangle ABC,
and has the angle CEF equal to the angle given D. Wherefore unto the
triangle given ABC is made an equal parallelograme, namely, FECG, whose angle
CEF is equal to the angle given D: which was required to be done.

The converse of this proposition after Pelitarius.
Unto a parallelogramme given, ^
to make a triangle equal, hauy^g an angle equal to a rectiline angle given.

Suppose that the parallelograme given be ABCD, and let the angle given be E.
It is required unto the parallelograme ABCD to make a triangle equal having an
angle equal to the angle E. Upon the line CD and to the point in it C,
describe (by the 23. propoposition) an angle equal to the angle E: which let
be DCF: and let the line CF cut the line AB being produced, in the point F: and
produce the line CD (which is parallel to the line AF) to the point G. And put
the line DG equal to the line CD and draw a line from F to G. Then I say that
the triangle CFG is equal to the parallelograme ABCD. For forasmuch as (by the
38. proposition) the whole triangle CFG is double to the triangle CDF. And (by
the 41. proposition) the parallelograme ABCD is double to the same triangle
CDF: therefore the parallelograme ABCD and the triangle CFG are equal the one
to the other: which was required to be done.

The 32. Theoreme. The 43. Proposition. In every parallelograme, the
supplementes of those parallelogrammes which are about the diameter, are equal
the one to the other.
SVppose that ABCD be a parallelograme, and let the diameter thereof be AC: and
about the diameter AC let these parallelogrames EH and GF consist: and let the
supplementes be BK and KD. Then I say that the supplement BK is equal to the
supplement KD. For forasmuch as ABCD is a parallelograme and the diameter
thereof is AC, therefore (by the 34. proposition) the triangle ABC is equal to
the triangle ADC. Again forasmuch as AEKH is a parallelograme, and the
diameter thereof is AK, therefore (by the same) the triangle AEK is equal to the
triangle AHK. And by the same reason also the triangle KFC is equal to the
triangle KGC. And forasmuch as the triangle AEK is equal to the triangle AHK,
and the triangle KFC to the triangle NGC, therefore the triangles AEK and KGC
are equal to the triangles AHK and KFC: and the whole triangle ABC is equal
to the whole triangle AD C: wherefore the residue, namely, the supplement BK is
(by the 3. common sentence) equal to the residue, namely, to the supplement
KD. Wherefore in every parallelogramme, the supplementes of those
parallelogrammes which are about the diameter, are equal the one to the
other: which was required to be proved.

How parallelogrammes are said to consiste about a diameter.
Those parallelogrames are said to consist about a diameter which have to their
diameters part of the diameter of the whole and great parallelograme, as in the
example of Euclide. And such parallelogrames which have not to their diameters
part of the diameter of the greater parallelograme, are said not to consist
about the diameter. For the^ the diameter of the greater parallelograme cutteth
the side of the less contained within it. As in the parallelogramme AB, the
diameter CD, cutteth the side EH of the parallelogramme CE. Wherefore the
parallelogramme CE is not about one and the self same diameter with the
parallelogramme CD.

Supplements and Complementes.
Supplementes or Complementes are those figures which with the two
parallelogrammes accomplish the whole parallelogramme. Although Pel^tarius for
distinction sake puts a difference between Supplementes and Complemente^.
The parallelogrammes about the diameter he calls Complementes, the other ^wo
figures he calls Supplementes.

Three cases in this Theoreme.
This theoreme has three cases only. For the parallelogrammes which consist
about the diameter, either touch the one the other in a point: or by a certain
part of the diameter are severed the one from the other: or else they cut the
one the other. The first case.
For the first case is the example of Euclide before set. The second case is
thus.

The second case.
Suppose that AB be a parallelograme^ whose diameter let be CD: and about the
same diameter let these parallelogrammes CK and DL consist: and between the^
let there be a certain part of the diameter, namely, LK. Then I say that the
two supplementes AGLKE and BFKLH are equal. For we may as before (by the 34.
proposition) prove that the triangle ACD, is equal to the triangle BCD, and
the triangle ECK to the triangle K CF, and also the triangle DGL to the
triangle DHL. Wherefore the residue, namely, the five sided figure AGLKE is
equal to the residue, namely, to the five sided figure, BFKLH: that is, the
one supplement to the other^ which was required to be proved.

The third case.
But now suppose AB to be a parallelogramme, and let the diameter thereof be CD:
and let the one of the parallelogrammes about it be ECFL, and let the other be
DGKH, of which let the one cut the other. Then I say that the supplementes EG
and EH are equal. For forasmuch as the whole triangle DGK is equal to the
whole triangle DHK (by the 34. proposition), and part also of the one, namely,
the triangle K LM is equal to part of the other, namely, to the triangle K LN
(by the same), for LK is a parallelograme: therefore the residue, namely, the
Trapesium DLNH is equal to the residue, namely, to the trapesiu^ DLMG: but the
triangle ADC is equal to the triangle BCD, and in the parallelograme OF, the
triangle FCL, is equal to the triangle ECL, and the trapesium DGML is (as it
has been proved) equal to the trapesium DHNL. Wherefore the residue, namely,
the quadrilater figure GF is equal to the residue, namely, to the quadrilater
figure EH, that is, the one supplement to the other: which was required to be
proved.

This is to be noted that in ^^h of those three cases it may so happen, that
the parallelogrammes about the diameter shall not have one angle common with
the whole parallelogramme, as they have in the former figures. But yet though
they have not, the self same demonstration will serve, as it is plain to see
in the figures here underneath put. For always, if from things equal be
taken away things equal, the residue shall be equal.



This proposition P^litarius calls Gnomicall, and mystical, This proposition
called Gnomical and mistical.
for that of it (says he) spring infinite demonstrations, and uses in
geometry. And he puts the converse thereof after this manner.

If a parallelogramme be divided into two equal supplementes, The converse of
this proposition.
and into two complements whatsoever: the diameter of the two complementes
shall be set directly, and make one diameter of the whole parallelogramme.

Here is to be noted as I before admonished that Pelitarius for distinction
sake puts a difference between supplementes and complementes, which
difference, for that I have before declared, I shall not need here to repete
again.

Suppose that there be a parallelogramme ABCD, whose two equal supplements let
be AEFG and F HDK, and let the two complementes thereof be GFCK and EBFH: whose
diameters let be CF and FB. Then I say that CFB is one right line, and is the
diameter of the whole parallelogramme ABCD: for if it be not, then is there an
other diameter of the whole parrallelogramme, which let be CLB being drawn
under the diameters CF and FB, and cutting the line GH in the in the point L.
And (by the 31. proposition) by the point L, draw unto the line AC a parallel
line MLN. And so are there in the whole parallelogramme ABCD two supplements
AMGL and LHND, which by this proposition shall be equal the one to the other.
For that they are about the diameter CLB. But the supplement AEFG is (by
supposition) equal to the supplement FHDK: and forasmuch as FHDK is greater
then LH DN, AEFG also shall be greater then AMGL, namely, the part greater then
the whole: which is impossible. And by the same reason may it be proved, that
the diameter cannot be drawn above the diameters CF and FB. Wherefore CFB is
one diameter of the whole parallelogramme ABCD: which was required to be proved.

The 12. Problem. The 44. Proposition. Upon a right line given, to apply a
parallelograme equal to a triangle given, and containing an angle equal to a
rectiline angle given.
SVppose that the right line given be AB, and let the triangle given be C, and
let the rectiline angle given be D. It is required upon the right line given
AB, to apply a parallelogramme equal to the triangle given C, Construction.
and containing an angle equal to the rectiline angle given 44. proposition)
ye parallelograme BGEF equal to the triangle C, and having the angle BGF
equal to the angle D. And unto the line EB join the line AB in such sort that
they make both one right line. And extend the line FG beyond the point G to the
point H. And (by the 31. proposition) by the point A draw to either of these
lines BG and OF a parallel line AH. And (by the first peticion) draw a right
line from the point H to the point B. And forasmuch as upon the parallel lines
AH and OF falls a certain right line HF, therefore (by the ^9 proposition)
the angles AHF and HFE are equal to two right angles: wherefore the angles BHG
and GFE are less then two right angles: but if upon two right lines fall a
right line making the inward angles on one and the same side less then two
right angles, those right lines being infinitely produced shall at the length
mete on that side in which are the angles less then two right angles (by the
5. peticion). Wherefore the lines HB and FE being infinitely produced will at
the length mete. Let them be produced, and let them mete in the point K. And
(by the 31 proposition) by the point K draw to either of these lines EA and FH
a parallel line KL. And (by the 2. peticion) extend the lines HA and GB till
they co^curre with the line KL in the points L and M. Demonstration
Wherefore HLKF is a parallelogramme, and the diameter thereof is HK: and
about the diameter HK are the parallelogrammes AG and ME, and the supplementes
are LB and BF: wherefore (by the 43. prop^sition) the supplement LB is equal
to the supplement BF: but by construction the parallelograme BF is equal to
the triangle C: wherefore also the parallelogramme LB is equal to the triangle
C. And forasmuch as the line FH is a parallel to the line KL, and upon them
lights the line GM, therefore (by the 27. proposition) the angle FGB is
equal to the angle BML. But the angle FGB is equal to the angle D, therefore
the angle BML is equal to the angle D. Wherefore upon the right line given AB
is applied the parallelograme LB, equal to the triangle given C, and containing
the angle BML equal to the rectiline angle given D: which was required to be
done.

Applications of spaces or figures to lines with excesses or wantes is (says
Eudemus) an ancient invention of Pithagoras. Applications of spaces with
excesses or wants an ancient invention of Pithagoras.


When the space or figure is joined to the whole line, How a figure is said
to be applied to a line.
the^ is the figure said to be applied to the line. But if the length of the
space be longer then the line, the^ it is said to exceed: and if the length
of the figure be shorter then the line, so that part of the line remains
without the figure described, then is it said to want.

In this problem are three things given. Three things given in this
proposition.
A right line to which the application is made, which here must be the one side
of the parallelogramme applied. A triangle whereunto the parallelogramme
applied must be equal: and an angle whereunto the angle of the parallelograme
applied must be equal. And if the angle given be a right angle, the^ shall the
parallelograme applied be either a square, or a figure on the one side longer.
But if the angle given be an obtuse or an acute angle, then shall the
parallelograme applied be a Rhombus or diamond figure, or else a Rhomboides or
diamondlike figure.

The converse of this proposition after Politarius.
Upon a right line given, to apply unto a parallelograme given an equal
triangle having an angle equal to an angle given. The converse of this
proposition.


Suppose that the right line given be AB, and let the parallelograme given be
CDEF, and let the angle given be G. It is required upon the line AB to describe
a tria^gle equal to the parallelograme CDEF, having an angle equal to the
angle G. Draw the diameter CF and produce CD beyond the point D to the point
H. And put the line DH equal to the line CD. And draw a line from F to H. Now
the^ (by the 41. proposition) the tria^gle CHF is equal to the parallelograme
CD OF. And (by this proposition) upon the line AB describe a parallelograme
ABKL equal to the triangle CHF, having the angle ABL equal to the angle given
G: and produce the line BL beyond the point L to the point M. And put the
line LM equal to the line BL, and draw a line from A to M. Then I say that
upon the line AB is described the triangle ABM, which is such a triangle as is
required. For (by the 41. proposition) the triangle ABM is equal to the
parallelogramme ABKL (for that they are between two parallel lines BM and AK,
and the base of the triangle is double to the base of the parallelogramme): but
ABKL is by construction equal to the triangle CHF: and the triangle CHF is
equal to the parallelograme CDEF. Wherefore (by the first common sentence) the
triangle ABM is equal to the parallelograme given CD OF, and has his angle
ABM equal to the angle given G: which was required to be done.

The 13. Problem. The 45 Proposition. To describe a parallelograme equal to
any rectiline figure given, and containing an angle equal to a rectiline angle
given.
SVppose that the rectiline figure given be ABCD, and let the rectiline angle
given be E. It is required to describe a parallelograme equal to the rectiline
figure given ABCD, and containing an angle equal to the rectiline angle given
E. Construction.
Draw (by the first peticion) a right line from the point D to the point B. And
(by the 42. proposition) unto the triangle ABD describe an equal
parallelograme FH, having his angle FKH equal to the angle E. And (by the 4^.
of the first) upon the right line GH apply the parallelogramme GM equal to the
triangle DBC, having his angle GHM equal to the angle E. Demonstration.
And forasmuch as either of those angles HKF and GHM is equal to the angle E:
therefore the angle HKF is equal to the angle GHM: put the angle KHG common to
them both, wherefore the angles FKH and KHG are equal to the angles KHG and
GHM. but the angles FKH and KHG are (by the 29. proposition) equal to two
right angles. Wherefore the angles KHG and GHM are equal to two right angles.
Now then unto a right line GH, and to a point in the same H, are drawn two
right lines KH and HM not both on one and the same side, making the side angles
equal to two right angles. Wherefore (by the 14. proposition) the lines KH and
HM make directly one right line. And forasmuch as upon the parallel lines. KM
and FG falls the right line HG, therefore the alternate aagles MHG and HGF
are (by the 29 proposition) equal the one to the other: put the angle HGL
common to them both. Wherefore the angles MHG and HGL are equal to the angles
HGF and HGL. But the angles MHG and HGL are equal to two right angles (by ye
29. proposition). Wherefore also the angles HGF and HGL are equal to two right
angles. Wherefore (by the 14. proposition) the lines FG and GL make directly
one right line. And forasmuch as the line KF is (by the 34. proposition) equal
to the line HG, and it is also parallel unto it: and the line HG is (by the
same) equal to the line ML, therefore (by the first common sentence) the line
FK is equal to the line ML, and also a parallel unto it (by the 30.
proposition). But the right lines KM and FL join them together. Wherefore (by
the 33. proposition) the lines KM and FL are equal the on to the other and
parallel lines. Wherefore KFLM is a parallelograme. And forasmuch as the
triangle ABD is eqnal to the parallelograme FH, and the triangle DBC to the
parallelogramme GM^ therefore the whole rectiline figure ABCD is equal to the
whole parallelograme KFLM. Wherefore to the rectiline figure given ABCD is made
an equal parallegrame KFLM, whose angle FKM is equal to the angle given,
namely, to E: which was required to be done.

The rectiline figure given (...) in the example of Euclide is a
parallelograme. But if the rectiline figure be of many sides, as of 5.6. or mo,
the^ must you resolve the figure into his triangles, as has been before taught
in the 32. proposition. And the^ apply a parallelograme equal to every triangle
upon a line given, as before in the example of the author. And the same kind of
reasoning will serve that was before, only by reason of the multitude of
triangles, you shall have need of oftener repeticio^ of the 29. and 14.
propositio^s to prove that the bases of all the parallelogrames made equal to
all the triangles make one right line, and so also of the tops of the said
parallelogrames. Pelitarius adds unto this proposition this Problem
following.

Two unequal rectiline superfici^c^s being given, to find out the exc^sse of
the greater above the less. An addition of Pelitarius.


Suppose that there be two unequal rectiline superficieces A and B of which
let A be the greater. It is required to find out the excess of the
superficies A above the superficieces B. Describe (by the 44. proposition) the
parallelograme CDEF equal to the rectiline figure A, containing a right angle.
And produce the line CD beyond the point D to the point G: and put the line DG
equal to the line CD. And again (by the 44. proposition) upon the line DG
describe the parallelograme DGHK equal to the rectiline figure B, and having
the angle DGK a right angle. And produce the line KH beyond the point H, until
it cut the line CE in the point L. Then I say that HLEF, is the excess of
the rectiline figure A above the rectiline figure B. For first that CGKL is a
parallelogramme it is manifest, neither needs it to be demonstrated. And
forasmuch as the lines CD and DG are by supposition equal and either of them is
a parallel to KL, therefore (by the 36, proposition) the two parallelogrames CH
and DK are equal. And forasmuch as DK is supposed to be equal to the
rectiline figure B, CH also shall be equal to the same rectiline figure B.
Wherefore forasmuch as the whole parallelograme CF is equal to the rectiline
figure A, and LF is the excess of CF above DL or DK, it follows that LF is
the excess of the rectiline figure A above the rectiline figure B: which was
required to be done.

An other more ready way.
Let the parallelograme CDEF remain equal to the rectiline figure A, and
produce the line CD beyond the point D to the point G. And upon the line DG
describe the parallelograme DGHK equal to the rectiline figure B. And produce
the lines EC and HK beyond the points C and K till they concur in the point
L. And by the point D draw the diameter LDM, which let cut the line HG being
produced beyond the point G in the point M, and by the point M draw unto
the line HL a parallel MN cuttyng the line EL in the point N: and by that
means is HLMN a parallelograme. Then I say that NF is the evcesse of the
rectiline figure A above the rectiline figure B. For forasmuch as the
parallelograme HD is equal to the rectiline figure B, and the supplementes HD
and DN ar (by the 43. proposition) equal: therefore DN also is equal to the
rectiline figure B, which rectiline figure DN being taken away from the
parallelograme CF (which is supposed to be equal to the rectiline figure A)
the residue NF shall be the ezcesse of the rectiline figure A above the
rectiline figure B: which was required to be done.

The 14. Problem. The 46. Proposition. Upon a right line given, to describe a
square.
SVppose that the right line given be AB. It is required upon the right line
AB, to describe a square. Upon the right line AB, and from a point in it given,
namely, A, raise up (by the 11 proposition) a perpendiculer line AC. And (by
the 3. proposition) unto AB put an equal line AD. And (by the 31. proposition)
by the point D draw unto AB a parallel line DE. And (by the same) by the point
B draw unto AD a parallel line BE. Wherefore ADEB is a parallelogramme.
Wherefore the line AB is equal to the line DE, and the line AD to the line
BE: but the line AB is equal to the line AD wherefore these four lines BA,
AD, DE, EB, are equal the one to the other. Wherefore the parallelogramme
ADEB consists of equal sides. I say also that it is rectangle. For forasmuch
as upon the parallel lines AB and DE falls a right line AD: therefore (by the
29. proposition) the angle: BAD and ADE are equal to two right angles: but the
angle BAD is a right angle. Wherefore the angle ADE also is a right angle. But
in parallelogrames the sides and angles which are opposite are equal the one
to the other (by the 34 proposition). Wherefore the two opposite angles ABE
and BED are each of them a right angle. Wherefore the parallelograme ABED is
rectangle: and it is also proved that it is equilater. Wherefore it is a
square, and it is described upon the right line given AB: which was required to
be done.

This is to be noted that if you will mechanically and redily, To describe a
square mechanically.
not regarding demo^stration describe a square upon a line given, as upon the
line AB, after that you have erected the perpendiculer line CA upon the line
AB, and put the line AE equal to the line AB: then open your compass to the
wydth of the line AB or AE, and set one foot thereof in the point E, and
describe a piece of the circumference of a circle: and again make the center
the point B, and describe also a piece of the circumference of a circle,
namely, in such sort that the piece of the circumfere^ce of the one may cut the
piece of the circumference of the other, as in the point D: and from the point
of the intersection, draw unto the points E and B right lines: and so shall be
described a square. As in this figure here put, wherein I have not drawn the
lines ED and DB, that the pieces of the circumference cutting the one the other
might the plainlier be seen.

An addition of Proc^us.
If the lines upon which the squares be described be equal, the squares also
are equal.

Suppose that these right lines AB and CD be equal, An addition of Proc^^^.
and upon the line AB describe a square ABEG: and upon the line CD describe a
square CDHF. Then I say that the two squares ABEG and CDHF are equal. For draw
these right lines GB and HD. And for as much as the right lines AB and CD are
equal, and the lines AG and HC are also equal, and they contain eqaul
angles, namely, right angles (by the definition of a square) therefore (by the
4. proposition) the base BG is equal to the base HD. And the triangle ABG is
equal to the triangle CDH. Wherefore the doubles of the said triangles are
equal. Wherefore the square AE is equal to the square CF: which was required
to be proved.

The converse thereof is thus.
If the squares be equal: The converse thereof.
the lines also upon which they are described are equal.

Suppose that there be two equal squares AF and CG described upon the lines AB
and BC. The^ I say, that the lines AB and BC are equal. Put the line AB
directly to the line BC, that they both make on right line. And forasmuch as
the angles are right angles, therefore also (by the 14. proposition) the right
line FB is set directly to the right line BG. Draw these right lines FC, AG,
AF, and CG. Now for as much as the square AF is equal to the square CG, the
triangle also AFB shall be equal to the triangle CBG: put the triangle BCF
common to them both. Wherefore the whole triangle ACF is equal to the whole
triangle CFG. Wherefore the line AG is a parallel unto the line CF (by the 38.
proposition): for the triangles consist upon one and the self same base,
namely CF. Again forasmuch as either of these angles AFG and CBG is the half
of a right angle, therefore (by the 17. proposition) the line AF is a parallel
to the line CG. Wherefore the right line AF is equal to the right line CG (for
the opposite sides of a parallelograme are equal). And forasmuch as there are
