mediall superficies, and let it be supposed to be divided into his parts in
the point C, so that let AC be the greater part, and take a rational line DE.
And (by the 44. of the first) unto the line DE apply the parallelogramme DF
equal to the square of the line AB, and making in breadth the line DG. Then I
say, that the line DG is a fifth binomiall line. Construction.
Let the self same co^struction be in this, that was in the former. And
forasmuch as AB is a line containing in power a rational and a mediall
superficies, Demonstration.
and is divided into his parts in the point C, therefore the lines AC and CB
are inco^mensurable in power, having that which is made of the squares of the^
added together mediall, and that which is contained under then rational. Now
forasmuch as that which is made of the squares of the lines AC and CB added
together is mediall, therefore also the parallelogramme DL is mediall.
Wherefore (by the 22. of the tenth) the line DM is rational and
incommensurable in length to the line DE. Again forasmuch as to the line DE.
Wherefore (by the 13. of the tenth) the line DM is incommensurable in in this
may it be proved, that that which is contained under the lines DK and KM is
equal to the square of MN the half of the less: and that the line DK is
incommensurable in length to the line KM. Wherefore (by the 18. of the tenth)
the line DM is in power more the^ the line MG by the square of a line
incommensurable in length to the line DM. And the lines DM and MG are rational
commensurable in power only, and the less line, namely, MG is commensurable
in length to the rational line given DE. Wherefore the line DG is a fifth
binomiall line: which was required to be demonstrated.

The 47. Theoreme. The 65. Proposition. The square of a line containing in
power two medialls applied unto a rational line, makes the breadth or other
side a sixth binomiall line.
SVppose that the line AB be a line containing in power two medialls, and let
it be supposed to be divided into his parts in the point C. And take a
rational line DE. And (by the 44. of the first) unto the rational line DE
apply the parallelogra^me DF equal to the square of the line AB and making in
breadth the line DG. Then I say that the line DG is a sixth binomiall line.
Construction.
Let the self same construction be in this that was in the former. And
forasmuch as the line AB is a line containing in power two medialls,
Demonstration.
and is divided into his parts in the point C, therefore the lines AC and CB
are incommensurable in power having that which is made of the squares of them
added together mediall, and that which is contained under them, mediall, and
moreover incommensurable to that which is made of the squares of them added
together. Wherefore by those things which have been before proved, either of
these parallelogra^mes DL and MF is mediall, and either of them is applied upon
the rational line DE. Wherefore (by the 22. of the tenth) either of these
lines DM and MG is rational DE. And forasmuch as that which is mad^ of the
squares of the lines AC and CB, added together is incommensurable to that which
is contained under the lines AC and CB twice, therefore the parallelogra^me DL
is incommensurable to the parallelogra^me MF. Wherefore (by the 1. of the sixth
and 10. of the tenth) the line DM is incommensurable in length to the line MG.
Wherefore the lines DM and MG are rational commensurable in power only.
Wherefore the whole line DG is a binomiall line. I say also that is a sixth
binomiall line. For even as in the other proposition^ it has been proved so
also in this may it be proved, that that which is contained under the lines DK
and KM, is equal to the square of the line MN, and that the line DK is
incommensurable in length to the line KM, and therefore (by the 18. of the
tenth) the line DM is in power more then the line MG by the square of a line
incommensurable in length to the line DM. And neither of these lines DM nor MG
is commensurable in length to there an^nall line given DE. Wherefore the line DG
is a sixth ^^nomiall line: which was required to be demonstrated.

The 48. Theoreme. The 66. Proposition. A line commensurable in length to a
binomiall line, is also a binomiall line of the self same order.
SVppose that the line AB be a binomiall line, The sixth Senary.
and unto the line AB let the line CD be commensurable in length. Then I say
that the line CD is a binomiall line and of the self same order that the line
AB is. For forasmuch as AB is ^ binomiall line let it be divided into his names
in the point E, Construction.
and let AE be the greater name. Wherefore the lines AE and EB are rational
commensurable in power only. And as the line AB is to the line CD, (so by the
12. of the sixth) let the line AE be to the line CF. Demonstration.
Wherefore (by the 19. of the fifth) the residue, namely, the line EB is to the
residue, namely, to the line FD, as the line AB is to the line CD. But (by
supposition) the line AB is commensurable in length to the line CD. Wherefore
(by the 10. of the tenth) the line AE is commensurable in length to the line
CF, and the line EB to the line FD. And the lines AE and EB are rational.
Wherefore the lines CF and FD are also rational. And for that as the line AE
is to the line CF, so is the line EB. to the line FD, therefore alternately (by
the 16. of the fifth) as the line A^E is to the line EB, so is the line CF to
the line FD. But the lines AE and EB are commensurable in power only,
wherefore the lines CF and FD are also commensurable in power only, and they
are rational. Wherefore the whole line CD is a binomiall line. I say also that
it is of the self same order of binomiall lines that the line AB is. For the
line AE is in power more then the line EB either by the square of a line
commensurable in length to the line AE, or by the square of a line
incommensurable in length to the line AE. If the line AE be in power more then
the line EB by the square of a line commensurable in length to the line AE, the
line also CF, by the 14. of the tenth) shall be in power more then the line FD by
the square of a line commensurable in length to CF. And if the line^ AE be
commensurable in length to a rational line given, the line CF also shall be
commensurable in length to the same (by the 12. of the tenth). And so either of
these lines AB and CD is a first binomiall line, that EB be commensurable in
length to the rational line put, the line FD also shall be commensurable in
length to the same. And by that means again the lines AB and CD are both of
one and the self same order^ for either of them is a second binomiall line.
But if neither of the lines AE nor E^ be commensurable CF nor FD shall be
commensurable in length to the same. And so neither of the lines AB and CD is a
third binomiall AE be in power more then the line EB by the square of a line
incommensurable in length to the line AE, the line also CF shall be in power more
then the line FD by the square of a line incommensurable in length to the line
CF, (by the 14. of the tenth). And then if the line AE be commensurable in
length to the rational line put the line CF also shall be commensurable in
length to the same, and so either of the lines AB, CD shall be a fourth binomiall
line. And if the line EB be commensurable in length to the rational line
given, the line FD also shall be commensurable in length to the same. And AB and
CD shall be a fifth binomiall line. But if neither of the lines AE nor EB be
commensurable in length to the rational line given, neither also of the lines
CF nor FD shall be commensurable in length to the same, and so either of the
lines AB and CD shall be a sixth binomiall line. A line, therefore commensurable
in length to a binomiall line, is also a binomiall line of the self same
order: which was required to be proved.

The 49. Theoreme. The 67. Proposition. A line commensurable in length to a
bimediall line, is also a bimediall line and of the self same order.
SVppose that the line AB be a bimediall line, And unto the line AB, let the
line CD be commensurable in length. Then I say that the line CD is a bimediall
line, and of the self order that the line AB is. Divide the line AB into his
parts in the point E. Construction.
And forasmuch as the line AB is a bimediall line, and is divided into his
parts in the point E, therefore (by the 37. and 38. of the tenth) the lines AE
and EB are medials commensurable in power only, And (by the 12. of the sixth)
as the line AB is to the line CD, so let the line AE be to the line CF.
Wherefore (by the 19. of the fifth) the residue, Demonstration.
namely, the line EB is to the residue, namely, to the line FD, as the line AB
is to the line CD. But the line AB is commensurable in length to the line CD.
Wherefore the line AE is commensurable in length to the line CF, and the line EB
to the line FD. Now the lines AE and EB are mediall, wherefore (by the 23. of
the tenth) the lines CF and FD are also mediall. And for that as the line AE is
to the line EB, so is the line CF to the line FD. But the lines AE and EB are
commensurable in power only, wherefore the lines CF and FD are also
commensurable in power only. And it is proved that they are mediall. Wherefore
the line CD is a bimediall AB be a first bimediall line, that also which is
contained under the lines CF and FD is rational. Wherefore also the line CD is
a first bimediall line. But if that which is contained under

A Corollary added by Flussates: but first noted by P. Monta^reus.
A line commensurable in power only to a bimediall line, is also a bimediall
line, and of the self same order.

Suppose that AB be a bimediall line, either a first or a second, whereunto let
the line GD be co^mensurable in power only. A Coroll^ry add^d by Flussetes.
Take also a rational line EZ, upon which (by the 45. of the first) apply a
rectangle parallelogramme equal to the square of the line AB, which let be
EZFC, and let the rectangle parallelogramme CFIH be equal to the square of the
line GD. And forasmuch as upon the rational line EZ is applied a rectangle
parallelogramme OF equal to the square of a first bimediall line, therefore
the other side thereof, namely, EC, is a second binomiall line, by the 61. of
this book. And forasmuch as by supposition the squares of the lines AB and GD
are commensurable, therefore the parallelogrammes OF and CI (which are equal
unto them) are also commensurable. And therefore by the 1. of the sixth, the
lines EC and CH are commensurable in length. But the line EC is a second
binomiall line. Wherefore the line CH is also a second binomiall line, by the
66. of this book. And forasmuch as the superficies CI is contained under a
rational line EZ or CF, and a second binomiall line CH, therefore the line
which contains it in power, namely, the line GD is a first bimediall line, by
the 55. of this book. And so is the line GD in the self same order of
bimediall lines that the line AB is. The like demonstration also will serve if
the line AB be supposed to b^ a second bimediall line. For so shall it make the
breadth EC a third binomiall line whereunto the line CH shall be commensurable
in length, and therefore CH also shall be a third binomiall line, by means
whereof the line which contains in power the superficies CI, namely, the line
GD shall also be a second bimediall line. Wherefore a line commensurable either
in length, or in power only to a bimediall line, is also a bimediall line of
the self same order.

But so is it not of necessity in binomiall lines, for if their powers only
be commensurable, it follows not of necessity that they are binomialls of
one and the self same order, Note.
but they are each binomialls either of the three first kinds, or of the three
last. As for example. Suppose that AB be a first binomiall line, whose greater
name let be AG, and unto AB let the DZ be co^me^surable in power only. Then I
say, that the line DZ is not of the self same order that the line AB is. For
if it be possible, let the line DZ be of the self same order that the line AB
is. Whe^efore the line DZ may in like sort be divided as the line AB is, by
that which has been demonstrated in the 66. Proposition of this booke^ let it
be so divided in the point E. Wherefore it can not be so divided in any other
point, by the 42^ of this book. And for that the line AB ^^ to the line DZ, as
the line AG is to the line DE, but the lines AG and DE, namely, the greater
names, are commensurable in length the one to the other (by the 10. of this
book) for that they are commensurable in length to (...) and the self same
rational line, by the first definition of binomiall lines. Wherefore the lines
AB and DZ are commensurable in length, by the 13. of this book. But by
supposition they are commensurable in power only: which is impossible.

The self same demonstration also will serve, if we suppose the line AB to be
a second binomial line: for the less names GB and EZ being commensurable in
length to one and the self same rational line, shall also be commensurable in
length the one to the other. And therefore the lines AB and DZ which are in the
self same proportion with them, shall also be commensurable in length the one
to the other: which is contrary to the supposition. Farther, if the squares of
the lines AB and DZ be applied unto the rational line CF, namely, the
parallelogrammes CT and HL, they shall make the breadthes CH and HK first
binomiall lines, of what order soever the lines AB and DZ (whose squares were
applied unto the rational line) are, (by the 60. of this book). Wherefore it
is manifest, that under a rational line and a first binomiall line, are
confusedly contained all the powers of binomiall lines (by the 54. of this
book). Wherefore the only commensuration of the powers does not of necessity
bring forth one and the self same order of binomiall lines. The self same
thing also may be proved, if the lines AB and DZ be supposed to be a fourth or
fifth binomiall line, whose powers only are conmmensurable, namely, that they
shall as the first bring forth binomiall lines of diverse orders. Now forasmuch
as the powers of the lines AG and GB, and DE and EZ are commensurable and
proportional, it is manifest, that if the line AG be in power more then the
line GB by the square of a line commensurable in length unto AG, the line DE
also shall be in power more then the line EZ by the square of a line
commensurable in length unto the line DE (by the 16. of this book). And so
shall the two lines AB and DZ be each, of the three first binomiall lines. But
if the line AG be in power more then the line GB by the square of a line
incommensurable in length unto the line AG, the line DE shall also be in power
(...) then the line EZ by the square of a line incomensurable in length unto
the line DE, by the self same P^oposition. And so shall each of the lines AB
and DZ be of the three last binomiall lines. But why it is not so in the third
and sixth binomiall lines, the reason is: For that in them neither of the name^
is commensurable in length to the rational line put FC.

The 50. Theoreme. The 68. Proposition. A line commensurable to a greater line,
is also a greater line.
SVppose that the line AB be a greater line. And unto the line AB let the line
CD be commensurable. Construction.
Then I say that the line CD also is a greater line. Divide the line AB into
his parts in the point E. Wherefore (by the 39. of the tenth) the lines AE and
EB are incommensurable in power, having that which is made of the squares of
them added together rational, and that which is contained under the^ mediall.
And let the rest of the construction be in this, as it was in the former. And
for that as the line AB is to the line CD, Demonstration.
so is the line AE to the line CF, and the line EB to the line FD, but the line
AB is commensurable to the line CD by suppositio^. Wherefore the line AE is
commensurable to the line CF, and the line EB to the line FD. And for that as
the line AE is to the line CF, so is the line EB to the line FD. Therefore
alternately (by the 16. of the fifth) as the line AE is to the line EB, so is
the line CF to the line FD. Wherefore by composition also (by the 18. of the
fifth) as the line AB is to the line EB, so is the line CD to the line FD.
Wherefore (by the 22. of the sixth) as the square of the line AB is to the
square of the line EB, so is the square of the line CD to the square of the
line FD. And in like sort may we prove that as the square of the line AB is to
the square of the line AE, so is the square of the line CD, to the square of
the line CF. Wherefore (by the 11. of the fifth) as the square of the line AB is
to the squares of the lines AE and EB, so is the square of the line CD to the
squares of the lines CF and FD. Wherefore alternately (by the 16. of the fifth)
as the square of the line AB is to the square of the line CD, so are the
squares of the lines AE and EB to the squares of the lines CF and FD. But the
square of the line AB is commensurable to the square of the line CD (for the
line AB is commensurable to the line CD by suppositio^). Wherefore also the
squares of the lines AE and EB are commensurable to the squares of the lines CF
and FD. But the squares of the lines AE and EB are incommensurable, and being
added together are rational. Wherefore the squares of the lines CF and FD are
incommensurable, and being added together, are also rational. And in like sort
may we prove that that which is contained under the lines AE and EB twice is
commensurable to that which is contained under the lines CF and FD twice. But
that which is contained under the lines AE and EB twice, is mediall, wherefore
also that which is contained under the lines CF and FD twice is medial.
Wherefore the lines CF and FD are incommensurable in power, having that which is
made of the squares of them added together rational, and that which is
contained under the^ mediall. Wherefore (by the 39. of the tenth) the whole line
CD is irrational, and is called a greater line. A line therefore commensurable
to a greater line, is also a greater line.

An other demonstration of Peter Montaureus to prove the same.
Suppose that the line AB be a greater line, and unto it let the line CD be
commensurable any way, that is, either both in length and in power, or else in
power only. An other demonstration after P. Montaureus.
Then I say that the line CD also is a greater line. Divide the line AB into
his parts in the point E. and let the rest of the construction be in this as
it was in the former. And for that as the line AB is to the line CD, so is the
line AE to the line CF, and the line EB to the line FD, therefore as the line AE
is to the line CF, so is the line EB to the line FD, but the line AB is
commensurable to the line CD. Wherefore also the line AE is commensurable to the
line CF, and likewise the line EB to the line FD. And for th^^ as the line AE
is to the line CF, so is the line EB to the line FD, therefore alternately as
the line AE is to the line EB, so is the line CF to the line FD. Wherefore (by
the 22. of the sixth) as the square of the line AE is to the square of the line
EB, so is the square of the line CF to the square of the line FD. Wherefore by
composition (by the 18. of the fifth) as that which is made of the squares of
the lines A^ and E^ added together is to the square of the line EB, so is that
which is made of the square^ of the lyne^ C^ and FD added together to the
square of the line FD. Wherefore by contrary proportion as the square of the
line EB is to that which is made of the squares of the lines AE and E^ added
together, so is the square of the line FD to that which is made of the squares
of the lines CF and FD added together. Wherefore alternately as the square of
the line EB is to the square of the line FD, so is that which is made of the
squares (...) the l^nes AE and EB added together to that which is made of the
squares of the lines CF and FD added together. But the square of the line EB is
co^mensurable to the square of the line FD, for it has already been proved
that the lines EB and FD are co^me^surable. Wherefore that which is made of the
squares of the lines AE and EB added together is comme^surable to that which is
made of the squares of C^ and FD added together. But that which is made of the
squares of the lines AE and EB added together is rational by suppositio^.
Wherefore that which is made of the squares of the lines CF and FD added
together is also rational. And as the line AE is to the line EB, so is the
line CF to the line FD: But as the line AE is to the line EB, so is the square
of the line A (...) contained under the lines AE and EB: therefore at the line
CF is to the line FD, so is the square of the line AE to the parallelogramme
contained under the lines AE and EB and as the line CF is to the line FD, so is
the square of the line CF to the parallelogra^me contained under the lines ^F
and FD. Wherefore as the square of the line AE is to the parallelogra^me
con^^^^ed under the lines AE and EB, so is the square of the line CF to the
parallelogramme contained under the lines CF and FD. Wher^or^ (...) ^s the
square of the line AE is to the square of the line CF, so is the
parallelogramme contained under the lines AE and EB to the parallelogramme
(...) vnde^ the lines ^^ and ^^. But the square of the line AE is commensurable
to the square of the line CF, for it is already pr^^^d that the lines AE and CF
are comme^surable. Wherefore the parallelogramme contained under the lines AE
and EB is commensurable to the parallelogramme contained under the lines CF and
FD. But the parallelogramme contained under the lines AE and EB is mediall by
suppo^ition. Wherefore the parallelogramme contained under the lines CF and ^D
also is mediall. And (as it has already been proved) as the line AE is to the
line EB, so is the line CF to the line FD. But the line AE was by supposition
incommensurable in power to the line EB. Wherefore (by the 10. of the tenth) the
line CF is incommensurable in power to the line FD. Wherefore the lines CF and
FD are incommensurable in power, having that which is made of the squares of
them added together rational, and that which is contained under them mediall.
Wherefore the whole line CD is (by the 39. of the tenth) a greater line.
Wherefore a line commensurable to a greater line is also a greater line: which
was required to be demonstrated.

An other more brief demonstration of the same after Campane.
Suppose that A be a greater line, unto which let the line B be comme^surable,
either in length and power, or in power only. An other demonstration after
Campane.
And take a rational line CD. And upon it apply the superficies C^ equal to
the square of the line A: and also upon the line FE (which is equal to the
rational line CD) apply the parallelogramme FG equal to the square of the
line B. And forasmuch as the squares of the two lines A and ^ are commensurable
by supposition, the superficies C^, shall be commensurable unto the superficies
FG: and therefore by the first of the sixth and tenth of this book, the line DE
is commensurable in length to the line GB. And forasmuch as (by the ^3. of this
book) the line DE is a fourth binomiall line, therefore by the ^6. of this
book the line GE is also a fourth binomiall line: wherefore by the 57. of this
book the line B which contains in power the superficies FG is a greater line.

The 51. Theoreme. The 69. Proposition. A line commensurable to a line
containing in power a rational and a mediall: is also a line containing in
power a rational and a mediall.
SVppose that AB be a line containing in power a rational and a mediall. And
unto the line AB let the line CD be commensurable, whether in length and power,
or in power only. The^ I say that the line CD is a line co^tayning in power a
rational and a mediall. Duide the line AB into his parts in the point E.
Construction.
Wherefore (by the 40. of the tenth) the lines AE and EB are incommensurable in
power, having that which is made of the squares of them added together medial,
and that which is contained under the^ national. Let the same construction be
in this that was in the former. Demonstration.
And in like sort we may prove that the lines CF and FD are incommensurable in
power, and that that which is made of the square of the lines AE and EB is
commensurable to that which is made of the squares of the lines CF and FD, and
that that also which is contained under the lines AE and EB is comme^surable to
that which is contained under the lines CF and FD. Wherefore that which is made
of the squares of the lines CF and FD is mediall, and that which is contained
under the lines CF and FD is rational. Wherefore the whole line CD is a line
containing in power a rational and a mediall: which was required to be
demonstrated.

An other demonstration of the same after Campane.
Supose that AB be a line containing in power a rational and a mediall: An
other demonstration af^^r Campane.
whereunto let the line GD be commensurable either in length and power, or in
power only. Then I say that the line GD is a line containing in power a
rational and a mediall. Take a rational line EZ, upon which by the 45. of the
first apply a rectangle parallelogra^me EZFC equal to the square of the line
AB: and upon the line CF (which is equal to the line EZ) apply the
parallelogramme FCHI equal to the square of the line GD^ and let the breadths
of the said parallelogrammes be the lines EG and CHAPTER And forasmuch as the line
AB is commensurable to the line GD at the least in power only, therefore the
parallelogrammes OF and FH (which are equal to their squares) shall be
commensurable. Wherefore by the 1. of the sixth the right lines EC and CH are
co^me^surable in length. And forasmuch as the parallelogramme OF (which is
equal to the square of the line A^ which contains in power ^ rational and a
mediall) is applied upon the rational EZ, making in breadth the line EC,
therefore the line EC is a fifth binomiall line (by the 64. of this book) unto
which line EC the line CH is co^me^surable in length, wherefore by the 66. of
this book the line CH is also a fifth binomiall line. And forasmuch as the
superficies CI is contained under the rational line EZ (that is CF) and a
fifth binomall line CH, therefore the line which contains in power the
superficies CI, which by supposition is the line GD is a line containing in
power a rational and a mediall by the 58. of this book. A line therefore
commensurable to a line containing in power a rational and a mediall. etc.

The 52. Theoreme. The 70. Proposition. A line commensurable to a line
containing in power two medialls, is also a line containing in power two
medialls.
SVppose that AB be a line containing in power two medialls. And unto the line
AB let the line CD be commensurable, whether in length and power, or in power
only. Then I say, that the line CD is a line containing in power two medialls.
Forasmuch as the line AB is a line containing in power two medialls,
Construction.
let it be divided into his parts in the point E. Wherefore (by the 41. of the
tenth) the lines AE and EB are incommensurable in power, having that which is
made of the squares of them added together mediall, and that also which is
contained under them mediall, and that which is made of the squares of the
lines AE and EB is incommensurable to that which is contained under the lines
AE and EB. Let the self same construction be in this, that was in the former.
Demonstration.
And in like sort may we prove, that the lines CF and FD are incommensurable in
power, and that that which is made of the squares of the lines AE and EB added
together, is commensurable to that which is made of the squares of the lines CF
and FD added together, and that that also which is contained under the lines AE
and EB is commensurable to that which is contained under the lines CF and FD.
Wherefore that which is made of the squares of the lines CF and FD is mediall
(by the Corollary of the 23. of the tenth): and that which is contained under
the lines CF and FD is mediall (by the same Corollary)^ and moreover, that
which is made of the squares of the lines CF and FD is incommensurable to that
which is contained under the lines CF and FD. Wherefore the line CD is a line
containing in power two medialls: which was required to be proved.

An Assumpt added by Montaureus.
An Assumpt.
That that which is made of the squares of the lines CF and FD added together,
is incommensurable to that which is contained under the lines CF and FD is thus
proved. For, because as that which is made of the squares of the lines AE and
EB added together is to the square of the line AE, so is that which is made of
the squares of the lines CF and FD added together, to the square of the line
CF, as it was proved in the Propositions going before: therefore alternately,
as that which is made of the squares of AE and EB added together is to that
which is made of the squares of CF and FD added together, so is the square of
the line AE to the square of the line CF. But before, namely, in the 68.
Proposition, it was proved, that as the square of the line AE is to the square
of the line CF, so is the parallelogra^me contained under the lines AE and EB
to the parallelogramme contained under the lines CF and FD. Wherefore as that
which is made of the squares of the lines AE and EB is to that which is made of
the squares of the lines CF and FD, so is the parallelogramme contained under
the lines AE and EB to the parallelogramme contained under the lines CF and FD.
Wherefore alternately, as that which is made of the squares of the lines AE and
EB is to the parallelogramme contained under the lines AE and EB, so is that
which is made of the squares of the lines CF and FD to the parallelogramme
contained under the lines CF and FD. But by supposition that which is made of
the squares of the lines AE and EB, is incomm^nsurable to the parallelogramme
contained under the lines AE and EB. Wherefore that which is made of the
squares of the lines CF and FD added together, is incommens^rable to the
parallelogramme contained under the lines CF and FD: which was required to be
proved.

An other demonstration after Campane.
Suppose that AB be a line containing in power two medialls: whereunto let the
line GD be commensurable either in length, and in power, or in power only. An
other demonstration after Campan^.
Then I say, that the line GD is a line co^tayning in power two medialls. Let
the same construction be in this, that was in the former. And forasmuch as the
parallelogramme OF is equal to the square of the line AB, and is applied upon
a rational line EZ, it makes the breadth EC a sixth binomiall line, by the 65.
of this book. And forasmuch as the parallelogrammes OF and CI (which are
equal unto the squares of the lines AB and GD, which are supposed to be
commensurable) are commensurable, therefore the lines EC and CH are
commensurable in length, by the first of the sixth. But EC is a sixth binomiall
line: Wherefore CH also is a sixth binomiall line, by the 66. of this book. And
forasmuch as the superficies CI is contained under the rational line CF and a
sixth binomiall line CH, therefore the line which co^tayneth in power the
superficies CI, namely, the line GD is a line containing in power two medialls,
by the 59. of this book. Wherefore a line commensurable to a line containing
in power two medialls. etc.

An Annotation.
If other to has been spoken of six Senarys, of which the first Senary
contains the pr^duction of irrational lines by composition: the second, the
division of them, namely, that those lines are in one poin^ only deuide^ the
third, the finding out of binomiall lines, of the first, I say, the second, the
third, the fourth, the fifth, and the sixth: after that begins the ^ourth
Senary, containing the difference of irrational lines between them selves. For
by the nature of every one of the binomiall lines are demonstrated the
differences of irrational lines. The fiueth entre^teth of the applications of
the squares of every irrational line, namely, what irrational lines are the
breadthes of every superficies so applied. In the sixth Senary is proved, that
any line commensurable to any irrational line, is also an irrational line of
the same nature. And now shall be spoken of the seventh Senary, wherein again
are plainly set forth the rest of the differences of the said lines between
them selves.

And the^e is even in those irrational lines an arithmeticall
proportionalitie. Note.
And that line which is the arithmeticall mean proportional between the
parts of any irrational line, is also an irrational line of the self same
kind. First it is certain that there is an arithmeticall proportion between
those parts. For suppose that the line AB be any of the foresaid irrational
lines, as for example, let it be a binomiall line, and let it be divided into
his names in the point C. And let AC be the greater name, from which take away
the line AD equal to the less name, namely, to CB. And divide the line CD
into two equal parts in the point E. It is manifest that the line AE is
equal to the line EB. Let the line FG be equal to either of them. It is
plain that how much the line AC differs from the line FG, so much the same
line FG di^^ereth from the line CB: for in each is the difference of the line
DE or EC, which is the property of arithmeticall proportionalitie. And it is
manifest, that the line FG is commensurable in length to the line AB, for it is
the half thereof. Wherefore (by the 66. of the tenth) the line FG is a
binomiall line. And after the self same manner may it be proved touching the
rest of the irrational lines.

The 53. Theoreme. The 71. Proposition. If two superficieces, namely, a
rational and a mediall superficies be composed together, the line which
contains in power the whole superficies, is one of these four irrational
lines, either a binomial line, or a first bimediall line, or a greater line, or
a line containing in power a rational and a mediall superficies.
SVppose that there be two superficieces AB and CD, The seuent^ Senary.
of which let the superficies AB be rational, and the superficies CD mediall.
The^ I say that the line containing in power y^ whole superficies AD, is either
a binomial line, or a first bimediall line, or a greater line, Construction.
or a line co^tayning in power a rational and a mediall superficies. For the
superficies AB is either greater or less the^ the superficies CD for they ca^
by no means be equal, when as the one is rational, and the other medial).
First let it be greater, Two cases in this proposition, of which each also has
his two cases.

First case.


and take a rational line OF. And (by the 44. of the first) unto the line OF
apply the parallelogramme EG equal to the superficies AB, and making in breadth
the line EH, and to the same line OF, that is, to the line HG apply the
parallelogramme HI equal to the superficies DC, and making in breadth the line
HK. Demonstration.
And forasmuch as the superficies AB is rational, and is equal to the
parallelogramme EG, therefore the parallelogramme EG is also rational, and it is
applied unto the rational line OF, making in breadth the line EH. Wherefore the
line EH is rational and commensurable in length to the line OF (by the 20. of
the tenth). Again forasmuch as the superficies CD is mediall, and is equal to
the parallelogra^me HI, therefore the parallelogra^me HI is also mediall, and is
applied unto the rational line OF, that is, unto the line HG making in breadth
the line HK. Wherefore the line HK is rational and incommensurable in length to
the line OF (by the 2^ of the tenth.) And forasmuch as the superficies CD is
mediall, and the superficies AB is rational, therefore the superficies AB is
incommensurable to the superficies CD. Wherefore also the parallelogramme EG is
incommensurable to the parallelogramme HI. But as the parallelogramme GE is to
the parallelogramme HI, so (by the 1. of the sixth) is the line EH to the line
HK. Wherefore (by the 10. of the tenth) the line EH is incommensurable in length
to the line HK, and they are both rational. Wherefore the lines EH and HK are
rational commensurable in power only. Wherefore the whole line EK is a
binomiall line, and is divided into his names in the point H. And forasmuch as
the super^icies AB is greater then the superficies CD, but the superficies AB
is equal to the parallelogramme EG, and the superficies CD to the
parallelogramme HI. Wherefore the parallelogramme EG is greater then the
parallelogramme HI. Wherefore the line EH is greater then the line HK. Wherefore
the line EH is in power more then the line HK either by the square of a line
commensurable in length to the line EH, or by the square of a line
incommensurable in length to the line EH. First part of the first case.
First let it be in power more by the square of a line co^me^surable in length
unto the line EH. Now the greater name, namely, EH is commensurable in length
to the rational line given OF, as it has already been proved. Wherefore the
whole line EK is a first binomiall line. And the line OF is a rational line.
But if a superficies be contained under a rational line, and a first binomiall
line, the line that contains in power the same superficies, is (by the 54. of
the tenth) a binomiall line. Wherefore the line containing in power the
parallelogramme EI is a binomiall line. Wherefore also the line containing in
power the superficies AD is a binomiall line.

But now let the line EH be in power more then the line HK by the square of a
line incommensurable in length to the line EH: Second part of the first case.
now the greater name that is, EH is commensurable in length to the rational
line given OF. Wherefore the line EK is afourth binomiall line. And the line OF
is rational. But if a superficies be contained under a rational line and
afourth binomiall line, the line that contains in power the same superficies
is (by the 57. of the tenth) irrational, and is a greater line. Wherefore the
line which contains in power the parallelogramme EI is a greater line.
Wherefore also the line containing in power the superficies AD is a greater
line.

The second case.
But now suppose that the superficies AB which is rational, be less then the
superficies CD which is mediall. Wherefore also the parallelogramme EG is less
then the parallelogra^me HI. Wherefore also the line EH is less then the line
HK. Now the line HK is in power more then the line EH either by the square of a
line co^mensurable in length to the line HK, or by the square of a line
incommensurable in length unto the line HK. First let it be in power more by
the square of a line commensurable in length unto HK: First part of the second
case.
now the less name, that is EH is commensurable in length to the rational
line given OF, as it was before proved. Wherefore the whole line EK is a second
binomiall line. And the line OF is a rational line. But if a superficies be
contained under a rational line and a second binomiall line, the line that
contains in power the same superficies, is (by the 55. of the tenth) a first
bimediall line. Wherefore the line which contains in power the parallelograme
EI is a first bimediall line. Wherefore also the line that contains in power
the superficies AD is a first bimediall line.

Second part of the second case.
But now let the line HK be in power more then the line EH, by the square of a
line inco^mensurable in length to the line HK, now the less name, that is, EH
is co^mensurable in length to the rational line given OF. Wherefore the whole
line EK is a fifth binomiall line. And the line OF is rational. But if a
superficies be contained under a rational line, and a fifth binomiall line, the
line that contains in power the same superficies, is (by the 58. of the
tenth) a line containing in power a rational and a mediall. Wherefore the line
that contains in power the parallelogramme EI is a line containing in power a
rational and a mediall. Wherefore also the line that contains in power the
superficies AD is a line containing in power a rational and a mediall. If
therefore a rational and a mediall superficies be added together, the line
which contains in power the whole superficies, is one of these four
irrational lines, namely, either a binomiall line, or a first bimediall line,
or a greater line, or a line containing in power a rational and a mediall:
which was required to be demonstrated.

The 54. Theoreme. The 72. Proposition. If two mediall superficieces
incommensurable the one to the other be composed together: the line containing
in power the whole superficies is one of the two irrational lines remaining,
namely, either a second bimediall line, or a line containing in power two
medialls.
LEt these two mediall superficieces AB and CD being incommensurable the one to
the other be added together. Then I say, that the line which contains in
power the superficies AD is either a second bimediall line, or a line
containing in power two medialls. Construction.
For the superficies AB is either greater or less then the superficies CD (for
they can by no means be equal, when as they are incommensurable). Two cases
in this Proposition.

The first case.


First let the superficies AB be greater then the superficies CD. And take a
rational line OF. And (by the 44. of the first) unto the line OF apply the
parallelogramme EG equal to the superficies AB, and making in breadth the line
EH: and unto the same line OF, that is, to the line HG, apply the
parallelogramme HI equal to the superficies CD, and making in breadth the line
HK. And forasmuch as either of these superficieces AB and CD is mediall,
therefore also either of these parallelogrammes EG and HI is mediall. And they
are each applied to the rational line OF, making in breadth the lines EH and
HK. Wherefore (by the 22. of the tenth) either of these lines EH and HK is
rational and incommensurable in length to the line OF. And forasmuch as the
superficies AB is incommensurable to the superficies CD, and the superficies AB
is equal to the parallelogramme E^, and the superficies CD to the
parallelogramme HI: therefore the parallelogramme EG is incommensurable to the
parallelogramme HI. But (by the 1. of the sixth) as the parallelogramme EG is to
the parallelogramme HI, so is the line EH^ to the line HK. Wherefore (by the
10. of the tenth) the line EH i^ ^spans^ HK^ Wherefore the ^^nes EH and HK are
rational commensurable in power only. Wherefore the whole line EK is a
binomiall line. And as in the former Proposition so als^ in this may it be
proved, that the line EH is greater then the line HK. Wherefore the line EH is
in power more then the line HK, either by the square of a line commensurable in
length to the line EH, or by the square of a line incommensurable in length to
the line EH. First let it be greater by the square of a line commensurable in
length unto the line EH. The first part of the first case.
Now neither of these lines EH and HK is commensurable in length to the
rational line given OF. Wherefore the whole line EK is a third binomiall line.
And the line OF is a rational line. But if a superficies be contained under a
rational line and a third binomiall line, the line that contains in power
the same superficies, is (by the 56. of the tenth) a second bimediall line.
Wherefore the line that contains in power the superficies EI, that is, the
superficies AD, is a second bimediall line.

(...) second (...) of the (...) case.
But now suppose that the line EH be in power more then the line HK by the
square of a line incommensurable in length to the line EH. And forasmuch as
either of these lines EH and HK is incommensurable in length to the rational
line given OF, therefore the line EK is a sixth binomiall line. But if a
superficies be contained under a rational line and a sixth binomiall line, the
line that contains in power the same superficies, is (by the 59. of the
tenth) a line containing in power two medialls. Wherefore the line that
contains in power the superficies AD, is a line containing in power two
medialls. The second case.
And after the self same manner, if the superficies AB be less then the
superficies CD, may we prove, that the line that contains in power the
superficies AD, is either a second bimediall line, or a line containing in
power two medialls. If therefore two mediall superficieces incommensurable the
one to the other be added together, the line containing in power the whole
superficies is one of the two irrational lines remaining, namely, either a
second bimediall line, or a line co^taining in power two medialls: which was
required to be proved.

A Corollary following of the former Propositions.
A binomiall line and the other irrational lines following it, are neither
mediall lines, nor one and the same between them selves. For the square of a
mediall line applied to a rational line, A Corollary
makes the breadth rational and incommensurale in length to the rational
line, whereunto it is applied (by the 22. of the tenth). The square of a
binomiall line applied to ^ rational line, makes the breadth a first
binomiall line (by the 60. of the tenth). The square of a first bimediall line
applied unto a rational line, makes the breadth a second binomiall line (by
the 61. of the tenth). The square of a second bimediall line applied unto a
rational line, makes the breadth a third binomiall line (by the 62. of the
tenth). The square of a greater line applied to a rational line, makes the
breadth a fourth binomiall line (by the 63. of the tenth). The square of a line
containing in power a rational and a mediall superficies, makes the breadth a
fifth binomiall line (by the 64. of the tenth). And the square of a line
containing in power two medialls, applied unto a rational line, makes the
breadth a sixth binomiall line (by the 65. of the tenth). Seeing therefore that
these foresaid breadthes differ both from the first breadth, for that it is
rational, and differ also the one from the other, for that they are binomials
of diverse orders: it is manifest that those irrational lines differ also the
one from the other.

Here begins the Senaries by substraction. The 55. Theoreme. The 73.
Proposition. If from a rational line be taken away a rational line
commensurable in power only to the whole line: the residue is an irrational
line, and is called a residuall line.
SVppose that AB be a rational line, and from AB take away a rational line BC
commensurable in power only to the whole line AB. The first Senary by
substraction.
Then I say that the line remaining, namely AC is irrational and is called a
residuall line. For forasmuch as the line AB is incommensurable in length unto
the line BC, and (by the assumpt going before the 22. of the tenth) as the line
AB is to the line BC, Demonstration.
so i^ the square of the line AB to that which is contained under the lines AB
and BC: wherefore (by the 10. of the tenth) the square of the line AB is
incommensurable to that which is contained under the lines AB and BC. But unto
the square of the line AB are commensurable the squares of the lines AB and BC
(by the 15. of the tenth). Wherefore the squares of the lines AB and BC are
incommensurable to that which is contained under the lines AB and BC. But unto
that which is contained under the lines AB and BC is commensurable that which
is contained under the lines AB and BC twice. Wherefore the squares of the
lines AB and BC are inco^me^surable to that which is contained under the lines
AB and BC twice. But the squares of the lines AB and BC are equal to that
which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice, and to the square of the
line AC (by the 7. of the second). Wherefore that which is contained under the
lines AB and BC twice together with the square of the line AC is
incommensurable to that which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice.
Wherefore (by the 2 part of the 16. of the tenth) that which is contained under
the lines AB and BC twice, is inco^me^surable to the square of the line AC.
Wherefore (by the first part of the same) that which is contained under the
lines AB and BC twice together with the square of the line AC, that is, the
squares of the lines AB and BC are incommensurable to the square of the line
AC. But the squares of the lines AB and BC are rational, for the lines AB and
BC are put to be rational: wherefore the line AC is irrational and is called a
residuall line: which was required to be proved.

An other demonstration after Campane.
Campane demonstrateth this Proposition by a figure more briefly after this
m^ner. An other demonstration after Campane.
Let the superficies EG be equal to the squares of the lines AB and BC added
together: which shall be rational (for that the lines AB and BC are supposed
to be rational co^mensurable in power only). From which superficies take away
the superficies DF equal to that which is con^^ya^d under the lines AB and DC
twice, which shall be mediall (by the 21. of this book). Now by the 7. of the
second, the superficies FG is equal to the square of the line AC. And
forasmuch as the superficies EG is incommensurable to the superficies DF (for
that the one is rational and the other mediall): therefore (by the 16. of this
book) the (...) superficies EG is incommensurable to the superficies FG.
Wherefore the superficies FG is irrational. And therefore the line AC which
contains it in power is irrational: which was required to be proved.

An annotation of P. Monta^re^s.
This Theoreme teaches nothing else but that that portion of the greater name
of a binomiall line which remains after the taking away of the less name
from the greater name is irrational, which is called a residuall line, that is
to say, if from the greater name of a binomiall line, which greater name is a
rational line co^mensurable in power only to the less name, be taken away
the less name, which self less name is also commensurable in power only to
the greater name (which greater name this Theoreme calls the whole line) the
rest of the line which remains is irrational, which he calls a residuall
line. Wherefore all the lines which are entreated in this Theoreme, and in the
five other which follow are the portions remaining of the greater parts of the
whole lines which were entreated of in the 36.37.38.39.40.41. propositio^s,
after the taking away the less part from the greater.

In this proposition is set forth the nature of the eight kind of irrational
lines which is called a residuall line, the definition whereof by this
proposition is thus.

Diffinition of the eight irrational line.
A residuall line is an irrational line which remains, when from a rational
line given, is taken away a rational line commensurable to the whole line in
power only.

The 56. Theoreme. The 74. Proposition. If from a mediall line be taken away a
mediall line commensurable in power only to the whole line, and comprehending
together with the whole line a rational superficies: the residue is an
irrational line, and is called a first mediall residuall line.
SVppose that AB be a mediall line. And from the line AB take away a mediall
line BC commensurable in power only to the whole line AB and comprehending
together with the line AB a rational superficies, that is, let that which is
comprehended under the lines AB and BC be rational. Then I say that the line
remaining, namely, AC is irrational and is called a first mediall residuall
line. ^^monstra^ion.
For forasmuch as the lines AB and BC are mediall, therefore also the squares
of the lines AB and BC are mediall. But that which is contained under the lines
AB and BC twice is rational. Wherefore that which is composed of the squares
of the lines AB and BC, that is, that which is contained under AB and BC twice
together with the square of the line AC is incommensurable to that which is
contained under the lines AB and BC twice. Wherefore (by the second part the
16. of the tenth) that which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice is
incommensurable to the square of the line AC. But that which is contained under
the lines AB and BC twice it rational, wherefore the square of the line AC is
irrational. Wherefore also the line AC is irrationall^ and is called a first
mediall residuall line. This first mediall residuall line is also that part of
the greater part of a first bimediall line, which remains after the taking
away of the less part from the greater, whereof it has also his name, and is
called a first mediall residuall lines which was required to be proved.

Out of this proposition is taken the definition of the ninth kind of
irrational lines, which is called a first residuall mediall line the
difinition whereof is thus.

Diffinition of (...) ^inth irrational line.
A first residuall mediall line is an irrational line which remains, when
from a mediall line is taken away a mediall line commensurable to the whole in
power only, and the part taken away and the whole line contain a mediall
superficies.

An other demonstration after Campane.
Let the line DE be rational, upon which apply the superficies DF equal to
that which is cont^ined under the lines AB and BC twice, and let the
superficies GE be equal to that which is composed of the squares of the lines
AB and BC: An other demonstration after Campane.
wherefore by the 7. of the second, the superficies FG is equal to the square of
the line AC. And forasmuch as (by supposition) the superficies EG is mediall,
therefore (by the 22. of the tenth) the line DG is rational co^mensurable in
power only to the rational line DE. And forasmuch as by supposition the
superficies EH is rational, therefore by the 20. of the tenth, the line DH is
rational commensurable in length unto the rational line DE. Wherefore the lines
DG and DH are rational commensurable in power only (by the assumpt put before
the 13. of this book). Wherefore by the 73 of this book, the line GH is a
residuall line, and is therefore irrational. Wherefore (by the corollary of the
21. of this book) the superficies FG is irrational. And therefore the line AC
which co^tayneth it in power is irrational, and is called a first medial
residuall line.

The 57. Theoreme. The 75. Proposition. If from a mediall line be taken away a
mediall line commensurable in power only to the whole line, and comprehending
together with the whole line a mediall superficies, the residue is an
irrational line, and is called a second mediall residuall line.
SVppose that AB be a mediall line, and from AB take away a mediall line CB
commensurable in power only to the whole line AB, and comprehending together
with the whole line AB a mediall superficies, namely, the parallelogramme
contained under the lines AB and BC. Construction.
Then I say that the residue, namely; the line AC is irrational, and is called
a second mediall residuall line. Take a rational line DI, and (by the 44. of
the first) unto the line DI apply the parallelogramme DE equal to the squares
of the lines AB and BC, and making in breadth the line DG. Demonstration.
And unto the same line DI apply the parallelogramme DH equal to that which is
contained under the lines AB and BC twice, and making in breadth the line DF.
Now the parallelogramme DH is less then the parallelogramme DE, for that also
the square of the lines AB and BC are greater then that which is contained
under the lines AB and BC twice, by the square of the line AC by the 7. of the
second. Wherefore the parallelogramme remaining, namely, FE, is equal to the
square of the line AC. And forasmuch as the squares of the lines AB and BC are
mediall, therefore also the parallelogramme DE is mediall, and is applied to the
rational line DI, making in breadth the line DG. Wherefore (by the 22. of the
tenth) the line DG is rational and incommensurable in length to the line DI.
Again forasmuch as that which is contained under the lines AB and BC is
mediall, therefore also that which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice
is mediall, but that which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice is
equal to the parallelogramme DH. Wherefore the parallelogramme DH is mediall
and is applied to the rational line DI making in breadth the line DF. Wherefore
the line DF is rational and incommensurable in length to the line DI. And
forasmuch as the lines AB and BC are co^mensurable in power only, therefore the
line AB is incomme^surable in length to the line BC. Wherefore (by the assumpt
going before the 22. of the tenth, and by the 10. of the tenth) the square of
the line AB is incommensurable to that which is contained under the lines AB
and BC. But unto the square of the line AB are commensurable the squares of AB
and BC (by the 15. of the tenth) And unto that which is contained under the
lines AB and BC is comme^surable to that which is contained under the lines AB
and BC twice. Wherefore the squares of the lines AB and BC are incommensurable
to that which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice. But unto the
squares of the lines AB and BC is equal the parallelogra^me DE, and to that
which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice, is equal the
parallelogramme DH. Wherefore the parallelogra^me DE is inco^me^surable to the
parallelogramme DH. But as the parallelogramme DE is to the parallelogramme DH,
so i^ the line GD to the line DF. Wherefore the line GD is incommensurable in
length to the line DF. And either of the^ is rational. Wherefore the lines GD
and DF are rational commensurable in power only. Wherefore the line FG is a
residuall line (by the 73. proposition of the tenth) And the line DE is a
rational line. but a supe^ficies comprehended under a rational line, and an
irrational line is irrational (by the 21 of the te^^^^ and the line which
contains in power the same super^icies is irrational (by the assumpt going
before the same) Wherefore the parallelograme FE is irrational. But the line AC
contains in power the parallelogramme FE. Wherefore the line AC is an
irrational line and is called a second mediall residuall line. And this second
mediall residuall line is that part of the greater part of a bimediall line
which remains after the taking away of the less part from the greater: which
was required to be proved.

An other demonstrtion more brief after Campane.
An other demon^^ra^ion after Campane.
Suppose that AB be a mediall line, from which take away the mediall line GB
commensurable unto the whole line AB in power only and containing with it ^
mediall superficies, namely, that which is contained under the lines AB and BG.
Then I say that the residue AG is an i^rationall line, and is called a second
mediall residua^l line. Take a rational line DC, upon which apply a
parallelogramme equal to that which is composed of the squares of the lines AB
and BG, which by the 45. of the first let be DCEI. Again let the
parallelogramme ZFEI be equal to that which is contained under the line^ AB
and BG twice. Wherefore the superficies remaining DF is equal to the square of
the line AG by the 7. of the second. (For that which is contained under the
lines AB and BG twice together with the square of the line A^ is equal to that
which is composed of the squares of the lines AB and B G). And forasmuch as the
squares of the lines AB and BG are mediall, for that they are described of
medial lines: the parllelogra^me DE which is equal unto the^, shall also be
mediall. And foras^uch as that which is contained under the lines AB and BG is
by supposition mediall, therefore the superficie^ Z^ which is double unto it is
also mediall. But the mediall superficies DE excedeth not the mediall
supe^ficies ZE by a rational superficies (by the 26. of this book). Wherefore
the excess, namely, the super^icies D^ is irrational, unto which the square
of the line A^ is equal: wherefore the square of the line A^ is ir^ationall,
and therefore the line AG which contains it in power is irrational by the
assumpt put before the 21. of this book, and is called a second mediall
residuall line.

This proposition sets forth the nature of the tenth kind of irrational
lines, which is called a second residuall mediall line, which is thus defined.

Diffinition of the tenth ir^ationall line.
A second residual^ mediall line is an irrational line which remains, when
from a medial line is taken away a mediall line commensurable to the whole in
power only, and the part taken away and the whole line contain a mediall
superficies.

The 58. Theoreme. The 76. Proposition. I^ from a right line be taken away a
right line incommensurable in power to the whole, and if that which is made of
the squares of the whole line and of the line taken away added together be
rational, and the parallelogra^me contained under the same lines mediall: the
line remaining is irrational, and is called a less line.
SVppose that AB be a right line, and from the right line AB take away a right
line BC incommensurable in power to the whole line, namely, to AB, and let that
which is composed of the squares of the lines AB and BC be rational, and let
the parallelogramme contained under the same lines AB and BC be mediall. Then I
say, that the line remaining, namely, the line AC is irrational, and is called
a less line. For forasmuch as that which is composed of the squares of the
lines AB and BC is rational, Demonstration.
and that which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice is mediall,
therefore that which is composed of the squares of the lines AB and BC is
incommensurable to that which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice.
Wherefore the squares of the lines AB and BC, are inco^mensurable to the square
of AC, as it was said in the 73. Proposition. But that which is made of the
squares of the lines AB and BC is rational. Wherefore the square of the line
AC is irrational: wherefore also the line AC is irrational: and is called a
less line. And is therefore so called, for that it is that portion of the
greater part of a greater line, which remains after the taking away of the
less part from the greater: which was required to be proved.

In this Proposition is contained the definition of the eleventh kind of
irrational lines, which is called a less line, whose definition is thus.

A less line is an irrational line which remains, Diffinition of the
eleue^th irrational line.
when from a right line is taken away a right line incommensurable in power to
the whole, and the square of the whole line, and the square of the part taken
away added together, make a rational superficies, and the parallelogramme
contained of them is mediall.

This Proposition may after Campanes way be demonstrated, if you remember well
the order and positions which he in the three former Propositions used.

The 19. Theoreme. The 77. Proposition. If from a right line be taken away a
right line incommensurable in power to the whole line, and if that which is
made of the squares of the whole line and of the line taken away added together
be mediall, and the parallelogramme contained under the same lines rational:
the line remaining is irrational, and is called a line making with a rational
superficies the whole superficies mediall.
SVppose that AB be a right line, and from the right line AB take away a right
line BC incommensurable in power to the whole line AB, and let that which is
made of the squares of the lines AB and BC added together, be mediall, and the
parallelogramme contained under the same lines rational. Then I say, that the
line remaining, namely, the line AC, is irrational, and is called a line
making with a rational superficies the whole superficies mediall.
Demonstration.
For for^smuch as that which is made of the squares of the lines AB and BC
added together is mediall, and that which is contained under the lines AB and
BC twice is rational, therefore that which is made of the squares of the lines
AB and BC added together, is incommensurable to that which is contained under
the lines AB and BC twice. Wherefore (by the 16. of the tenth) the residue,
namely, the square of the line AC is incommensurable to that which is contained
under the lines AB and BC twice. But that which is contained under the lines AB
and BC twice is rational. Wherefore the square of the line AC is irrational.
Wherefore also the line AC is irrational: and is called a line making with a
rational super^icies the whole superficies mediall: and is therefore so called
for that that which is made of the squares of the lines AB and BC added
together is mediall, and is a certain whole superficies, part whereof is that
which is contained under the lines AB and BC, which is a rational superficies.
For the squares of the lines AB and BC, are equal to that which is contained
under the lines AB and BC twice, and to the square of the line AC (by the 7. of
the second). Or it is therefore so called for that the square thereof added to
a rational super^icies, makes the whole superficies mediall, as shall be
proved by the 109. Proposition of this book: which was required to be proved.

In this Proposition is declared the nature of the twelueth kind of irrational
lines, which is called a line making with a rational superficies the whole
superficies mediall, whose definition is thus.

^^^^i^ition of the twelueth irra^ionall line.
A line making with a rational superficies the whole superficies mediall, is an
irrational line which remains, when from a right line is taken away a right
line inco^mensurable in power to the whole line, and the square of the whole
line and the square of the part taken away added together make a mediall
superficies, and the parallelogramme contained of them is rational.

This Proposition also may after Campanes way be demonstrated, observing the
former caution.

The 60. Theoreme. The 78. Proposition. If from a right line be taken away a
right line incommensurable in power to the whole line, and if that which is
made of the squares of the whole line and of the line taken away added together
be medial, and the parallelogramme contained under the same lines be also
mediall, and incommensurable to that which is made of the squares of the said
lines added together: the line remaining is irrational, and is called a line
making with a mediall superficies the whole superficies mediall.
SVppose that AB be a right line, and from AB take away a right line BC
incommensurable in power to the whole line AB. And let that which is made of
the squares of the lines AB and BC added together be mediall, and let the
parallelograme contained under the lines AB and BC be also medial, and let that
which is made of the squares of the lines AB and BC added together be
incommensurable to that which is contained under the lines AB and BC. The^ I
say that the line remaining, namely, the line AC i^ irrational and is called a
line making with a mediall superficies the whole superficies medial. Take a
rational line DI. And (by the 44. of the first) unto the line DI apply the
parallelogramme DE equal to that which is made of the squares of the lines AB
and BC added together, Construction.
and making in breadth the line DG. And unto the same line DI apply the
parallelogramme DH equal to that which is contained under the lines AB and BC
twice and making in breadth the line DF. Wherefore the parallelogramme
remaining, namely the parallelogramme FE, is equal to the square of the line
AC. Wherefore the line AC contains in power the parallelograme FE.
Demonstration.
And forasmuch as that which is made of the squares of the lines AB and BC
added together is mediall, and is equal to the parallelogramme DE, therefore
also the parallelogramme DE is mediall. And the parallelogramme DE is applied
to the rational line DI making in breadth the line DG. Wherefore (by the 22. of
the tenth) the line DG is rational and incommensurable in length to the line
DI. Again forasmuch as that which is contained under the lines AB and BC twice
is mediall and is equal to the parallelogramme DH, therefore the
parallelogramme DH is mediall. And the parallelograme DH is applied unto the
rational line DI making in breadth the line DF, wherefore the line DF is
rational and incommensurable in length to the line DI. And forasmuch as that
which is made of the squares of the lines AB and BC added together is
incommensurable to that which contained under the lines AB and BC twice,
therefore the parallelogramme DE is incommensurable to the parallelogramme DH.
But as the parallelogramme DE is to the parallelogramme DH, so (by the first of
the sixth) is the line DG to the line DF: wherefore the line DG is
incommensurable in length to the line DF. And they are both rational lines.
Wherefore the lines DG and DF are rational commensurable in power only,
where^ore the line FG is a residuall line by the 73. of this booke^ But the
line FH is rational for that it is equal unto the line DI. But a rectangle
parallelogramme contained under a rational line and an irrational line is
irrational, and the line also that contains in power the same
parallelogramme is irrational (by the 21. of the tenth). But the line CA
contains in power the parallelogramme FE. Wherefore the line AC is
irrational and is called a line making with a mediall superficies the whole
superficies mediall. And is therefore so called, for that that which is made of
the squares of the lines AB and BC added together is mediall, and is a certain
whole superficies, part whereof is that which is contained under the lines AB
and BC, which is also mediall: you shall also by the 110. proposition of this
book understand an other cause why it is so called.

This proposition may thus more briefly be demonstrated: forasmuch as that
which is composed of the squares of the lines AB and BC is mediall, and that
also which is contained under them is mediall, therefore the parallelogramm^s
DE and DH which are equal unto them are mediall: but a mediall superficies
exceeds not a mediall superficies by a rational superficies. Wherefore the
superficies FE which is the excess of the mediall superficies DE above the
mediall superficies DH is irrational. And therefore the line AC which
contains it in power is irrational. etc.

In this proposition is showed the condition and nature of the thirtenth and
last kind of irrational lines, which is called a line making with a mediall
superficies the whole superficies mediall, whose definition is thus.

A line making with a mediall superficies the whole superficies mediall is an
irrational line which remains, Diffinition of the thirtenth and last
irrational line.
when from a right li^e is taken away a right line incommensurable in power to
the whole line, and the squares of the whole line and of the line taken away
added together make a mediall superficies, and the parallelogramme contained of
the^ is also a mediall superficies, moreover the squares of them are
incommensurable to the parallelogramme contained of them.

An assumpt of Campane.
If there be four qua^tities, and if the difference of the first to the
second, be as the difference of the third to the fourth, then alternately, as
the difference of the first is to the third, so is the difference of the second
to the fourth.

This is to be understand of qua^tities in like sort referred the one to the
other, that is if the first be greater then the second, An Assumpt of Campane.
the third ought to be greater then the fourth and if the first be less then
the second, the third ought to be less then the fourth: and is also to be
understand in arithmeticiall proportionality. As for example let the difference
of A be unto B as the difference of C is to D. I. Dee.

Though Campanes lemma be true, ye^ the manner of demonstrating it, (narrowly
considered) is not artificial.


Then I say that as the difference of A is to C, so is the difference of B to
D. For (by this common sentence, the difference of the extremes is composed of
the differences of the extremes to the means), the difference of A to C is
composed of the difference of A to B and of the difference of B to C. And (by
the same common sentence) the difference of B to D is composed of the
difference of B to C, and of ^he difference of C to D. And forasmuch as (by
supposition) the difference of A to B is as the difference of C to D, and the
difference of B to C is common to them both. Wherefore it follows, that as
the difference of A is to C, so is the difference of B to D: which was required
to be proved.

The 61. Theoreme. The 79. Proposition. Unto a residual line can be joined one
only right line rational, and commensurable in power only to the whole line.
Second Senary.
LEt AB be a residuall line, and unto it let the line BC be supposed to be
joined, so that let the lines AC and BC be rational commensurable in power
only. Then I say that unto the line AB cannot be joined any other rational
line commensurable in power only to the whole line. Demonstration leading to
an impossibility.
For if it be possible, let BD be such a line added unto it. Wherefore the lines
AD and DB are rational commensurable in power only. And forasmuch as how much
the squares of the lines AD and DB do exceed that which is contained under the
lines AD and DB twice, so much also do the squares of the lines AC and CB
exceed that which is contained under the lines AC and CB twice, for the
excess of each is one and the same, namely, the square of the line AB (by the
7. of the second.) Wher^ore alternately (by the ^ormer assumpt of Campanus) how
much the squares of the lines AD and DB do exceed the squares of the lines AC
and CB, so much also excedeth that which is contained under the lines AD and DB
twice, that which is contained under the lines AC and CB twice. But that which
is made of the squares of the lines AD and DB added together, exceeds that
which is made of the squares of the lines AC and CB added together by a
rational super^icies: (for they are either of them rational). Wherefore that
which is contained under the lines AD and DB twice, exceeds that which is
contained under the lines AC and CB twice by a rational superficies. But that
which is contained under the lines AD and DB twice, is mediall, for it is
commensurable to that which is contained under the lines AD and DB once, which
superficies is mediall (by the 21. of the tenth) and by the same reason also
that which is contained under the lines AC and CB twice is mediall. Wherefore a
mediall superficies differs from a mediall superficies by a rational
superficies, which (by the 26. of the tenth) is impossible. Wherefore unto the
line AB cannot be joined any other rational line besides BC commensurable in
power only, to the whole line. Wherefore unto a residuall line can be joined
one only right line rational and commensurable in power only to the whole
line: which was required to be demonstrated.

The 62. Theoreme. The 80. Proposition. Unto a first medial residuall line can
be joined one only mediall right line, commensurable in power only to the
whole line, and comprehendyng with the whole line a rational superficies.
SVppose that AB be a first mediall residuall line, and unto AB join the line
BC, so that let the lines AC and BC be mediall commensurable in power only,
and let that which is contained under the lines AC and BC be rational. Then I
say that unto the line AB cannot be joined any other mediall line commensurable
in power only to the whole line, and comprehending together with the whole
line a rational super^icies. Demonstration leading to an absurdity.
For if it be possible let the line BD be such a line. Wherefore the lines AD
and DB are mediall commensurable in power only, and that which is contained
under the lines AD and DB is rational. And forasmuch as how much the squares of
the lines AD and DB exceed that which is contained under the lines AD and DB
twice, so much also exceed the squares of the lines AC and BC, that which is
contained under the lines AC and CB twice (for the excess of each is one and
the same, namely, the square of the line AB). Wherefore alternately (as it was
said in the former proposition) how much the squares of the lines AD and DB
exceed the squares of the lines AC and CB, so much also that which is
contained under the lines AD and DB twice, excedeth that which is contained
under the lines AC and CB twice. But that which is contained under the lines AD
and DB twice, excedeth that which is contained under the lines AC and CB twice
by a rational superficies, for they are either of them a rational
supersicies. Wherefore that which is made of the squares of the lines AD and DB
excedeth that which is made of the squares of the lines AC and CB by a
rational superficies, which (by the 26. of the tenth) is impossible. For they
are either of them mediall (for those four lines were put to be mediall.)
Wherefore unto a first mediall residuall line can be joined only one right
mediall line commensurable in power only to the whole line, and comprehending
with the whole line a rational super^icies: which was required to be proved.

The 63. Theoreme. The 81. Proposition. Unto a second mediall residuall line
can be joined only one mediall right line, commensurable in power only to the
whole line, and comprehending with the whole line a mediall superficies.
SVppose that AB be a second mediall residual line, and unto the line AB join
the line BC, so that let the lines AC and CB be mediall co^mensurable in power
only, and let that which is comprehended under the lines AC and CB be mediall.
Then I say, that unto the line AB can not be joined any other mediall right
line co^mensurable in power only to the whole line, and comprehending together
with the whole line a mediall superficies. For if it be possible, let the line
BD be such a line. Wherefore the lines AD and DB are mediall commensurable in
power only, and that which is contained under the lines AD and DB is also
mediall. Take a rational line OF. Construction.
And (by the 44. of the first) unto the line OF apply the parallelogramme EG
equal to the squares of the lines AC and CB, and making in breadth the line
EM: and from that parallelogramme EG take away the parallelogramme HG equal to
that which is contained under AC and CB twice, and making in breadth the line
HM. Wherefore the parallelogramme remaining, namely, EL, is (by the 7. of the
second) equal to the square of the line AB. Wherefore the line AB contains
in power the parallelograme EL. Again, unto the line OF apply (by the 44. of
the first) the parallelogramme EI equal to the squares of the lines AD and DB,
and making in breadth the line EN. But the squares of the lines AD and DB are
equal to that which is contained under the lines AD and DB twice, and to the
square of the line AB. Demonstration leading to an absurdity.
Wherefore the parallelogramme EI is equal to that which is contained under
the lines AD and DB twice, and to the square of the line AB. But the
parallelogramme EL is equal to the square of the line AB. Wherefore the
parallelogramme remaining, namely, HI, is equal to that which is contained
under the lines AD and DB twice. And forasmuch as the lines AC and CB are
^^^iall, therefor the squares also of the lines AC and CB are mediall: and
they are equal to the parallelogramme EG: wherefore the parallelogramme EG is
(by that which was spoken in the 75. Proposition) mediall: and it is applied
unto the rational line OF, making in breadth the line EM. Wherefore (by the
22. of the tenth) the line EM is rational, and in^ommensurable in length to
the line OF. Again, forasmuch as that which is contained under the lines AC
and CB is mediall, therefore (by the Corollary of the 23. of the tenth) that
which is contained under the lines AC and CB twice is also mediall: and it is
equal to the parallelogramme HG: wherefore also the parallelogramme HG is
mediall, and is applied to the rational line OF, making in breadth the line
